questions.text: The region marked corresponds to the surface marking for which of the following structures:(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Right atrium

 

Explanation:

 

The region marked corresponds to the surface marking for the right atrium.

 

This image shows the mid-clavicular line, xiphoid process, and costal margin.

 

The examiner marks a laterally convex line that runs from the third costal cartilage, which is located about three spaces below the second costal cartilage (as shown by the sternal angle), to the sixth costal cartilage. The distance between this line and the sternal margin is around 1.2 cm. This imply that the area designated matches the right atrium's surface marking.

 

An average adult's projected cardiac borders onto the front chest wall form a trapezium shape. The percussion approach can be used to map this out by checking for cardiac dullness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thoracic duct: The thoracic duct typically ascends in the posterior mediastinum and does not correspond to the surface marking in the image which is more anterior and lateral.

 

Option C. Inferomedial bronchopulmonary segments: These segments are located more inferiorly in the lung fields and do not correspond to the area marked which is on the chest wall at the level of the heart.

 

Option D. Hilum: The hilum of the lung, where structures enter and exit the lung, is located more laterally than the area marked. It does not align with the vertical placement of the right atrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The varying heart borders and the corresponding surface markings are as follows:

 

  • ﻿﻿Upper border: Slopes gently from the second left costal cartilage to the third right costal cartilage. It corresponds to the left atrium.
  • ﻿﻿Right border: Convex to the right and runs from the third to the sixth right costal cartilages, 1-2 cm lateral to the sternal edge. It corresponds to the right atrium.
  • ﻿﻿Inferior border or acute border: Runs leftwards from the 6th right costal cartilage to the cardiac apex which is located approximately
  • 9 cm lateral to the midline, often in the left 5th intercostal space or level with the 5th or 6th rib. It corresponds to the right ventricle.
  • ﻿﻿Left border or obtuse border: Convex laterally on the left. It extends superomedially from the cardiac apex to meet the second left costal cartilage about 1 cm from the left sternal edge. It corresponds to the left ventricle.

questions.text: After administering the patch test to a 10-year-old boy with a history of allergic contact dermatitis, when should you schedule his return for patch removal? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 48 hours

 

The Gold standard Diagnostic test for Airborne contact dermatitis (ABCD) & Allergic Contact Dermatitis (ACD) is a patch test. 

 

Patch testing:

 

  • It is a method used to determine if a specific substance causes allergic inflammation of a patient's skin.
  • It is typically indicated for patients with suspected allergic contact dermatitis.
  • The test involves the application of various substances in small chambers or patches to the skin, usually on the back.
  • After the application of a patch test, the patches are generally removed at 48 hours (2 days), and an initial reading is taken.
  • This timeframe allows for the elicitation of a Type IV or delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction, which is the basis of allergic contact dermatitis.
  • However, readings at 48 hours may not be sufficient to detect all reactions, and thus an additional reading at 96 hours is often recommended.
  • The additional reading helps to identify late reactions, which could otherwise be missed if only the 48-hour reading is considered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 24 hours

 

  • This timeframe is too short for most delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions to occur.
  • Removing the patches at 24 hours would likely result in missing many positive reactions.

 

Option B. 72 hours

 

  • It is not typically when the patches are first removed.
  • The patches are usually removed at 48 hours, and the skin is then inspected for any reactions.

 

Option D. 96 hours

 

  • This is a common time for a follow-up reading and not the initial removal of the patches.
  • Some protocols suggest readings at this time to ensure that late-appearing reactions are not missed.

 

The image below shows a patch test:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref- Rooks textbook of dermatology - 9th Edition volume I Chapter 4 page no 4.23

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page no 406

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3900336/

questions.text: A lesion of the structure marked in the image below cause?(AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Contralateral hemiplegia

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked in the image is the pyramid containing the pyramidal tracts. A lesion here leads to contralateral hemiplegia.

 

This is because the fibers of these tracts decussate (cross over) in the medulla oblongata. Thus, an injury to the pyramidal tract on one side of the brain or upper spinal cord will affect motor function on the opposite side of the body.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ataxia: Ataxia refers to uncoordinated movement and is typically related to damage to the cerebellum or sensory pathways, not the pyramidal tracts. The cerebellum plays a crucial role in fine-tuning motor movements and ensuring coordination. So, an injury to the pyramidal tracts does not typically result in ataxia.

 

Option C. Tinnitus: Tinnitus is the perception of noise or ringing in the ears. It's a symptom of an underlying condition, such as age-related hearing loss, ear injury, or a circulatory system disorder. Injury to the pyramidal tracts would not lead to tinnitus, as they are primarily motor tracts and not involved in auditory processing or function.

 

Option D. Ipsilateral facial palsy: Facial palsy refers to weakness or paralysis of the muscles on one side of the face. It is most commonly associated with damage to the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). While the pyramidal tracts do play a role in voluntary facial movements, a direct injury to these tracts would not typically lead to ipsilateral facial palsy. Furthermore, facial movements are controlled by both sides of the brain, so an isolated pyramidal tract lesion might not manifest as overt facial weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pyramids in the medulla oblongata, containing the pyramidal tracts, are crucial for voluntary motor control. A lesion here can lead to contralateral hemiplegia due to the crossing over of these tracts within the medulla. This understanding is essential for diagnosing and understanding the implications of brainstem injuries, especially in the context of stroke or other neurological disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded New Ballard score? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Scarf sign

 

The extended new Ballard score has a component of scarf sign which is a component of the neuromuscular maturity. The New Ballard Score is an extended to include extremely pre-term babies i.e. up to 20 weeks.

 

The scoring relies on the intra-uterine changes that the fetus undergoes during its maturation. Whereas the neurological criteria depend mainly upon muscle tone, the physical ones rely on anatomical changes. The neonate (less than 37 weeks of age) is in a state of physiological hypotonia. This tone increases throughout the fetal growth period, meaning a more premature baby would have lesser muscle tone.

 

Scarf sign: If the infant's arm is pulled medially across the chest (as shown in the image below)

 

 

  • In a hypotonic infant, the elbow will cross the midline.
  • In a term infant with a normal tone, the elbow will not reach the midline.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heel-knee test: Heel to knee test is not a part of ballard score

 

Option B. Finger-nose test: Finger to nose test is done to assess the cerebellar function.

 

Option D. Cubital angle: The cubital angle, also known as the carrying angle, is measured during the Services Selection Board (SSB) testing process. This has no role in ballard score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The extended new Ballard score has a component of scarf sign which is a component of the neuromuscular maturity

questions.text:
Match the following:

 

Column A:

1. Drugs of Abuse

2. On Prescription-only drugs

3. Hormones

4. Antibiotics

 

Column B:
a. Schedule H
b. Schedule G
c. Schedule L
d. Schedule X
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-d, 2-a, 3-b, 4-c

 

1. Drugs of Abuse – d. Schedule X: These include substances with a high potential for abuse and dependency, like narcotics and psychotropic drugs. Special precautions are necessary for storage and prescription.

 

2. On Prescription-only Drugs – a. Schedule H: Medications that require a prescription from a Registered Medical Practitioner. These drugs are labeled with a warning and include barbiturates, amphetamines, and sulphonamides.

 

3. Hormones – b. Schedule G: Schedule G drugs contain hormones or other potent agents that need careful use under medical guidance. Labels include the caution: “Dangerous to take without medical supervision.”

 

4. Antibiotics – c. Schedule L: Antibiotics and certain chemotherapeutics are listed under Schedule L. They are also regulated for hospital and medical institution distribution.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Drug Schedules and Associated Categories:

 

  1. Schedule C: Encompasses biological products, including items like sera and vaccines.
  2. Schedule E: Specifies toxic substances used in traditional medicine practices, such as Ayurveda, Siddha, and Unani.
  3. Schedule G: Covers drugs that are potent and require careful medical oversight, including hormone preparations, antihistamines, and certain anticancer medications.
  4. Schedule H: Represents prescription-only medications that must display a warning label indicating they are to be sold only with a registered medical practitioner's prescription. This category includes barbiturates, amphetamines, and sulfonamides.
  5. Schedule J: Lists medications that should not be promoted for treating diseases deemed incurable, such as cancer, cataracts, appendicitis, epilepsy, and others.
  6. Schedule L: Pertains to antibiotics and chemotherapeutic agents that are regulated similarly to Schedule H drugs, often for use in hospitals and healthcare facilities.
  7. Schedule X: Involves substances that carry a high risk of abuse and dependency, requiring strict regulation and control.

questions.text: Which of the following colored cannula will you use to achieve maximum flow rate in a patient who needs a large amount of fluids?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Grey

 

The grey-colored intravenous cannula, which is 16G, allows a flow rate of 236 ml/min, making it highly suitable for administering large volumes of fluids quickly. It is commonly used in cases such as trauma, major surgery, gastrointestinal bleeding, and situations requiring rapid blood transfusions or fluid replacement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Green (18G): The green cannula has a flow rate of 103 ml/min. It is used for blood product transfusions, delivery of irritant medications, and major surgeries, but it is less efficient for rapid fluid administration compared to the grey cannula.

 

Option C. Blue (22G): The blue cannula has a flow rate of 42 ml/min and is suitable for use in small or fragile veins and for cytotoxic therapy. It is not appropriate for situations requiring a large fluid volume due to its significantly lower flow rate.

 

Option D. Pink (20G): The pink cannula, with a flow rate of 67 ml/min, is used for general IV maintenance, antibiotics, and analgesics. Its flow rate is not adequate for high-volume fluid administration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For rapid fluid administration, especially in emergencies or trauma cases, a grey (16G) or orange (14G) cannula should be used to ensure a high flow rate.

questions.text: Which of these options is not a causal factor for head and neck malignancies? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin A deficiency

 

Vitamin A deficiency is not recognized as a direct risk factor for head and neck malignancies. While vitamin A plays crucial roles in maintaining epithelial tissues and immune function, its deficiency primarily leads to issues like night blindness and immune deficiencies, rather than directly causing cancers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus) infection: EBV is associated with various types of cancers, including nasopharyngeal carcinoma. It is a well-established risk factor for this specific type of head and neck cancer.

 

Option B. HPV (Human Papillomavirus) infection: HPV, particularly type 16, is a significant risk factor for oropharyngeal cancers. The virus can lead to cellular transformations that result in malignancy.

 

Option Betel nut: Consumption of betel nut, often part of a "paan" or betel quid, is a known risk factor for oral cancers, particularly in the gingivobuccal sulcus, common in regions where it is a cultural practice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The common risk factors known to cause head and neck malignancies includes:

 

  1. Alcohol use
  2. Tobacco use (smoking or chewing)
  3. Viruses
    1. HPV 16 - oropharyngeal cancer
    2. EBV – Nasopharyngeal cancer
  4. Paan (betel quid) – Oral cancers especially in gingivobuccal sulcus
  5. Preserved or salted food consumption - nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  6. Occupational exposure:
    1. Exposure to wood or nickel dust or formaldehyde - a risk factor for cancers of the paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity
    2. Radiation exposure is a risk factor for salivary gland tumors, thyroid gland carcinoma

questions.text:
Chlorpromazine is an antipsychotic drug. It also produces sedation and adverse effects like dry mouth and hypotension. All these actions result due to action on which of the following receptors?(INICET MAY 2024)

 

1. D2 and 5HT2 receptors

2. GABA and Beta-adrenergic receptors

3. Muscarinic and alpha-adrenergic receptors

4. H1 receptors
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 3 and 4 are correct

 

Chlorpromazine is a typical anti-psychotic drug having main mechanism of antipsychotic action as D2 blockade and minor as 5 HT2 blockade. However, it also blocks many other receptors that can result in adverse effects.

 

While chlorpromazine does block H1 receptors causing sedation, it is not the sole receptor responsible for its adverse effects. It must be considered in conjunction with D2, 5HT2, muscarinic, and alpha-adrenergic receptors.

 

Other Option:

 

2. GABA and Beta-adrenergic Receptors: Chlorpromazine does not primarily act on GABA or beta-adrenergic receptors, hence this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Actions of anti-psychotic drugs

 

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/470-471

choices.text: Epithelial cell with bacteria attached on cell surface
﻿﻿﻿Bacteria engulfed by macrophages
﻿﻿﻿Neutrophil engulfed bacteria
﻿﻿﻿Bacteria arranged in clusters

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with a history of profuse vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odour. Which of the following best describes the microscopic finding given below?  (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epithelial cell with bacteria attached on cell surface

 

The microscopic finding described is consistent with "clue cells," which are a hallmark of bacterial vaginosis (BV). Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells that are covered with a stippled appearance due to bacteria adhering to their surface. This attachment creates a poorly defined border on the cell. Clue cells are significant in diagnosing bacterial vaginosis because they are a reliable indicator of this condition. For a diagnosis of BV, at least 20 percent of epithelial cells in a wet mount preparation should appear as clue cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bacteria engulfed by macrophages: This finding is more indicative of an inflammatory response and is not characteristic of bacterial vaginosis. It is more commonly associated with other types of infections or inflammatory conditions.

 

Option C. Neutrophil engulfed bacteria: This description is associated with acute bacterial infections or inflammation but not with bacterial vaginosis, where clue cells are the key finding.

 

Option D. Bacteria arranged in clusters: While bacteria may be present in clusters in some infections, this description does not specifically identify the clue cells characteristic of bacterial vaginosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clue cells, which are epithelial cells with bacteria attached on their surface, are the most reliable microscopic indicator of bacterial vaginosis.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A hospital has reported an outbreak of MRSA infection. On investigation, it was found out that a staff nurse had nasal carriage of MRSA. Which of the following drugs helps in the removal of colonization of bacteria? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Topical mupirocin

 

Topical mupirocin is the preferred agent for the elimination of nasal carriers of MRSA.

 

Decolonization therapy is the administration of antimicrobial or antiseptic agents to eradicate or suppress MRSA carriage:

 

  • Intranasal antibiotic or antiseptic (e.g., mupirocin, povidone-iodine)
  • Topical antiseptic (e.g., chlorhexidine)
  • +/- Systemic antibiotics

 

MRSA decolonization has been associated with reduction in MRSA carriage, transmission and infection.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral vancomycin: While effective against MRSA, oral vancomycin is not used for nasal decolonization. It is primarily used for treating severe systemic MRSA infections and Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea.

 

Option B. Inj cephalosporin: Cephalosporins are a class of antibiotics that are generally ineffective against MRSA due to resistance mechanisms. They are not used for MRSA nasal decolonization.

 

Option D. Inhaled colistin: Colistin is an antibiotic used for treating multidrug-resistant Gram-negative infections, particularly in the lungs. It is not used for nasal decolonization of MRSA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Topical mupirocin is the recommended treatment for the nasal decolonization of MRSA, effectively reducing the nasal carriage of the bacteria and thereby decreasing the risk of transmission and subsequent infections.

questions.text: The catalytic efficiency of enzyme is best expressed by which of the following kinetic constants? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Kcat/Km

 

The catalytic efficiency is the ratio of Kcat/Km.

 

Kcat is the first-order rate constant that determines the reaction rate when the enzyme is fully occupied at a saturating concentration of the substrate.

 

The Michaelis constant (Km), defined as the concentration of substrate that is transported at half the maximal velocity (Vmax) of transport, is a measure of the affinity of the transporter for its substrate.

 

Decreasing the catalytic efficiency or the quantity of the catalyst for the "bottleneck" or rate-limiting reaction therefore reduces metabolite flux through the entire pathway. Conversely, an increase in either its quantity or catalytic efficiency enhances flux through the pathway as a whole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The catalytic efficiency of an enzyme is best expressed by the ratio Kcat/Km, as it provides a measure of how effectively the enzyme converts substrate into product, considering both the enzyme's turnover rate and its substrate affinity.

questions.text: Mw vaccine is extracted from which of the following bacteria? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) M. indicus pranii

 

Mw vaccine is extracted from M. indicus pranii

 

The Mycobacterium w (M.w) vaccine is a heat-killed suspension derived from a non-pathogenic mycobacterium: mycobacterium indicus pranii. As an immunotherapy, M.w is used against leprosy; the compound also shares antigens with M. tuberculosis. Its use has shown clinical improvement, rapid bacterial clearance, and enhanced immune responses to Mycobacterium leprae antigens.

 

Administration: 0.1 ml intradermal. It is divided into two equal doses and given on both arms. Booster doses are injected only on one arm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. M. welchii: This bacterium is known for causing gas gangrene and is not associated with the Mw vaccine.

 

Option C. M. leprae: This bacterium is the causative agent of leprosy, but the Mw vaccine is not derived from M. leprae itself.

 

Option D. M. bovis: This bacterium causes tuberculosis in cattle and can also infect humans, but it is not the source of the Mw vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mw vaccine is extracted from Mycobacterium indicus pranii and is used in the immunotherapy of leprosy, enhancing immune responses and promoting rapid bacterial clearance.

questions.text: Identify the following post-mortem change. (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Suggillation

 

The image shows post mortem staining on the back, also called suggillation. Post-mortem staining (PMS) is the settling of the blood in the dependent portions of the body after death due to loss of circulation, causing a purplish-red discoloration of the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tattooing: Tattoos appear as distinct, well-defined patterns or designs, often in various colors. Tattoos can be located anywhere on the body and are not necessarily confined to dependent areas. They are typically intentional markings made by injecting ink into the skin.

 

Option C. Putrefaction: The body becomes greenish in colour in putrefaction. Later it becomes blackish.

 

Option D. Decomposition: Same explanation as that of putrefaction

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post Mortem Staining (PMS)

 

  •  It is the settling of the blood in the dependent, portion of the body after death due to loss of circulation, causing a purplish red discoloration of the skin.
  • Other names of PMS are:
    • Hypostasis
    • livor mortis
    • Vibices
    • Suggillation
    • Postmortem Lividity
    • Cadaveric lividity
    • Darkening of death
  •  It is present on dependent areas, but absent on pressure areas as the blood vessels get compressed. In a supine body the pressure areas are back of chest, buttocks etc as these are in the direct contact with ground.

questions.text: Which of the following finger has two dorsal interossei muscles? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Middle finger

 

Explanation:

 

The middle finger has two dorsal interossei muscles flanking it. One is positioned between the index and middle fingers, and the other is positioned between the middle and ring fingers.

 

This anatomical configuration allows the middle finger to be abducted in both directions: towards the index finger and towards the ring finger.

 

 

The dorsal interossei muscles are four bipennate muscles located between the metacarpal bones in the hand. They are named "dorsal" because they are located on the dorsum (back) of the hand, and "interossei" means between bones. Their main action is to abduct the fingers away from the axial line, which runs down the center of the third (middle) finger.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Index finger: This finger has one dorsal interosseous muscle which abducts the index finger away from the middle finger.

 

Option B. Little finger: The little finger also has one dorsal interosseous muscle. This muscle abducts the little finger away from the ring finger.

 

Option D. Ring finger: The ring finger has one dorsal interosseous muscle which abducts it away from the little finger.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Chimeric DNA is used for? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Organ transplantation

 

Chimeric DNA (also known a recombinant DNA) is used in organ transplantation, especially in bone marrow transplant. It allows for the production of essential therapeutic proteins and other biological products.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paternity test:

  • Function: Uses genetic markers to determine biological parentage.
  • Relevance: Typically uses DNA fingerprinting rather than chimeric DNA technology.

 

Option B. Maternity test:

  • Function: Similar to paternity testing, using genetic markers for parentage.
  • Relevance: Uses DNA fingerprinting, not chimeric DNA.

 

Option C. Personal identification:

  • Function: Uses DNA profiling for forensic and legal identification.
  • Relevance: DNA fingerprinting and STR analysis are common methods, not chimeric DNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uses of Chimeric DNA are:

 

  1. Recombinant human insulin
  2. Recombinant human growth hormone (HGH, somatotropin) and other human hormones (e.g. FSH)
  3. Recombinant blood clotting factor VIII and other clotting factors (Factor IX, tPA, hirudin)
  4. Recombinant hepatitis B vaccine, HPV vaccine, etc.
  5. Cytokines and growth factors (interferon, interleukins, etc.)
  6. Monoclonal antibodies and other related products (rituximab, trastuzumab, etc.)
  7. Recombinant enzymes (acid α glucosidase [myozyme], α L iduronidase [aldurazyme])
  8. Recombinant HIV protein for HIV ELISA testing
  9. Herbicide and insect resistant crops
  10. Other products: Bone morphogenic protein (BMP), albumin, fibinolytic and thrombolytic agents, etc.
  11. Gene mapping using techniques such as fluorescence in sit hybridization (FISH).
  12. Molecular analysis of disease, to detect gene variations and mutations.
  13. Restriction Fragment Length polymorphism (RFLP) and single nucleotide polymorphism (SN)
  14. Microsatellite DNA polymorphisms
  15. Gene therapy and bone marrow transplantation

questions.text:
Aspirin and phenobarbitone are acidic drugs whereas diazepam is a basic drug. Which of the following statement/s about these drugs is/are true?(AIIMS MAY 2019)

 

  1. Aspirin is present mainly in non-ionized form in stomach, hence can be easily absorbed
  2. Diazepam is mostly absorbed form intestine
  3. Phenobarbitone can be absorbed from stomach but most of the absorption occurs in small intestine due to its large surface area
  4. No drug is absorbed in large intestine due to its very low surface area
  5. Diseases decreasing the transit time of drugs like diarrhea will increase the drug absorption in small intestine
questions.solution:
Ans. A. a, b and c

 

Absorption across any membrane depends on lipid solubility. Non-ionized form of drugs is lipid soluble and can easily cross the membranes.

 

 

So, basic drugs like diazepam are absorbed maximally from intestine (option b).

 

  • Acidic drugs although are mainly non-ionized in stomach but are absorbed very less because the gastric emptying time is very small. So, these are quickly transferred to intestine. These become ionized in intestine due to alkaline medium. However, due to their longer time of stay in intestine and very large surface area as compared to stomach even the small amount of their non-ionised form contributes to significant absorption. So, practically every drug (whether acidic or basic) are absorbed more in intestine as compared to stomach. 
  • Aspirin (acidic drug) – It is non-ionised in stomach and hence easily absorbed.
  • Diazepam (basic drug)- It is non-ionised in intestine, hence easily absorbed.
  • Phenobarbitone (acidic drug)- Any drug is maximally absorbed in intestine due to large surface area of intestine.
  • Surface area of large intestine is large, so statement (d) is wrong.
  • Diarrhea decreases the transit time of drug, hence decreases the absorption as the time available for absorption decreases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option D. This statement is incorrect. The large intestine does have a considerable surface area and can absorb drugs, although to a lesser extent compared to the small intestine.

 

Option E. This statement is also incorrect. Diseases that decrease the transit time, such as diarrhea, reduce the absorption of drugs because the time available for absorption is decreased.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-ionized forms of drugs are more lipid-soluble and can cross membranes more easily. Acidic drugs like aspirin and phenobarbitone are primarily non-ionized in the stomach but are absorbed mainly in the intestine due to its large surface area. Basic drugs like diazepam are absorbed maximally from the intestine.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/20-21

choices.text: Cells in lateral geniculate body

questions.text: Which is the first-order neuron in the optic pathway? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rods and cones

 

  • The rods and cones act as the first-order neurons They give the signals to the bipolar cells act as second order neurons in the optic pathway. They serve as an intermediate link between the photoreceptor cells and the ganglion cells (option B), which are the third-order neurons.
  • The electrical signals from the bipolar cells are further transmitted to the ganglion cells. The axons of ganglion cells form the optic nerve, which carries visual information from the retina to the visual processing centers in the brain.
  • The optic nerve fibers project to different regions of the brain, including the lateral geniculate body (option C), which is part of the thalamus and is involved in visual processing. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Ganglion cells: Incorrect. Ganglion cells are the third-order neurons in the optic pathway.

 

Option C. Cells in lateral geniculate body: Incorrect. These cells are involved in the later stages of visual processing and are not first-order neurons.

 

Option D. Bipolar cells: Incorrect. Bipolar cells are the second-order neurons in the optic pathway.

 

Educational Objective

 

In the optic pathway, the first-order neurons are the photoreceptor cells, specifically rods and cones, which convert light into electrical signals. These signals are then relayed through bipolar cells to ganglion cells, whose axons form the optic nerve, ultimately transmitting visual information to the brain.

questions.text: Which hormone crosses the plasma membrane for its action? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroxine

 

Thyroxine crosses the plasma membrane for its action.

 

The thyroid hormone receptors are either attached to the DNA genetic strands or located in proximity to them. The thyroid hormone receptor usually forms a heterodimer with retinoid X receptor (RXR) at specific thyroid hormone response elements on the DNA. On binding with thyroid hormone, the receptors become activated and initiate the transcription process. Then large numbers of different types of messenger RNA are formed, followed within another few minutes or hours by RNA translation on the cytoplasmic ribosomes to form hundreds of new intracellular proteins.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Epinephrine: Incorrect. Epinephrine is a catecholamine that acts on cell surface receptors (adrenergic receptors) and does not cross the plasma membrane to exert its effects.

 

Option C. Glucagon: Incorrect. Glucagon is a peptide hormone that binds to receptors on the cell surface and does not cross the plasma membrane.

 

Option D. Insulin: Incorrect. Insulin is a peptide hormone that binds to its receptor on the cell surface and does not cross the plasma membrane.

 

Educational objective

 

Thyroxine (T4) crosses the plasma membrane and binds to intracellular receptors to exert its effects, initiating transcription and subsequent protein synthesis.

questions.text: A bank employee, felt depressed with no interest in activities, came to AIIMS OPD. He was started on escitalopram. Which of these adverse effects cannot be explained with escitalopram? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sialorrhea

 

Sialorrhea, or excessive saliva production, is not a common side effect of SSRIs like escitalopram. It is more commonly associated with the atypical antipsychotic drug clozapine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anorgasmia: Anorgasmia, or difficulty achieving orgasm, is a well-known side effect of SSRIs due to their impact on serotonin levels, which can interfere with sexual function.

 

Option C. Nausea: Nausea is one of the most common side effects of SSRIs. It typically occurs at the beginning of treatment and may subside with continued use.

 

Option D. Vivid dreams: Vivid dreams are another common side effect of SSRIs. They occur due to the influence of increased serotonin levels on sleep patterns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Escitalopram is a Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor (SSRI).
  • Other SSRIs include Fluoxetine, Paroxetine, Fluvoxamine etc.
  • Side-effects of SSRI include:
  • Most common: Nausea, Vomiting
  • Next most common: Anxiety etc.
  • Other side effects- Delayed ejaculation, anorgasmia, diarrhea, vivid dreams etc.
  • Main drug which causes sialorrhea is CLOZAPINE (an atypical anti-psychotic drug)

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/488

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with developmental delay, can ride a tricycle, can climb upstairs with alternate feet, can say the name, knows own sex, but cannot narrate a story. What is the developmental age? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 years

 

The developmental age is 3 years.

 

Based on the developmental milestones provided, the child's age can be estimated to be around 3 years old. The child is able to ride a tricycle and climb stairs with alternate feet, which are typical milestones for a 3-year-old child. Additionally, the child is able to say their own name and identify their own sex, which are typical milestones for a 2 to 3-year-old child. However, the child is not able to narrate a story, which is a milestone typically seen in 4 to 5-year-old children. Therefore, overall, the child's developmental age is estimated to be around 3 years old.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 4 years: A child can narrate stories by 4 years

 

Option C. 5 years: By 5 years child can ask meaning of words

 

Option D. 2 years: 2 years cannot tell his full name, age and sex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A child's developmental age can be estimated by comparing their abilities to typical developmental milestones; in this case, a child who can ride a tricycle and climb stairs with alternating feet is likely around 3 years old.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason is the correct explanation for Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason is not the correct explanation for Assertion.
Assertion is true, but Reason is false.
Assertion is false, but Reason is true.

questions.text:
Assertion: Sacubitril/Valsartan is indicated in the treatment of NYHA class II to IV in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.

 

Reason: Sacubitril/Valsartan is an angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI) counteracts RAAS system and raises the level of vasoactive peptaaides.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason is the correct explanation for Assertion.

 

Sacubitril/Valsartan, marketed as Entresto, is a combination medication classified as an angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI). It is specifically indicated for the treatment of patients with chronic heart failure classified as NYHA class II to IV with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). This combination therapy has been shown to reduce the risk of cardiovascular death and hospitalization for heart failure in adult patients with chronic heart failure. 

 

The mechanism of action involves dual inhibition:

 

  1. Neprilysin Inhibition: Sacubitril inhibits neprilysin, an enzyme responsible for degrading vasoactive peptides such as natriuretic peptides, bradykinin, and adrenomedullin. By inhibiting neprilysin, sacubitril increases the levels of these peptides, leading to vasodilation, natriuresis, and diuresis, which collectively reduce the workload on the heart. 
  2. Angiotensin II Receptor Blockade: Valsartan blocks the angiotensin II type-1 (AT1) receptor, thereby inhibiting the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). This blockade results in vasodilation and a reduction in the release of aldosterone, which decreases sodium and water retention, further alleviating stress on the cardiovascular system. 

 

The combination of these mechanisms addresses both the detrimental effects of RAAS activation and enhances the beneficial effects of increased vasoactive peptides, providing a comprehensive approach to managing heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sacubitril/Valsartan is an angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI) indicated for treating NYHA class II to IV heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, functioning by inhibiting the RAAS and increasing levels of beneficial vasoactive peptides.

questions.text: All of the following characteristics are found in the pleural effusion fluid of a rheumatoid arthritis patient except: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High Glucose

 

Rheumatoid pleural effusion, associated with rheumatoid arthritis, typically presents with low glucose levels, making high glucose the correct answer as it is not a characteristic found in such effusions. The low glucose in rheumatoid pleural effusion is due to increased metabolic activity of leukocytes and pleural cells which consume glucose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RA factor: The presence of RA factor (Rheumatoid factor) in pleural fluid is commonly seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid factor is an autoantibody found in the blood of approximately 80% of adults with rheumatoid arthritis. Its presence in pleural fluid reflects the systemic inflammatory nature of the disease.

 

Option B. Cholesterol crystals: Cholesterol crystals in the pleural fluid are indicative of a long-standing effusion, which can occur in chronic rheumatoid pleuritis. These crystals form as the pleural fluid becomes more concentrated over time due to the chronic nature of the inflammation.

 

Option D. High LDH: High levels of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) in the pleural fluid are a common feature of exudative effusions, including those caused by rheumatoid arthritis. LDH is an enzyme present in most cells and is released into the pleural fluid when cells are damaged or destroyed, reflecting the inflammatory processes occurring in rheumatoid pleuritis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The best way to manage the wound shown in the image is: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cleaning and dressing

 

The image shows an abrasion. Since it is going to heal with primary intention, no grafting is required.

 

  • Cleaning the wound involves gently removing any debris, foreign material, or contaminants from the wound site. This step helps prevent infection and promotes a healthy healing environment.
  • Dressing the wound involves covering it with a sterile bandage or dressing. Dressings help maintain a moist environment, protect the wound from further contamination, and provide a barrier against external factors.

 

In many cases, initial wound management involves cleaning the wound to prevent infection and applying a sterile dressing. This basic approach is suitable for wounds that are not deeply contaminated, do not require extensive tissue removal (debridement), and do not necessitate advanced interventions like grafting (skin graft or allograft). It provides a clean and protected environment for natural healing to occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Debridement and dressing: Debridement involves the removal of dead or contaminated tissue from the wound, which may be necessary in cases of severe infection or tissue damage. After debridement, the wound is dressed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Here are some general principles for the management of a superficial abrasion:

 

  1. Clean the wound: Gently clean the wound with soap and warm water to remove any dirt or debris. Use a clean cloth or sterile gauze to pat the wound dry.
  2. Apply a dressing: Cover the abrasion with a sterile dressing or adhesive bandage to keep it clean and protected. Change the dressing daily or more often if it becomes wet or dirty.
  3. Manage pain: Over-the-counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen can help relieve pain and reduce inflammation.
  4. Watch for signs of infection: Keep an eye on the abrasion for signs of infection such as redness, swelling, pus, or increasing pain.
  5. Follow up: Depending on the severity of the abrasion, you may need to follow up with a healthcare provider for further evaluation and treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following does not present with maculopapular rash? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zoster (shingles)

 

A maculopapular rash is not seen in zoster (shingles).

 

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution as shown in the image below.

 

 

Herpes zoster:

 

  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  1. Painful zoster infections in adults
  2. Facial zoster at any age
  3. Immunocompromised

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rubella: Presents with a maculopapular rash as shown in the image below, which consists of minute, discrete macules.

 

 

  • The rash appears within 24 hours of onset of prodromal symptoms.

 

Option C. Dengue (during febrile phase): Dengue fever can present with a maculopapular rash during its febrile phase.

 

Option D. Measles: Measles is characterized by fever and a maculopapular skin rash, which is accompanied by immune clearance of measles virus (MV)-infected cells

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zoster (shingles) does not present with a maculopapular rash but rather with a painful, vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution. In contrast, rubella, dengue during the febrile phase, and measles are classic causes of maculopapular rashes.
 

 

Ref- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no. 25.27-25.28
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106
Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 4.13

questions.text: Which of the following shows functional assessment of B1 deficiency? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. RBC Transketolase

 

In thiamine deficiency, erythrocyte transketolase activity is reduced; this is the earliest manifestation seen even before clinical disturbances. Addition of thiamine diphosphate in vitro to erythrocyte lysate resulting in activation of apo transketolase is suggestive of B1 deficiency.

 

Thiamine contains a substituted pyrimidine ring connected to a substituted thiazole ring by means of methylene bridge. The vitamin is then converted to its active co-enzyme form by addition of two phosphate groups, with the help of ATP. It is catalyzed by thiamine pyrophosphotransferase.

 

Physiological Role of Thiamine

 

  1. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: The co-enzyme form is thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP). It is used in oxidative decarboxylation of alpha keto acids, e.g. pyruvate dehydrogenase catalyzes the breakdown of pyruvate, to acetyl CoA, and carbon dioxide
  2. Alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase: An analogous biochemical reaction that requires TPP is the oxidative decarboxylation of alpha ketoglutarate to succinyl CoA and CO2
  3. Transketolase: The second group of enzymes that use TPP as co-enzyme are the transketolases, in the hexose monophosphate shunt pathway of glucose
  4. The main role of thiamine (TPP) is in carbohydrate metabolism. So, the requirement of thiamine is increased along with higher intake of carbohydrates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RBC Glutathione Reductase:

  • Function: Measures the activity of riboflavin (Vitamin B2).
  • Relevance: Used to assess riboflavin deficiency, not thiamine deficiency.

 

Option C. Serum Thiamine Levels:

  • Function: Direct measurement of thiamine in the blood.
  • Relevance: While it can indicate thiamine levels, it is less specific than functional assays like erythrocyte transketolase activity for assessing functional deficiency.

 

Option D. RBC Glutathione Peroxidase:

  • Function: Measures the activity of selenium and glutathione metabolism.
  • Relevance: Used to assess selenium status, not thiamine deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: For cutting ribs in thoracic surgery
For smoothening of edges in amputation surgery
To remove fibrous tissue from non-union site

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is used for:(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Used as a bone nibbler

 

BONE NIBBLER

 

  • Bone Nibbler/Bone Rongeurs are like pliers with a heavy, pointed jaw.
  • With their heavy construction, bone nibblers are used for gnawing holes in bones during Orthopedic surgery.
  • The scoop-shaped tip of the rongeur is used for gouging the bone.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. For cutting ribs in thoracic surgery. Rib Shears are surgical instruments used in cardiothoracic surgeries to cut bones, especially ribs. They absorb the shock of the cut and provide an atraumatic experience. 

 

 

Option B. For smoothening of edges in amputation surgery. Putti Bone Rasp is used for orthopedic surgeries that require mild reshaping and handling of bones. It is a double-ended instrument used for debriding and smoothing the bone edges after the amputation surgery.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

The image shown in the question is of a bone nibbler which is used to gnaw holes in the bones during the surgery.

questions.text: All of the following are the core clinical features for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Orthostatic hypotension.

 

Lewy body dementia (LBD), also known as dementia with Lewy bodies, is characterized by specific core clinical features. Orthostatic hypotension, while commonly observed in LBD due to autonomic dysfunction, is not classified as a core clinical feature but rather as a supportive feature for diagnosis.

 

Central feature: Dementia (Essential for the diagnosis of DLB).

 

Core Clinical criteria include the following:

 

  1. Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness.
  2. Recurrent visual hallucinations that are typically well formed and detailed.
  3. Rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder (RBD).
  4. Spontaneous cardinal features of parkinsonism.

 

Supportive Features of LBD:

 

  • Autonomic Dysfunction: Including orthostatic hypotension.
  • Severe Sensitivity to Antipsychotic Drugs: Patients may experience severe motor and neuroleptic sensitivity.
  • Other Hallucinations and Neurological Signs: Can include auditory hallucinations or transient, unexplained loss of consciousness.

 

Onset of dementia preceding or within 1 year of onset of parkinsonism differentiates Lewy Body dementia from Parkinson's disease with dementia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluctuating cognition: Fluctuating cognition is one of the hallmark symptoms of LBD, characterized by significant variations in attention and alertness. This fluctuation is more pronounced than what is typically seen in other forms of dementia, such as Alzheimer's disease, and can vary from hour to hour or day to day.

 

Option B. REM sleep behavior disorder: REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD) is a core feature of LBD, where patients physically act out their dreams, often vividly. This disorder is a result of the loss of normal muscle atonia that should occur during REM sleep, leading to potentially violent movements and vocalizations during sleep.

 

Option C. Recurrent visual hallucinations: Visual hallucinations in LBD are typically well-formed and detailed, often involving people or animals. These hallucinations are a core feature and differ from the more nebulous or less structured hallucinations seen in other disorders. They are thought to be due to the underlying Lewy body pathology affecting cortical brain areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orthostatic hypotension is a supportive, not core, criterion for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia.

 

Reference - Harrison 21e/Neurology, DLB Chapter 434 /12305.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child with ambiguous genitalia presented to the hospital, his BP is 88/68 mm Hg, Serum K+ is 6 mEq/L, serum sodium is 120 mEq/L. Patient was started on intravenous fluids. What additional specific therapy will you add?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hydrocortisone

 

The presentation of an 18-month-old child with ambiguous genitalia, hypertension (BP is 88/68 mm Hg, which is low for this age), hyperkalemia (serum K of 6 mEq/L), and hyponatremia (serum sodium of 120 mEq/L) is suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), most likely due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. This is a common form of CAH and can lead to a decrease in cortisol and aldosterone production, with an accompanying increase in adrenal androgens.

 

Given this clinical picture, the specific therapy to be added would include:

 

  1. Glucocorticoid Replacement: This is critical to suppress the overproduction of adrenal androgens. Hydrocortisone is commonly used, especially in pediatric patients, due to its short duration of action and lower impact on growth.

  2. Mineralocorticoid Replacement: Fludrocortisone is usually added to manage the aldosterone deficiency, which is contributing to the hyperkalemia and hyponatremia.

  3. Sodium Chloride Supplements: In some cases, especially in infants and young children, additional sodium chloride supplements may be necessary to manage hyponatremia.

  4. Monitoring and Adjustment: Regular monitoring of electrolytes, blood pressure, and growth is necessary to adjust therapy accordingly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Potassium Binding Resins: While these can be used to treat hyperkalemia, they do not address the underlying cause of the electrolyte imbalance in this scenario, which is likely due to aldosterone deficiency. Therefore, it would not be the first choice.

 

Option C. Digoxin: This is used primarily for heart failure and certain arrhythmias, not for the conditions described in this scenario.

 

Option D. Calcium Gluconate: This is used in the acute management of severe hyperkalemia to stabilize cardiac membranes. While it might be used in an emergency setting for life-threatening hyperkalemia, it does not address the underlying cause in this case and is not a long-term management strategy.

 

Therefore, the most appropriate addition to this patient's treatment regimen would be Hydrocortisone (option a), as it addresses the underlying cause of the symptoms in CAH. Additionally, monitoring and adjusting mineralocorticoid therapy (like fludrocortisone) would be important in the long-term management, especially given the electrolyte imbalances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most appropriate addition to this patient's treatment regimen would be Hydrocortisone, as it addresses the underlying cause of the symptoms in CAH. Additionally, monitoring and adjusting mineralocorticoid therapy (like fludrocortisone) would be important in the long-term management, especially given the electrolyte imbalances.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/314

choices.text: Dystrophic with increased serum calcium
Metastatic with increased serum calcium
Dystrophic with normal serum calcium

questions.text: A 58-year-old man died 24 hours after the onset of substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm. On autopsy, an atheromatous plaque was seen obstructing the left anterior descending artery. Which type of calcification is most likely to be seen in this condition? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dystrophic with normal serum calcium

 

Atheromatous plaques show dystrophic calcification in the presence of normal calcium levels in the serum.

 

The deposition of calcium in dead or dying tissues is called dystrophic calcification. Although it occurs in the presence of normal serum calcium, it can be worsened by hypercalcemia.

 

Dystrophic calcification is seen in areas of necrosis of any type -

 

Calcification in dead tissue –

 

  1. Caseous necrosis in tuberculosis is the most common site for dystrophic calcification.
  2. Liquefaction necrosis in chronic abscesses may get calcified.
  3. Fat necrosis following acute pancreatitis or traumatic fat necrosis in the breast results in deposition of calcium soaps.
  4. Gamma-Gandy bodies in chronic venous congestion (CVC. of the spleen is characterized by calcific deposits admixed with hemosiderin on fibrous tissue.
  5. Infarcts may sometimes undergo dystrophic calcification.
  6. Thrombi, especially in the veins, may produce phleboliths.
  7. Hematomas in the vicinity of bones may undergo dystrophic calcification.
  8. Dead parasites like in hydatid cyst, Schistosoma eggs, and cysticercosis are some of the examples showing dystrophic calcification.
  9. Calcification in breast cancer detected by mammography.
  10. Congenital toxoplasmosis involving the central nervous system visualized by calcification in the infant brain.

 

Calcification in degenerated tissues

 

  1. Dense old scars may undergo hyaline degeneration and subsequent calcification.
  2. Atheromatous in the aorta and coronaries frequently undergo calcification.
  3. Mönckeberg’s sclerosis shows calcification in the tunica media of muscular arteries in elderly people
  4. Stroma of tumors such as uterine fibroids, breast cancer, thyroid adenoma, goitre etc. show calcification.
  5. Some tumors show characteristic spherules of calcification called psammoma bodies or calcospherites such as in meningioma, papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary and papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.
  6. Cysts which have been present for a long time may show calcification of their walls e.g. epidermal and pilar cysts.
  7. Calcinosis cutis is a condition of unknown cause in which there are irregular nodular deposits of calcium salts in the skin and subcutaneous tissue.
  8. Senile degenerative changes may be accompanied by dystrophic calcification such as in costal cartilages, tracheal or bronchial cartilages, and pineal gland in the brain etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dystrophic with increased serum calcium: Dystrophic calcification typically occurs in the setting of normal serum calcium levels. While hypercalcemia can exacerbate dystrophic calcification, it is not a defining feature.

 

Option B. Metastatic with increased serum calcium: Metastatic calcification occurs when calcium salts are deposited in normal tissues as a result of hypercalcemia. This form of calcification is not associated with tissue injury or necrosis and typically affects tissues like the lungs, stomach, kidneys, and blood vessels under conditions of high serum calcium. It does not apply to the situation described, where calcification is occurring in damaged tissue with normal calcium levels.

 

Option D. Metastatic with normal serum calcium: This option is incorrect because metastatic calcification is always associated with hypercalcemia, not normal serum calcium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg no 83

questions.text: As a healthcare consultant in Uttar Pradesh working to improve maternal and child health outcomes, you need to address issues such as inadequate hygiene, lack of skilled staff, and outdated equipment in labor rooms of public health facilities. Which program should you recommend that is specifically designed to enhance the quality of labor rooms? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) LAQSHYA

 

LAQSHYA [Labour Room Quality Improvement Initiative] 

 

  • MoHFW launched LaQshya to improve the quality of care that is being provided to the pregnant mother in the Labor Room and Maternity Operation Theaters, thereby preventing the undesirable adverse outcomes associated with childbirth
  • Aim: To reduce Maternal and newborn mortality & morbidity and stillbirths
  • Coverage: Govt Medical colleges & hospitals/District hospitals/FRU > 100 deliveries/month, High load CHC (>60 deliveries/month)

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ayushman Bharat: This is a broader health insurance scheme aimed at providing health cover to underprivileged families, not specifically focused on improving labor room conditions.

 

Option C. Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram: Although this program provides free benefits to pregnant women and sick infants, it does not specifically target the improvement of labor room conditions.

 

Option D. Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan: This initiative is aimed at providing assured, comprehensive, and quality antenatal care, free of cost, to pregnant women on the 9th of every month but does not specifically address labor room quality improvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recommending the LAQSHYA program is directly aligned with the need to overhaul the quality of labor rooms in public health facilities, targeting specific improvements in infrastructure, hygiene, and staff competencies to ensure safer childbirth experiences.

questions.text:
Match the following with regards to cellular inclusions: 

 

Column-A

1. Howell-Jolly bodies

2. Dohle bodies

3. Flame cells

4. Auer rod cells

 

Column-B

a. Ig inclusions

b. Azurophilic granules

c. Nuclear material remnants

d. Remnants of ER
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 → c, 2 → d, 3 → a, 4 → b

 

1. Howell-Jolly bodies → Nuclear material remnants (c): Howell-Jolly bodies are remnants of nuclear material within red blood cells, seen in cases of asplenia or when the spleen's filtering function is impaired.

 

 

2. Dohle bodies → Remnants of ER (d): Döhle bodies are blue inclusions in neutrophils, representing remnants of the endoplasmic reticulum. They appear in conditions like sepsis and severe inflammatory states.

 

 

3. Flame cells → Ig inclusions (a): Flame cells are plasma cells with red-staining cytoplasm due to immunoglobulin accumulation, seen in certain plasma cell disorders.

 

 

4. Auer rod cells → Azurophilic granules (b): Auer rods are azurophilic, rod-like structures found in the cytoplasm of myeloblasts, characteristic of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Howell-Jolly bodies: Nuclear remnants in RBCs, indicating asplenia.
  • Dohle bodies: Remnants of ER, seen in neutrophils during severe inflammation.
  • Flame cells: Plasma cells with Ig inclusions.
  • Auer rods: Azurophilic granules in myeloblasts, seen in AML.

questions.text: A 75-year-old female had a fall and had intertrochanteric fracture. This is due to:(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Osteoporosis

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology of Osteoporosis:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.
    • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate

 

 

Codfish Vertebrae (Osteoporosis/Osteomalacia)

 

Note: Intertrochanteric hip fractures are the most commonly occurring fractures in the elderly osteoporotic population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Osteopetrosis. This disease is commonly seen in children. It is a diaphyseal dysplasia characterized by failure of bone resorption due to functional deficiency of osteoclast. Due to functional deficiency of osteoclasts, calcified chondroid (cartilage) and primitive woven bone persists down into metaphysis and diaphysis, leading to osteosclerosis and increased brittleness of bones (marble bone disease). Autosomal dominant osteopetrosis is diagnosed in adult asymptomatic patients. It may present with mild anemia, pathological fractures premature osteoarthritis, and rarely osteomyelitis of mandible. Autosomal recessive malignant (congenital) osteopetrosis clinically presents at birth or in early infancy because of obliteration of marrow cavity by bony overgrowth resulting in inability of bone marrow to participate in hematopoiesis. Pancytopenia develops resulting in abnormal bleeding, easy bruising, progressive anemia, and failure to thrive. Laboratory parameters are serum calcium low, serum PTH high, serum phosphate low and serum ALP high. Radiological hallmark is increased radiopacity of bones. There is no distinction between cortical and cancellous bone, because intramedullary canal is filled with bone. Endobones (os in os or bone within bone appearance) and rugger jersey spine are seen on radiographs. Treatment is bone marrow transplant.

 

 

Option C. Paget’s disease. It is characterized by excessive disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation. Osteoclast appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. The new bone formed is abnormal, very vascular and larger (deforms and fractures) than preexisting bone, which leads to cortical widening and deformity. The diagnostic histological feature of Paget's disease is irregular area of lamellar bone fitting together like a jigsaw with randomly distributed cement lines. Initial osteolytic phase involves prominent bone resorption and marked hypervascularization (Radiologically seen as advancing lytic wedge or blade of grass lesion). 2nd phase of active bone formation and resorption replaces normal lamellar bone with structurally weak woven bone that bend, bow and fracture easily. In 3rd sclerotic (burnt out) phase, bone resorption declines progressively and leads to hard, dense, less vascular pagetic or mosaic bone. Most people are asymptomatic. The sites most commonly involved are pelvis, tibia, followed by skull, spine, clavicle and femur. It affects men (> 50 years) more commonly. Pain is most common presenting symptom. Limb looks bent and feels thick, and skin is unduly warm due to high vascularity.

 

 

Blade of grass

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hip fractures are most commonly seen in elderly females due to osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of heavy alcohol use presents to the emergency department with severe epigastric pain that radiates to the back and recurrent vomiting. On examination, the patient has tenderness and guarding in the upper epigastrium. The chest x-ray is normal. What is the next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum Lipase

 

Serum lipase is an enzyme produced by the pancreas. Elevated levels of serum lipase are a hallmark of acute pancreatitis. It is a critical diagnostic test to confirm the diagnosis in a patient with symptoms suggestive of pancreatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Upper GI endoscopy: Upper GI endoscopy is used to visualize the upper gastrointestinal tract, which may help diagnose conditions like peptic ulcers or esophagitis. However, in this case, the symptoms and clinical findings are more indicative of acute pancreatitis rather than upper GI issues.

 

Option B. Alcohol breath test: An alcohol breath test is used to detect recent alcohol consumption. While the patient has a history of heavy alcohol use, this test won't provide information about the current medical condition, such as pancreatitis.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography): A contrast-enhanced CT scan (CECT) can be a valuable tool for confirming the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis and assessing its severity. However, in many cases, a serum lipase test is ordered first because it's a quicker and less invasive way to diagnose acute pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Abdominal pain with recurrent vomiting in a chronic alcoholic with upper epigastric guarding is highly suggestive of pancreatitis.
  • A normal erect chest x-ray suggests that there is no pneumoperitoneum, effectively ruling out perforation.
  • In this setting, the main differential diagnosis to consider is pancreatitis.
  • The next appropriate investigation would be a serum lipase test to confirm the diagnosis of pancreatitis.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is exclusively secreted by adrenal gland but not by the ovaries of females? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DHEA-S

 

DHEAS is exclusively secreted from the adrenals but not by ovaries because ovaries lack the enzyme dehydroepiandrosterone-sulphotransferase needed to form DHEAS.

 

Adrenal hormones

 

  1. Zona glomerulosa – Aldosterone
  2. Zona fasciculata – glucocorticoids cortisol, corticosterone, as well as small amounts of adrenal androgens and estrogens
  3. The zona reticularis – adrenal androgens dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA. and androstenedione, as well as small amounts of estrogens and some glucocorticoids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progesterone: Incorrect. Progesterone is secreted by both the adrenal glands and the ovaries.

 

Option B. DHEA: Incorrect. DHEA is secreted by both the adrenal glands and the ovaries.

 

Option C. Estrogen: Incorrect. Estrogen is produced by both the ovaries and the adrenal glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DHEA-S (dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate) is exclusively secreted by the adrenal glands and not by the ovaries because the ovaries lack the enzyme necessary to produce DHEA-S.

choices.text: Dorsal group of neurons in the medulla

questions.text: Pacemaker generating the rhythm for breathing is? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pre-Bötzinger complex

 

The Pre-Bötzinger complex is a group of neurons located in the ventrolateral medulla of the brainstem, which is responsible for generating the basic rhythm of breathing. It is considered the primary respiratory rhythm generator, as it sets the pace for breathing and coordinates the activity of other respiratory neurons in the brainstem.

 

The Pre-Bötzinger complex receives input from a variety of sources, including chemoreceptors, mechanoreceptors, and cortical areas, which help to adjust the respiratory rhythm based on changing physiological demands. It also sends signals to other respiratory centers in the brainstem, such as the dorsal respiratory group, which modulate the depth and rate of breathing.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Pneumotaxic centre: Incorrect. It modifies the respiratory rate and pattern but does not generate the basic rhythm.

 

Option B. Dorsal group of neurons in the medulla: Incorrect. It regulates respiratory muscles and processes sensory information related to breathing but does not generate the primary rhythm.

 

Option D. Apneustic centre: Incorrect. It influences the pattern of breathing but does not generate the primary rhythm.

 

Educational objective

 

The Pre-Bötzinger complex, located in the ventrolateral medulla, is the primary respiratory rhythm generator. It sets the basic pace of breathing by generating rhythmic bursts of activity that drive the respiratory muscles, coordinating with other respiratory centers to modulate the breathing pattern based on the body's needs.

 

The pneumotaxic center and apneustic center are other respiratory centers located in the pons and medulla, respectively, which help to adjust the respiratory pattern by modifying the duration and intensity of inhalation and exhalation. The dorsal respiratory group is a cluster of neurons in the medulla that is involved in the regulation of respiratory muscles.

questions.text: A bodybuilder starts eating raw eggs for protein. He starts to develop fatigue on moderate exercise. The doctor prescribes a vitamin. Which enzyme is deficient in him? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pyruvate Carboxylase

 

Raw eggs contain a protein called avidin, which binds to biotin and prevents its absorption in the intestine. Biotin is a vital coenzyme for several carboxylase enzymes, including pyruvate carboxylase. When biotin is deficient, these enzymes cannot function properly, leading to symptoms such as fatigue, particularly during moderate exercise.

 

Mechanism:

  • Avidin in Raw Eggs: Binds strongly to biotin, preventing its absorption and leading to biotin deficiency.
  • Pyruvate Carboxylase Deficiency: Results in impaired gluconeogenesis and energy production, causing fatigue during exercise.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose 6 Phosphate:

  • Function: Involved in glycogenolysis and the pentose phosphate pathway.
  • Relevance: Not related to biotin deficiency or the symptoms described.

 

Option C. PEPCK (Phosphoenolpyruvate Carboxykinase):

  • Function: Catalyzes the conversion of oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate in gluconeogenesis.
  • Relevance: Although involved in gluconeogenesis, its activity is not directly dependent on biotin.

 

Option D. Glycogen Phosphorylase:

  • Function: Breaks down glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate in glycogenolysis.
  • Relevance: Not related to biotin deficiency or the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eating raw eggs can lead to biotin deficiency due to avidin binding, resulting in a deficiency of pyruvate carboxylase. This enzyme deficiency impairs gluconeogenesis, causing fatigue during exercise. Supplementing biotin can correct the deficiency and alleviate symptoms.

questions.text:
172. Match the following tests and poisons:

 

Column-A

1. Marsh test

2. Silver nitrate paper test

3. Cavett test

4. Marqui's test

 

Column-B

a. Opium

b. Aluminium phosphide

c. Alcohol

d. Arsenic
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 → d, 2 → b, 3 → c, 4 → a

 

1. Marsh test → Arsenic (d): The Marsh test is a well-known, traditional method for detecting arsenic poisoning. It generates arsine gas, which decomposes to produce metallic arsenic stains, confirming the presence of arsenic.

 

2. Silver nitrate paper test → Aluminium phosphide (b): This test is used to detect aluminium phosphide poisoning. When aluminium phosphide reacts with moisture, it releases phosphine gas. The phosphine turns silver nitrate paper black, indicating a positive result.

 

3. Cavett test → Alcohol (c): The Cavett test is a micro-method for determining blood alcohol levels. It works on the principle that alcohol reduces potassium bichromate. For forensic purposes, gas chromatography is often preferred for accurate measurement.

 

4. Marqui's test → Opium (a): Marqui's test is used to detect opium. When a suspected opium sample is treated with concentrated sulfuric acid and formalin, a color change from purple-red to violet and finally to blue occurs, indicating the presence of opium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Marsh test detects arsenic.
  • Silver nitrate paper test detects aluminium phosphide.
  • Cavett test is for alcohol detection.
  • Marqui's test detects opium.

questions.text: The following image of a FAST scan in a trauma patient suggests: (AIIMS 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Positive FAST

 

Explanation:

 

The ultrasound image shows an anechoic area (appearing dark on ultrasound), which is fluid between the liver and kidney. This finding is indicative of a hemoperitoneum, suggesting that the FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma) scan is positive. A positive FAST scan in this context typically points to the presence of free fluid in the abdomen, which in trauma settings, is usually due to bleeding, confirming a hemoperitoneum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Negative FAST: This would imply no visible free fluid; the image, however, shows clear evidence of fluid.

 

Option C. Equivocal FAST: This term would be used if the findings were unclear or uncertain, which is not the case here as the fluid is distinctly visible.

 

Option D. Pneumoperitoneum: This condition involves the presence of free air in the abdominal cavity and would present differently on an ultrasound, typically as increased echogenicity reflecting off the free air; this is not visible in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anechoic fluid between liver and kidney is suggestive of hemoperitoneum-FAST positive

 

eFAST: Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma

 

Focus:

 

  • Hemoperitoneum (free fluid in abdomen)
  • Pericardial effusion
  • Pneumothorax
  • Hemothorax

questions.text: A farmer from the sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury a year back and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of prick. A skin biopsy sample was taken and sent for histopathological examination. The characteristic microscopic body as shown in the image was seen. Which of the following could be the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chromoblastomycosis

 

The history of a slowly spreading warty, verrucous lesion following a thorn prick injury and the histopathological image showing medlar bodies is suggestive of chromoblastomycosis.

 

It is a chronic deep cutaneous fungal infection usually affecting the limbs at the inoculation site

 

Causative agents include several fungi found in soil, wood and decaying plant material:

 

  • Phialophora verrucosa
  • Fonsecaea pedrosi (most common pathogen, accounts for > 90% of the cases in South America)
  • Fonsecaea compacta
  • Cladosporium carrionii
  • Rhinocladiella aquaspersa (Ramichloridium cerophilum)

 

Common clinical presentation is verrucous lesion over extremities of adult men engaged in outdoor work. Lesion starts as a small firm red / gray bump on the traumatized skin on the foot or hand. Grows slowly (2 mm/year) to form raised hyperkeratotic (crusted, warty-looking) plaque

 

Histologically, the lesions are granulomatous and the dark sclerotic bodies may be seen within leukocytes or giant cells called medlar/copper penny bodies.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blastomycosis: This is a fungal infection caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis. It typically presents with flu-like symptoms, skin lesions, and sometimes lung involvement. The histopathology would show broad-based budding yeast rather than medlar bodies.

 

Option B. Pheohyphomycosis: This refers to a group of fungal infections caused by dematiaceous (dark-walled) fungi. The infection can present in various forms, from superficial to deep infections, but it does not typically produce medlar bodies.

 

Option D. Sporotrichosis: Caused by Sporothrix schenckii, this infection usually follows a thorn prick and presents as nodular lesions that can ulcerate. The characteristic histopathological finding is cigar-shaped yeast, not medlar bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromoblastomycosis is characterized by a slowly spreading warty, verrucous lesion following a thorn prick injury, with histopathological evidence of medlar bodies.

questions.text: Glycopyrrolate is used as a preanesthetic agent for?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reducing the secretions

 

  • Mechanism of Action: Glycopyrrolate is an anticholinergic agent, which means it acts by blocking the action of acetylcholine on muscarinic receptors.
  • Effect: One of the effects of this action is the reduction in the production of secretions, such as saliva and bronchial mucus.
  • Clinical Use: Given before anesthesia, it can prevent excessive secretions that might interfere with the procedure or increase the risk of aspiration. Hence, this is the primary reason glycopyrrolate is used as a preanesthetic agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sedative effect: Glycopyrrolate does not have inherent sedative properties. While it may have some central side effects due to its anticholinergic action, its quaternary structure limits its ability to cross the blood-brain barrier. Thus, it doesn't produce sedation in the same manner as agents specifically designed for that purpose, like benzodiazepines.

 

Option C. Skeletal muscle relaxant: Glycopyrrolate does not have skeletal muscle relaxant properties.

 

Option D. Anxiolytic: Glycopyrrolate is not used as an anxiolytic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glycopyrrolate is primarily used as a preanesthetic agent to reduce secretions, thus preventing complications during anesthesia and surgery.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 849

choices.text: Potassium binding resins
Broad spectrum antibiotics

questions.text: A 3-week neonate presents with ambiguous genitalia with Na+ - 127, K+ - 6 meq with a BP of 50/22 mm Hg. Along with IV fluids, what specific management is done? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrocortisone

 

The neonate in this case presents with ambiguous genitalia, hyponatremia (Na+ 127 mEq/L), hyperkalemia (K+ 6 mEq/L), and hypotension (BP 50/22 mm Hg). These findings are suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), most likely due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. CAH is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a deficiency in cortisol production, leading to an overproduction of androgens and a deficiency in aldosterone, which causes salt-wasting and hyperkalemia.

 

The treatment of choice in this situation is hydrocortisone, which replaces the deficient glucocorticoids. Hydrocortisone will help manage the adrenal insufficiency by increasing cortisol levels, thereby normalizing blood pressure, glucose levels, and reducing the overproduction of androgens. In addition to hydrocortisone, mineralocorticoid replacement with fludrocortisone may also be required to address the salt-wasting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spironolactone: This is a potassium-sparing diuretic and aldosterone antagonist. It is not appropriate in this scenario as it would exacerbate hyperkalemia and does not address the underlying cortisol deficiency.
