Option B. Potassium binding resins: These are used to treat hyperkalemia by promoting the excretion of potassium in the stool. While they may reduce potassium levels, they do not address the underlying cause of the hyperkalemia, which is the deficiency in cortisol and aldosterone.

 

Option D. Broad spectrum antibiotics: Antibiotics are used to treat infections and are not relevant in managing CAH unless the patient has a concurrent infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrocortisone is the first-line treatment for congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) with 21-hydroxylase deficiency, which presents with ambiguous genitalia, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypotension in neonates.

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby was brought to the hospital with complaints of poor feeding and abnormal twitching of his lower limb. On examination, he has fever with fontanelle bulging and the child was lethargic. The most probable cause is: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Meningitis

 

Poor eating, fever, convulsions, a bulging fontanelle, and lethargy are all symptoms of meningitis.

 

Meningococcus, Streptococcus pneumonia, or Haemophilus influenza type b can all cause bacterial meningitis. General symptoms include fever, lethargy, unwillingness to feed, vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Febrile seizure: Patient should have a history of high grade fever associated with seizures.

 

Option C. Pseudotumor cerebri: This is the most common type of focal seizure present in sleep. Age group 3-10 yr, resolve by adolescence. Start at night in the form of buccal throat tingling, tonic clonic contraction of one side with preserved consciousness.

 

Option D. Intracranial hemorrhage: Patient should have history of any trauma

 

Seizures and localised neurological symptoms are possible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Poor eating, fever, convulsions, a bulging fontanelle, and lethargy are all symptoms of meningitis.

choices.text: Herpes virus
Verruca vulgaris
Molluscum contagiosum

questions.text: A 36-year-old male with skin-colored umbilicated papules. Microscopy is as shown below. The most likely diagnosis is: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Molluscum contagiosum

 

The given picture shows intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (staining purple-pink) within the keratinocytes.

 

Molluscum contagiosum is a common self-limiting contagious lesion caused by a poxvirus which is a DNA virus. It is more common in children and young adults. Infection is acquired by direct contact. Clinically, the lesions are often multiple, discrete, waxy, papules, about 5 mm in diameter and are seen more frequently on the face and trunk

 

Tzanck smear shows intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson-Patterson bodies), the largest known inclusion bodies (30-35 m).

 

 

Individual lesions are firm, pruritic, pink to skin-colored umbilicated papules (shown below). A curd-like material can be expressed from the central umbilication

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes virus: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections typically present with grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, which then progress to pustules, ulcers, and crusts. The histology usually shows multinucleated giant cells with intranuclear inclusions on a Tzanck smear, not the intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies seen in this case.

 

Option B. Verruca vulgaris: Also known as common warts, verruca vulgaris is caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV). These lesions are typically hyperkeratotic, exophytic papules with a rough surface. Histologically, they show papillomatosis, hyperkeratosis, and koilocytosis (vacuolated cells with a halo around the nucleus). These features are distinct from the molluscum bodies seen in Molluscum contagiosum.

 

Option D. Lichen planus: Lichen planus is an inflammatory condition that presents with pruritic, polygonal, flat-topped, violaceous papules, often with Wickham striae (fine white lines) on the surface. Histologically, it shows a band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermoepidermal junction, hypergranulosis, and saw-toothing of the rete ridges. These findings are not consistent with the histological image provided, which shows molluscum bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Molluscum contagiosum is characterized by the presence of intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson-Patterson bodies) within keratinocytes, and it presents clinically as skin-colored, umbilicated papules.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 1940

choices.text: 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D
1-D, 2-F, 3-E, 4-C
1-D, 2-A, 3-C 4-E
1-D, 2-C, 3-F, 4-E

questions.text: Match the following drugs with their ocular adverse effects?(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1-D, 2-C, 3-F, 4-E

 

The following are the drugs and their associated ocular adverse effects:

 

  1. Amiodarone: This drug is known to cause corneal deposits (cornea verticillata) and optic neuritis. The correct match for Amiodarone is D (Optic neuritis).
  2. Hydroxychloroquine: This drug is associated with bull’s eye maculopathy, a specific type of retinopathy. Therefore, Hydroxychloroquine is correctly matched with C (Retinopathy).
  3. Systemic steroids: When given topically, systemic steroids can cause open-angle glaucoma. However, when given systemically, they are known to cause posterior subcapsular cataract. Thus, systemic steroids are best matched with F (Cataract).
  4. Digoxin: This drug can cause yellow vision, a condition where the patient perceives a yellow tint in their vision. Hence, Digoxin is correctly matched with E (Yellow vision).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ocular adverse-effects of drugs:

 

  • Amiodarone: Corneal deposits (cornea verticallata) Optic neuritis
  • Hydroxychloroquine: Bull’s eye maculopathy (retinopathy).
  • Systemic steroids: Given topically – cause Open angle Glaucoma; Given systemically – cause Posterior subcapsular cataract.
  • Digoxin: Yellow vision

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/880, 318, 560, Goodman Gilman 13th/  564

questions.text: Which is not an obvious advantage of high-flow nasal cannula? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreases need of intubation

 

Explanation:

 

 

  • Decreases need of intubation: While high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) can be an intermediate step between standard oxygen therapy and more invasive respiratory support, it doesn't always eliminate the need for intubation. HFNC can improve oxygenation and reduce the work of breathing in many patients, but it may not be sufficient in cases of severe respiratory failure where intubation becomes necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduces nasopharyngeal dead space: High-flow nasal cannula allows for the delivery of oxygen at much higher flow rates than standard nasal cannulae. This higher flow rate can flush out the nasopharyngeal dead space, leading to a more consistent fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) and improving alveolar ventilation.

 

Option C. Heating and humidification: One of the distinct features of HFNC systems is that they deliver oxygen that's both heated and humidified. This enhances comfort, reduces the risk of mucosal drying and injury, and can help improve mucociliary clearance.

 

Option D. PEEP (Positive End-Expiratory Pressure): PEEP refers to the maintenance of a positive pressure in the airways at the end of expiration, which can prevent alveolar collapse. The high flow rate from HFNC can generate a degree of PEEP, especially with the mouth closed. This can help recruit alveoli and improve oxygenation in certain patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) offers several advantages, including reducing nasopharyngeal dead space, providing heated and humidified oxygen, and generating PEEP, it does not always eliminate the need for intubation in patients with severe respiratory failure.

choices.text: Acute kidney injury (AKI)
Chronic renal failure

questions.text: AKIN and RIFLE criteria are used to classify? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute Kidney Injury (AKI)

 

The AKIN (Acute Kidney Injury Network) and RIFLE (Risk, Injury, Failure, Loss of kidney function, and End-stage kidney disease) criteria are specifically designed to classify and diagnose Acute Kidney Injury (AKI). These criteria help in early detection and grading the severity of AKI based on changes in serum creatinine, urine output, and duration of symptoms.

 

Current diagnosis is based on the KDIGO group criteria. Urine output (OR) Creatinine rise is considered in the diagnosis.

 

KDIGO group criteria for diagnosis of AKI:

 

  1. Increase in S. Creatinine ≥ 0.3mg/dL.
  2. Increase in S. Creatinine ≥ 1.5 times of baseline that is known/presumed to have occur in the past 7 days.
  3. Urine volume < 0.5ml/kg/hour for 6 hours.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute glomerulonephritis: This has specific clinical and laboratory features distinct from AKI.

 

Option C. Chronic renal failure: Characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over months to years.

 

Option D. Nephrotic syndrome: Defined by high levels of protein in the urine, low levels of protein in the blood, high levels of cholesterol, and swelling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The AKIN and RIFLE criteria are essential tools for diagnosing and assessing the severity of Acute Kidney Injury, which can guide interventions and predict outcomes in affected patients. They emphasize changes in serum creatinine and urine output as key indicators of kidney function.

questions.text: Child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be Zellweger syndrome. Which among the following accumulates in brain in this condition?(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Long chain fatty acid

 

Zellweger syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder. It occurs due to defective oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA). Peroxisomal enzymes are produced; but their entry into peroxisome is denied. This leads to insufficient oxidation of VLCFA. Accumulation of VLCFA in CNS causes neurological impairment and death in childhood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose:

  • Function: Primary energy source for the brain.
  • Relevance: Accumulation is not characteristic of Zellweger syndrome but is more relevant in conditions like glycogen storage diseases or diabetes.

 

Option B. Lactic acid:

  • Function: Produced during anaerobic metabolism.
  • Relevance: Accumulation is associated with mitochondrial disorders or lactic acidosis, not Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option D. Triglycerides:

  • Function: Stored form of energy in adipose tissue.
  • Relevance: Accumulation in the brain is not characteristic of Zellweger syndrome; rather, it is associated with lipid storage diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zellweger syndrome leads to the accumulation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) in the brain due to defective peroxisomal oxidation, resulting in severe neurological impairment and early death in affected children.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion
Assertion is independently true, but the Reason is independently false
Assertion is independently false, but the Reason is independently true

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Central dogma says DNA is transcribed into RNA, which is subsequently translated into proteins.


Reason (R): Retrovirus has reverse transcriptase of central dogma where RNA is first converted into DNA, which is then transcribed to RNA, which is subsequently translated into proteins.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Both Assertion and Reason are independently true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion


The assertion correctly states the central dogma of molecular biology, which describes the flow of genetic information. It outlines three primary processes:

 

  1. Replication: The DNA molecule is copied to produce an identical daughter DNA strand.
  2. Transcription: DNA is transcribed into RNA.
  3. Translation: RNA is translated into proteins.

 

The central dogma represents the unidirectional flow of genetic information, from DNA to RNA and then to proteins.

 

The reason provided describes an extension of the central dogma, applicable to retroviruses. Retroviruses, like HIV, possess the enzyme reverse transcriptase, which synthesizes DNA from an RNA template. This process deviates from the typical flow outlined in the central dogma but is a unique mechanism seen in certain viruses. While both the assertion and reason are true, the reason does not directly explain the central dogma but rather provides an exception to it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The central dogma of molecular biology describes the flow of genetic information as DNA → RNA → Proteins. Retroviruses, however, exhibit reverse transcription, an exception to this classical concept.

choices.text: Drug resistant falciparum is seen in India
Presence of duffy blood group antigen is protective against vivax
Severe malaria with shock is called algid malaria
Relapse is seen in P. ovale

questions.text: Choose the wrong statement about Plasmodium species: (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presence of duffy blood group antigen is protective against vivax

 

  • The absence, not the presence, of the Duffy blood group antigen, is protective against P. vivax because the Duffy antigen normally serves as the receptor for Plasmodium vivax.
  • Drug Efflux pumps are the primary mode of resistance for Chloroquine. It is mediated by an ABC transporter encoded by P. falciparum multidrug resistance gene 1 (Pfmdr1).
  • Algid malaria is a rare complication of severe malaria characterized by hemodynamic collapse manifesting as shock with pronounced metabolic changes and hypothermia.
  • Relapse is seen in cases of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale.
  • Malaria relapse:
    • True relapse is caused due to Hypnozoites.
    • These are resting forms.
  • In the case of Plasmodium vivax and ovale two kinds of sporozoites are seen, some of which:
    • multiply inside hepatic cells to form - Schizonts
    • others persist and remain dormant as - hypnozoites
  • From time to time some are activated to become schizonts and release merozoites, which go on infecting RBCs producing clinical relapse.
  • In the case of Plasmodium falciparum and Plasmodium malaria, the initial tissue phase disappears completely and no hypnozoites are found, hence technically relapse is not seen.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Drug resistant falciparum is seen in India: This statement is correct. Drug-resistant strains of Plasmodium falciparum are a significant concern in India.

 

Option C. Severe malaria with shock is called algid malaria: This statement is correct. Algid malaria is a rare but severe complication of malaria characterized by shock and metabolic disturbances.

 

Option D. Relapse is seen in P. ovale: This statement is correct. Relapse is seen in Plasmodium ovale as well as Plasmodium vivax due to the presence of hypnozoites.

 

Educational Objective

 

The absence of the Duffy blood group antigen is protective against Plasmodium vivax, not its presence.

choices.text: Stop the treatment and follow up
Continue treatment for another 2 years
Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment
Continue lifelong treatment with antiepileptics

questions.text: A 16-year-old who is taking antiepileptics, has had a seizure-free period of 6 months. She has no family history of epilepsy. Her EEG is now normal and she has a normal neurological exam and intelligence. What would be your advice? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Continue treatment for another 2 years

 

In cases of epilepsy, particularly in children and adolescents, the continuation of antiepileptic drug (AED) therapy after a period of being seizure-free is typically recommended for about 2 years. This recommendation is based on the need to stabilize neurological function and minimize the risk of recurrence. The decision to discontinue AEDs should consider factors such as the duration of being seizure-free, EEG findings, the type of epilepsy, and the individual’s neurological examination.

 

Rationale for Continuing Treatment:

 

  • Continuing AED treatment for at least 2 years after achieving seizure control helps ensure the stability of the condition and reduces the likelihood of seizure recurrence, especially during the critical developmental years of adolescence.
  • Recurrences are most common in the first 3 months after discontinuing AEDs, making a cautious approach necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop the treatment and follow up: This would be risky given the short period of seizure freedom (only 6 months). Stopping treatment prematurely may lead to recurrence.

 

Option C. Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment: This is typically considered after a longer period of seizure freedom, usually a minimum of 2 years, not just 6 months.

 

Option D. Continue lifelong treatment with antiepileptics: This is generally reserved for cases of refractory epilepsy where seizures cannot be controlled with multiple medications, which does not seem to be the case here based on the information provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-epileptics once initiated must be continued for a minimum period of 2 years. Decision to stop AED is considered if, seizure free > 2 years with normal MRI, EEG, seizure type.

 

Recurrences occur in the first 3 months of discontinuing AED.

 

Reference - Harrison principles of internal Medicine 21st edition Pg. 12076

choices.text: Strength of correlation is same in A and B
Strength of the correlation is more in A than in B
Strength of the variation is more in B than A
Variation in variables is more with A than B

questions.text: A perinatologist is analyzing scatterplots from two research studies on the relationship between bone marrow density and gestational age. Study A shows data points tightly clustered along a trend line, while Study B shows data points that are more spread out but still follow a general trend line. Which statement correctly describes the relationship between bone marrow density and gestational age based on these observations? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Strength of the correlation is more in A than in B

 

  • Graph A represents stronger correlation than graph B.
  • More compact and close the dots are to the line, stronger is the relation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are correct, and the Reason is the appropriate explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are correct, but the Reason is not the explanation for the Assertion
Assertion is correct, but the Reason is incorrect
Assertion is incorrect, but the Reason is correct

questions.text:
Assertion: Menopause is associated with hot flashes.


Reason: Hot flashes occur because of a decrease or fluctuation in estrogen levels.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both Assertion and Reason are correct, and the Reason is the appropriate explanation for the Assertion

 

Menopause is closely associated with hot flashes, which are sudden and brief sensations of heat that can cause redness and sweating, particularly affecting the face and neck. These episodes typically last from 2 to 5 minutes. The frequency can vary, but they are usually more pronounced during nighttime, causing significant sleep disturbances.

 

The physiological explanation for hot flashes centers around hormonal changes, specifically a decrease or fluctuation in estrogen. Estrogen is crucial for the proper functioning of the hypothalamic thermoregulatory center, which maintains the body's temperature. During menopause, the drop in estrogen levels results in a decrease in hypothalamic endorphins. This decline leads to an increase in neurotransmitters like norepinephrine and serotonin. The surge in norepinephrine disrupts the hypothalamus's ability to regulate body temperature effectively, triggering episodes of hot flashes.

 

Common symptoms that accompany hot flashes include:

 

  • Headaches
  • Palpitations
  • Chest discomfort (anginal pains)
  • Irritability
  • Difficulty concentrating

 

Although estrogen deficiency is a major cause of hot flashes, it is essential to note that there are other potential causes. These include thyroid issues, epilepsy, tumors like pheochromocytoma and insulinomas, carcinoid syndromes, autoimmune diseases, and some blood disorders like leukemias. This highlights the complexity of diagnosing and understanding hot flashes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hot flashes during menopause are caused by a decrease or fluctuation in estrogen, which disrupts the thermoregulatory system in the hypothalamus, leading to sudden heat sensations and sweating.

questions.text: What to be done next? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bone biopsy

 

  • The given X-ray image shows a bone tumor which needs to be diagnosed.
  • The image shows a well-defined, lytic lesion (a darker area indicating bone destruction) in the distal femur, specifically in the medial femoral condyle. 
  • The lesion appears somewhat expansile and has a narrow zone of transition, suggesting a benign or low-grade aggressive lesion rather than a highly aggressive malignant tumor. 
  • There's no clear periosteal reaction or soft tissue mass immediately evident.
  • This appearance is highly suggestive of a Giant Cell Tumor (GCT), given its typical location (epiphyseal/metaphyseal region of long bones), lytic nature, and often eccentric appearance. 
  • Other possibilities might include an aneurysmal bone cyst or a chondroblastoma, but GCT is a strong consideration.
  • To reach the correct and final diagnosis, a bone biopsy test must be done. 
  • Bone biopsy is the most appropriate "next step" to definitively diagnose the nature of the lesion before proceeding with a potentially complex surgical intervention.
  • Without a biopsy, one cannot be absolutely certain of the benign or malignant nature, or the specific type of tumor.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extended curettage with allograft. Curettage involves scraping out the tumor. "Extended" curettage aims to remove as much of the tumor as possible while preserving the bone. After removal, the resulting cavity often needs to be filled to maintain structural integrity. An allograft is one option for filling. This is a common treatment for GCTs, especially those that are not highly aggressive or are in a location where wide excision would lead to significant functional impairment. Extended curettage remains the preferred treatment option for Grade I and II GCT due to least postoperative morbidity, cost-effectiveness, and surgical convenience. The risk of recurrence is high after curettage alone,and therefore adjuvants such as cryosurgery, cement, phenol or a combination of these are recommended. 

 

Option C. Curettage. Curettage alone might be insufficient for a lesion like a GCT due to its tendency for local recurrence. Compared with resection, curettage is associated with a higher rate of local recurrence; however, curettage often allows for a better functional result. Curettage can be extended by the use of adjuvants, such as liquid nitrogen, phenol, polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA), or thermal cautery to extend destruction of tumor cells. Bone cavities have been reinforced with autologous bone grafts, allograft, PMMA bone cement, demineralized bone matrix and bone graft substitutes. These fillers augment final bone strength, reduce the risk of local recurrence (esp. giant cell tumors) and fill the empty cavities. 

 

Educational Objective:

  • To reach the correct and final diagnosis, a bone biopsy test must be done. 
  • The management will follow the result of the bone biopsy. 
  • If the question implies "what is the definitive treatment generally indicated for a lesion with this appearance (strongly suggesting GCT)," then options A or D would be relevant. Giant Cell Tumors are known for local recurrence after simple curettage, which is why extended curettage (with or without adjuvant therapy) is the preferred surgical treatment.

questions.text: Identify the breast condition shown in the image below? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mondor’s Disease

 

Mondor's disease is a rare condition characterized by superficial thrombophlebitis of the subcutaneous veins, typically in the breast or chest wall, but it can occur in other parts of the body as well.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paget's disease: Paget's disease is an insitu lesion of nipple which presents with nipple destruction.

 

Option C. Zuska's disease: Zuska's disease, also known as chronic periductal mastitis is characterized by slit like nipple retraction after repeated inflammation of lactiferous ducts seen in smoker females.

 

Option D. Tietze syndrome: Tietze syndrome is a rare inflammatory condition that affects the cartilage of the ribs and sternum, causing pain and swelling in the affected area. The exact cause of Tietze syndrome is unknown, but it may be related to trauma, infection, or underlying autoimmune or inflammatory disorders. Symptoms may include pain, swelling, tenderness, and redness over the affected area. Treatment options may include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), corticosteroids, and physical therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical presentation of Mondor's disease includes pain, tenderness, and redness over the affected area, along with a palpable cord-like structure that corresponds to the thrombosed vein.
  • The diagnosis of Mondor's disease is made by physical examination.
  • Treatment for Mondor's disease includes restriction of arm movements, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), warm compresses, and compression garments to alleviate pain and inflammation.

choices.text: Sense changes in muscle direction
Sense changes in muscle tension
Sense changes in position of the muscle
Sense changes in length of the muscle

questions.text: The function of the Golgi tendon organ is to? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sense changes in muscle tension

 

The Golgi tendon organ functions as a crucial sensory receptor that provides important feedback to the central nervous system, contributing to muscle control, injury prevention, and maintaining appropriate muscle tension during various activities.

 

The Golgi tendon organ is an encapsulated sensory receptor through which muscle tendon fibers pass. About 10 to 15 muscle fibers are usually connected to each Golgi tendon organ, and the organ is stimulated when this small bundle of muscle fibers is “tensed” by contracting or stretching the muscle.

 

The major difference in excitation of the Golgi tendon organ versus the muscle spindle is that the spindle detects muscle length and changes in muscle length, whereas the tendon organ detects muscle tension as reflected by the tension in itself.

 

Golgi tendon reflex (Inverse myotatic/ Inverse stretch reflex)

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Sense changes in muscle direction: Incorrect. Muscle direction changes are not detected by the Golgi tendon organ but by proprioceptors in the muscle and joints.

 

Option C. Sense changes in position of the muscle: Incorrect. This function is primarily performed by muscle spindles and joint receptors, not by the Golgi tendon organ.

 

Option D. Sense changes in length of the muscle: Incorrect. Muscle spindles are responsible for detecting changes in muscle length and the rate of change in length, not the Golgi tendon organ.

 

Educational Objective

 

The Golgi tendon organ is responsible for sensing changes in muscle tension, providing crucial feedback to the central nervous system to prevent muscle damage and maintain appropriate muscle tension during various activities.

questions.text: Most specific for diagnosing ankylosing spondylitis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bilateral sacroiliitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy a genetically determined generalized chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
  • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis & synovitis.
  • Bilateral sacroilitis is a hallmark radiological feature of AS and is a key criterion in diagnostic classification.
  • Visible inflammation and structural changes in the sacroiliac joints, especially if bilateral, are highly indicative of AS.
  • This is considered a more specific diagnostic feature than HLA-B27 alone.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years.
    • Most initial symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, associated with morning stiffness and improves with activity.
  • Radiographic features:
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.

 

 

  • Later on, SI joints show irregular subchondral erosions in, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually, bony ankylosis.
  • Squaring of vertebra, loss of lumbar lordosis and bridging osteophytes (syndesmophytes) are seen. 
  • Bamboo spine appearance due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HLA B27. While HLA-B27 is strongly associated with ankylosing spondylitis (AS) and is found in a large majority of patients, it's not the most specific for diagnosis on its own. The presence of HLA-B27 can be found in a significant percentage of the general population who do not have AS.

 

Option C. Lumbar movements. Lumbar movements are decreased in ankylosing spondylitis, but it is not specific to the disease.

 

Option D. ESR. ESR is a non-specific marker of inflammation. Increased ESR can be present in systemic infections, bone infections, rheumatic fever, tuberculosis. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

HLA-B27 is a significant genetic marker and helps in identifying individuals at risk, the most specific finding for diagnosing ankylosing spondylitis, particularly in its later stages, is often the presence of definite structural changes in the sacroiliac joints, especially bilateral sacroiliitis, on imaging.

questions.text: A public health researcher is studying the prevalence of a disease among school-aged children in a suburban town across two separate periods during the monsoon season. Two unpaired cohorts of children are observed: one from June to July and another from August to September. To compare the prevalence rates between these two cohorts, which statistical test is most appropriate? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chi square

 

  • Chi-square test can be implemented in this given scenario.
  • The data is expressed as proportion of children affected by the disease in various months.
  • It is a qualitative variable as we assess the proportion of children who are affected by the disease and those who are not affected by the disease. The chi-square test can be used to compare two or more groups.

 

Chi square: Non parametric test used for comparing percentage, proportions & fractions in two or more different group of individuals. 

 

Example: Three-fourth of MBBS students in a class are underweight whereas another class has two thirds anaemic; test of significance to be used is Chi-square test

 

Fischer’s test: Is a variant of Chi-square test when sample size is < 30

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paired t test: Parametric test which is used to compare means (+ SD) in paired data (in same group of individuals before and after an intervention)

 

  • Example: Mean serum albumin level of dengue patients before treatment was 3.6 g/dL and after treatment was 3.2 g/dL; Comparison of mean levels can be done by Paired Student’s t-test (Unpaired Student’s t-test is for comparing means (+ SD) in two different group of individuals - Example: Mean Hb level of anemia patients was 9.6 g/dL and those of hookworm patients was 7.2 g/dL; Comparison of mean levels can be done by Unpaired Student’s t-test; Z - test: Is a variant of student’s t-test which is used when sample size is > 30)

 

Option C. Wilcoxon test: Non parametric test used for comparing percentage, proportions & fractions in matched paired data

 

  • Wilcoxon (rank sum) test: Comparing percentage, proportions & fractions in two unpaired samples
  • Mann-Whitney (Wilcoxon) test:
    • MWW is same as Wilcoxon (rank sum) test
    • Is used for assessing whether two set of observations come from same distribution (if 2 independent ‘nonpaired’ samples come from the same population)
    • ‘MWW is analogous to parametric two-sample t-test’ on the data after ranking over the combined samples
    • MWW requires calculation of ‘U statistic’.

 

Option D. ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) (F-test/F-ratio): Parametric test used to compare means (+ SD) in more than two different group of individuals

 

  • Example: Mean weight of students in class A is 50 kg, those of class B is 44.6 kg and those of class C is 52.7 kg; Comparison of mean weights can be done by ANOVA test.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient is diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia. The peripheral blood smear picture is given in the image. The cell indicated by the arrow is best described as: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Faggot cell

 

The picture shows multiple Auer rods clustered in a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks.

 

Such cells are called faggot cells (faggot meaning bundle of sticks in French). Faggot cells are characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) associated with the t(15;17) translocation.

 

The presence of faggot cells is particularly indicative of APL, where the leukemic promyelocytes have an abundance of Auer rods. Auer rods are distinctive needle-like azurophilic granules formed by the fusion of primary (azurophilic) granules. While Auer rods can be seen in other subtypes of AML, the clustering of these rods within a single cell to form a faggot cell is most commonly associated with APL.

 

Since the question is particularly about the cell, the best answer from the given options is faggot cell and not Auer rods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Auer rods: Auer rods are distinctive needle-like azurophilic granules present in many cases but particularly numerous in AML with the t(15;17) aberration (acute promyelocytic leukemia).

 

Option B. Flaming promyelocyte: Flaming promyelocyte is an abnormal promyelocyte with disintegrating cytoplasm and liberating Auer rods and granules into the surrounding marrow. Found in APL

 

Option C. Dusky promyelocyte: Promyelocytes with fine granules appearing dusky or hazy are called dusky promyelocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A faggot cell, characterized by multiple Auer rods clustered together in a single cell, is highly indicative of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). While Auer rods are a feature of various forms of AML, the presence of faggot cells is particularly associated with APL.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 1154

questions.text:
A team of researchers is conducting investigations to evaluate the impact of interventions targeting a specific disease. Two independent studies, labeled as A and B, are analyzed. Study A utilized an intervention denoted as "X", and Study B utilized an intervention denoted as "Y". Both studies incorporate control groups. The calculated p-values for studies A and B, with 95% confidence intervals, were found to be 0.02 and 0.001, respectively.  Based on this information, which of the following conclusions is most appropriate? (AIIMS MAY 2019)

 

  1. Study B is more precise than study A and intervention Y is more significant compared to Intervention X.
  2. Study A is more precise than study B and intervention X is more significant compared to Intervention Y.
  3. Both X and Y show a significant variation, but Study B is more significant than Study A.
  4. Both study A and B show a significant variation and both interventions have similar statistical significance.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) If 1 and 3 are correct

 

  • Statements 1 and 3 are accurate. The p-value for study A involving intervention X within a 95% confidence interval stands at 0.02.
  • In the case of study B, employing intervention Y within the same confidence interval, the p-value is 0.001.
  • Both studies' probability (p) values fall below the 0.05 threshold (level of significance - α), leading to the conclusion that both studies A and B hold significance and thus warrant the rejection of the null hypothesis.
  • Nevertheless, study B exhibits a p-value lower than that of study A, implying that the precision and significance of study B, involving intervention Y, surpass those of study A with intervention X.

 

Other Options:

 

Option 2: This is incorrect as it mistakenly asserts that Study A, which had a higher p-value, would be more precise and that intervention X would be more significant than intervention Y. This is opposite to what the p-values suggest.

 

Option 4: Also incorrect because it suggests that both interventions have similar statistical significance, which contradicts the considerable difference in their p-values. A lower p-value in Study B indicates a stronger statistical significance compared to Study A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In interpreting clinical study results, a lower p-value indicates stronger evidence against the null hypothesis and typically points to a more significant intervention effect.
  • In this scenario, Study B's intervention (Y) is statistically more significant than Study A's intervention (X), indicating a potentially more effective or impactful intervention.

questions.text: A patient presented with painless decrease in vision and metamorphopsia. Fundus examination revealed the lesion shown in the image. What is the expected finding on ultrasonography? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Collar stud appearance  

 

The provided image depicts the right fundus of a patient, which indicates the presence of choroidal melanoma.

 

  • Angiography of the lesion: shows a distinct "double circulation" pattern, which represents the internal circulation within the tumor and the normal vascularity of the overlying retina.
  • On B-scan: pathognomonic feature called the "collar stud appearance" is visible. This appearance refers to a raised, dome-shaped tumor with a collar-like thickening at the base, caused by the accumulation of melanin and the infiltration of inflammatory cells at the tumor base.

 

 

Choroidal melanoma is a type of cancer that originates in the choroid, which is the vascular layer of the eye located between the retina and the sclera. It is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults and can lead to visual impairment and even metastasis to other organs. Therefore, it is crucial to diagnose and manage it promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Smoke-stack appearance: Typically associated with central serous retinopathy, showing a smoke-like leakage of fluid under the retina.

 

Option B. Inkblot appearance: Another pattern seen in central serous retinopathy where fluid leaks in a blot-like fashion.

 

Option D. Double circulation: While this feature can be seen in angiography of choroidal melanoma, it does not describe the ultrasonography appearance, which is specifically asked in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When diagnosing choroidal melanoma via ultrasonography, the "collar stud appearance" is a key finding. Recognizing this feature, along with the clinical presentation of painless visual loss and metamorphopsia, supports a timely and accurate diagnosis of this potentially life-threatening condition.

questions.text: Which of the following ventilation modes is associated with the risk of respiratory alkalosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Assisted Control Mode Ventilation (ACMV)

 

Assisted Control Mode Ventilation (ACMV) is a type of mechanical ventilation where every breath taken by the patient, whether spontaneous or initiated, is supported by the ventilator. This mode delivers a set tidal volume and rate, and even spontaneous efforts result in a full ventilator breath. Due to this mechanism, there is a risk of hyperventilation if the patient has a high respiratory drive, which can lead to respiratory alkalosis. Respiratory alkalosis occurs when there is an excessive loss of carbon dioxide (CO₂) due to over-ventilation.

 

  • Advantages of ACMV: It ensures guaranteed ventilation and provides full support to each breath.
  • Disadvantages of ACMV: It can lead to hyperventilation, barotrauma, and volume trauma, potentially causing respiratory alkalosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Controlled Mandatory Ventilation (CMV): Incorrect. CMV delivers a set number of breaths per minute and does not depend on the patient’s effort. It is less likely to cause respiratory alkalosis compared to ACMV because it does not support spontaneous breaths that could increase ventilation excessively.

 

Option C. Pressure Controlled Ventilation (PCV): Incorrect. PCV focuses on controlling pressure rather than volume. It is generally used to avoid barotrauma and does not typically cause hyperventilation or respiratory alkalosis.

 

Option D. Synchronized Intermittent Mandatory Ventilation (SIMV): Incorrect. SIMV allows for a combination of mandatory ventilator breaths and spontaneous patient breaths. It synchronizes with the patient's effort, reducing the risk of hyperventilation compared to ACMV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Assisted Control Mode Ventilation (ACMV) can lead to hyperventilation and respiratory alkalosis due to the full support of each patient breath, even if spontaneous.

questions.text: The action of the muscle attached to the marked area? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Abduction

 

Explanation:

 

The greater trochanter is visible in the photograph, and the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscle fibres attach (insert) here. Action of these fibres of abducting the leg, and their anterior fibres rotate the thigh medially.

 

Both are innervated by the superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1)

 

Hip abduction involves moving the thigh laterally, away from the midline. This is the primary function of both the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus. When you stand on one leg, these muscles contract on the standing side to prevent the pelvis from tilting down on the free side. This stabilizing action is crucial for bipedal walking.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flexion: Hip flexion primarily involves lifting the thigh forward in an anterior direction. While the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus can assist in flexion when the hip is initially in extension, this is not their primary function. Main hip flexors include the iliopsoas, rectus femoris, and sartorius.

 

Option B. Adduction: Hip adduction is the action of moving the thigh medially, towards the midline. Gluteus medius and gluteus minimus are not adductors; in fact, they act in opposition to this movement. The primary hip adductors include muscles like the adductor longus, adductor brevis, adductor magnus, gracilis, and pectineus.

 

Option D. Extension: Hip extension involves moving the thigh posteriorly. The primary hip extensor is the gluteus maximus, which is the largest of the gluteal muscles. While the gluteus medius and minimus can assist in hip extension when the hip is initially flexed, this is not their main action.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Insert needle in appropriate intercostal space

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He has chest trauma, a respiratory rate of 40 breaths per minute, and a blood pressure of 90/50 mmHg. The patient is conscious but only able to speak in short phrases. On examination, there is hyperresonance on the affected side of the chest. What should be your next immediate step in managing this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Insert needle in appropriate intercostal space

 

The given clinical scenario of hemodynamic instability and hyper-resonance on the affected side is suggestive of tension pneumothorax.

 

The next immediate step of management is inserting a needle i.e. needle decompression in the appropriate intercostal space (ICS).

 

The presence of hyper-resonance on percussion and the patient's signs of respiratory distress suggest a potential tension pneumothorax. A tension pneumothorax occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space and compresses the lung, leading to severe respiratory compromise. Inserting a needle (needle decompression) in the appropriate intercostal space is a life-saving procedure to release the trapped air and relieve the pressure on the affected lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intubate: While maintaining a patient's airway is crucial in cases of respiratory distress, intubation is not the immediate next step in this case. The patient is conscious and speaking, indicating that they have a patent airway. The primary concern is addressing the chest trauma and potential tension pneumothorax.

 

Option C. Start intravenous fluids urgently: While providing intravenous fluids may be necessary, it is not the immediate priority in this case.

 

Option D. Take a chest X-ray: While a chest X-ray can provide valuable diagnostic information, it is not the immediate next step in a suspected tension pneumothorax. Clinical signs and symptoms, including chest percussion and the patient's condition, warrant immediate intervention to relieve the pressure on the lung.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of tension pneumothorax:

 

  • Immediate management: Needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line
  • Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety
  • Note: According to ATLS 10th edition
  • In adults, needle thoracostomy or needle decompression location is changed to 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line from 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • However, In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location remains at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.

questions.text: Calculate the anion gap from the following values: Na+ = 137 mmol/L; K+ = 4 mmol/L; CI- =100 mmol/L; HCO3- = 15 mmol/L? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 22 mmol/L

 

AG = (Sum of cation) - (Sum of anion)

 

AG = (Na - (HCO3 + CL))

 

AG = 137 – 115 = 22 mmol/L

 

Note: Normal AG ~ 12

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Sign of effective neonatal resuscitation is: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased heart rate

 

The best indicator of successful newborn resuscitation is a rise in heart rate. Based on heart rate, the response to newborn resuscitation is evaluated at different stages.

 

  • If the heart rate is under 100, PPV is given, SPO2 is monitored, and sufficient breathing is guaranteed.
  • Chest compressions are started over the lower portion of the sternum at a pace of 90 compressions per minute if the heart rate is below 60. The ventilation to compression ratio is 3 to 1.
  • IV epinephrine is administered if the heart rate is still below 60 despite effective compressions and breathing.


 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colour change: Colour change is not a sign of effective resuscitation.

 

Option B. Bilateral air entry: this feature is checked when we are thinking of pneumothorax or severe pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best indicator of successful newborn resuscitation is a rise in heart rate.

questions.text: Preferred drug for the treatment of a 48-year-old man with uncomplicated grade 2 hypertension without any associated co-morbidity is (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chlorthalidone

 

  • Chlorthalidone is a thiazide-like diuretic that is highly effective in lowering blood pressure and is often recommended as the preferred first-line treatment for uncomplicated grade 2 hypertension. It has a longer duration of action compared to other thiazides, such as hydrochlorothiazide, making it particularly effective in managing hypertension over a 24-hour period.
  • According to ACC Guidelines and JNC 8 Guidelines, the DOC for hypertension is Thiazides (preferred diuretic).
  • Apart from thiazides, the other first line drugs for hypertension are-
  • ACE Inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers
  • Calcium channel blockers

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Triamterene: This is a potassium-sparing diuretic. It is primarily used in combination with other diuretics to prevent hypokalemia but is not recommended as a first-line treatment for hypertension.

 

Option C. Spironolactone: Another potassium-sparing diuretic, primarily used in conditions such as heart failure, hyperaldosteronism, and resistant hypertension, not as a first-line treatment for uncomplicated hypertension.

 

Option D. Furosemide: This is a loop diuretic, which is typically used in conditions such as congestive heart failure, renal insufficiency, and edema. It is not recommended as a first-line treatment for uncomplicated hypertension due to its short duration of action and the potential for significant electrolyte disturbances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the treatment of uncomplicated grade 2 hypertension without any associated comorbidities, thiazide diuretics, particularly chlorthalidone, are the preferred first-line agents according to ACC and JNC 8 guidelines.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/615

questions.text: A patient has the freedom to pick his or her caretaker and future course of action in treatment under the Mental Health Care Act of 2017. What is the name of this provision? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Advance directive

 

Under the Mental Health Care Act of 2017 in India, the provision allowing a patient to choose his or her caretaker and future course of action in treatment is termed the “Advance directive”. It is a legal document wherein the individual specifies the type of treatment they want or don't want, should they become mentally ill and be unable to make competent decisions in the future.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treatment directive, Option B. Mental will, and Option C. Future directive are not the correct terms used in the context of the Mental Health Care Act of 2017.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Under the Mental Health Care Act 2017 in India, individuals can use an "Advance Directive" to state the way they wish to be treated for a mental illness and the way they wish not to be treated for a mental illness. This provision empowers individuals to have a say in their treatment even if they become incapacitated in the future. This is applicable only if a person loses the capacity to make mental healthcare or treatment decisions. Individuals can also appoint “Nominated Representative (NR)”, who will help in taking decisions regarding the treatment if he or she loses the capacity to make decision.

 

Reference: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian Laws and Mental Health, Page No 42.

questions.text: I-125 labelled albumin is used for measurement of: (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasma volume

 

Albumin iodinated I-125 serum is a radiopharmaceutical diagnostic agent indicated for use in the determination of total blood and plasma volume.

 

The use of I-125 labeled albumin for the measurement of interstitial fluid volume, intracellular fluid volume or extracellular fluid volume is not common.

 

Other tracers, such as inulin or sucrose, are more commonly used for measuring extracellular or interstitial fluid volume, while radiolabeled water or radiolabeled potassium chloride can be used for measuring total body water and intracellular fluid volume.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Interstitial fluid volume: Incorrect. Interstitial fluid volume is typically measured using other tracers such as inulin or thiosulfate.

 

Option C. ICF (Intracellular Fluid): Incorrect. Intracellular fluid volume is not measured using I-125 labelled albumin. Methods like radiolabeled potassium or total body water (using deuterium or tritium) are used for ICF estimation.

 

Option D. ECF (Extracellular Fluid): Incorrect. Extracellular fluid volume is generally measured using tracers like inulin, which distribute throughout the extracellular compartment but do not enter cells.

 

Educational objective

 

I-125 labelled albumin is specifically used to measure plasma volume. It remains confined to the vascular compartment, making it an effective tracer for determining the volume of plasma within the circulatory system

questions.text:
True statements in view of septic arthritis are:(AIIMS MAY 2019)

 

  1. Widening of joint space is there.
  2. Staph aureus is the most common organism in young children and neonate.
  3. Incision and drainage is frequently required.
  4. Kocher criteria used to differentiate from transient synovitis.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All are correct

 

SEPTIC (PYOGENIC) ARTHRITIS

 

  • Refers to Infection of Joint.
  • Septic arthritis word is a misnomer as initially there is only infection of joint and if not treated early then Arthritis (joint destruction) develops.
  • Thus, all sepsis of joints do not cause arthritis only inadequately treated ones do.
  • Etiology and Pathology: The hematogenous route of infection is the most common route in all age groups.
  • Epidemiology:
    • Staph. aureus is the most common organism in neonates.
    • Absent movements of a joint after ruling out trauma in pediatric population is septic arthritis till proved otherwise.

 

 

  • Diagnosis: 
    • X-rays are usually normal or may indicate soft tissue swellings.
    • The earliest plain film radiographic findings of septic arthritis are soft tissue swelling around the joint and a widened joint space from joint effusion; however, uniform narrowing of the joint has also been described.
    • MRI may show effusion, synovitis or cartilage destruction.
    • Aspiration of joint will help to confirm the diagnosis by culture and sensitivity and can also help to differentiate from transient synovitis.
    • Aspiration also decreases intra-articular pressure and reduces chances of avascular necrosis (AVN) of femoral head.
    • Aspiration shows > 50,000 cells/mL and >75% polymorphoneutrophils in septic arthritis.
    • Culture of the aspirate is the gold standard for diagnosis.
    • Kocher Criterion:
      • To differentiate between septic arthritis and transient synovitis, the predictive value of four original Kocher criteria (fever, inability to bear weight, elevated serum white blood cell count, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate) must be present.
      • Non-weight-bearing on affected side
      • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate > 40
      • Fever > 38.5°C
      • White blood cell count >12,000
  • Septic Arthritis with Negative Cultures – Diagnostic Criterion (Morrey and Associates Criterion):

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment options include:
      • Arthrotomy (opening the joint capsule)
      • Surgical drainage (decompression)
      • Synovectomy
      • Antibiotics (2 weeks IV and 4 weeks oral)
    • Duration of antibiotics is same as osteomyelitis as usually focus is from the bone.
    • If signs of local sepsis do not abate and synovial fluid analysis does not move to normal within 2 days after treatment, open surgical drainage is indicated.
    • If the purulent fluid becomes too thick to aspirate, open surgical drainage is indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given statements in the question are all correct about the septic arthritis.

 

  • There is widening of joint space.
  • Staph aureus is the most common organism in young children and neonate.
  • Incision and drainage is frequently required to treat the infection.
  • Kocher criteria is used to differentiate septic arthritis from transient synovitis.

questions.text: As a researcher designing a clinical study, you are exploring methods to eliminate confounding variables, which can lead to spurious associations between the independent and dependent variables. Which of the following methods is NOT primarily used to eliminate confounders? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blinding

 

  • This method is used primarily to prevent bias in the conduct and interpretation of clinical research.
  • Blinding can be of participants, investigators, or those assessing outcomes, to ensure that the behaviors and evaluations are not influenced by knowledge of which treatment or intervention participants receive.
  • While blinding reduces bias, it does not specifically address the issue of confounding variables.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Randomization: By randomly assigning participants to different groups in a study, randomization aims to evenly distribute confounding variables across all groups, thus reducing their potential impact on the outcome. This helps ensure that any differences observed between groups can more reliably be attributed to the intervention itself rather than to external variables.

 

Option C. Restriction: This involves limiting the participants in a study to certain criteria, effectively isolating specific characteristics and reducing variation that could lead to confounding. For example, a study may restrict participants to a certain age range, gender, or health status to control for these variables.

 

Option D. Matching: Matching involves pairing participants in the treatment group with similar participants in the control group based on certain characteristics (e.g., age, sex, baseline health status). This technique helps to ensure that the treatment and control groups are comparable on these characteristics, thereby controlling for confounding variables related to them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blinding is used to remove Bias.

 

Confounding can be removed by:

 

  1. Matching (MC used /simplest)
  2. Randomisation (2nd Best Method)
  3. Restriction
  4. Stratification
  5. Statistical Modelling / Multivariate analysis (MVA)
  6. Stratified Randomization (Overall Best Method)

questions.text: As a public health expert, you are consulted about a series of outbreaks in a region that lacks significant prior vaccination campaigns. Given the imperative to contain the spread of disease and protect vulnerable populations, you are asked to prioritize a disease for which mass vaccination would provide the most immediate and impactful reduction in transmission. Which of the following diseases would most benefit from such an intervention? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polio

 

  • Mass immunization is one of the best strategies to deal with outbreak of poliomyelitis.
  • Outbreak response immunization (ORI): Following the Acute flaccid paralysis case investigation and stool specimen collection, ORI is organized in community.
  • Children aged 0-59 months are given one dose of OPV regardless of previous immunization (in the village/locality of the AFP case)
  • Travel history of the child with AFP may suggest additional places of stay where ORI should also be conducted
  • Atleast 500 children are vaccinated

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Cholera: In case of a cholera outbreak, the most effective response would be chemoprophylaxis for a household or a closed community and. Drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis is Tetracycline.

 

Option B. Typhoid: control in case of an outbreak includes health education, water quality and sanitation improvement, prevent carriers from handling food, milk or water from others, and training of health professionals in diagnosis and treatment. Vaccination is not advised for typhoid outbreaks.

 

Option D. Tetanus: Tetanus is not a communicable disease in the traditional sense as it does not spread from person to person. Instead, it is caused by bacteria entering the body through wounds. Thus, mass vaccination for tetanus isn't typically utilized as an outbreak response but is important in routine immunization schedules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Polio, due to its potential for rapid spread and severe outcomes, along with the availability of an effective and easily administered vaccine, makes it the most critical focus for a mass vaccination campaign in response to an outbreak.
  • This strategy not only protects individuals but also aids in the global effort to eradicate polio.

 

Additional Information

 

Outbreak response for Measles includes

 

  1. Isolation for 7 days after the onset of rash
  2. Immunization of the contacts within 2 days of exposure (if vaccine is contraindicated, immunoglobulins should be given within 3-4 days of exposure)
  3. Prompt immunization at the beginning of an epidemic is essential to limit the spread.

choices.text: USG Doppler of right upper limb

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a smoking history of 36 pack years presents with numbness and weakness of the right hand and arm and tingling in the fingers. There is associated drooping of the right eye with miosis. What is the IOC for the patient? (AIIMS 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. MRI

 

Explanation:

 

  • The clinical presentation is pointing towards a diagnosis of right Pancoast or superior sulcus tumor involving the brachial plexus and sympathetic plexus.
  • Radiographic findings include an apical mass or unilateral or asymmetrical apical pleural thickening (“apical cap”).
  • Asymmetry in the thickness of an apical cap exceeding 5 mm is considered suggestive.
  • MRI is more accurate than CT in diagnosing brachial plexus and sympathetic plexus involvement, and define the relationship of the tumor to great vessels and the brachial plexus.

 

Regional spread can cause:

 

  • Tracheal obstruction

  • Esophageal compression with dysphagia

  • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness

  • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea

  • Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner's syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chest X-ray: While helpful for initial evaluation, it lacks the detail required to assess soft tissue involvement and the exact extent of the tumor.

 

Option B. USG Doppler of right upper limb: Useful for vascular assessment but not suitable for visualizing intrathoracic tumors or their impact on neural structures.

 

Option C. HRCT: High-resolution CT can identify the presence of an apical mass but does not provide as detailed visualization of soft tissue and neurovascular involvement as MRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected Pancoast tumor, MRI is preferred over other imaging modalities for its superior ability to delineate the extent of tumor involvement with the brachial plexus and sympathetic plexus, critical for accurate diagnosis and treatment planning.

questions.text: There was outbreak of MRSA in the hospital, and it was found that a nurse of NICU had MRSA colonization of anterior nares. What is the best treatment?(INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Topical mupirocin

 

  • Anterior nares are the most common site of colonization in carrier state of MRSA.
  • Mupirocin (2% topical cream) is DOC for MRSA carriers. Other drug that can be used is topical Bacitracin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oral Vancomycin: Vancomycin is typically used for systemic MRSA infections and is administered intravenously due to poor oral absorption. It is not appropriate for eradicating nasal colonization.

 

Option C. Inhaled colistin: Colistin is used for multi-drug-resistant gram-negative infections and is not indicated for MRSA, especially not for nasal colonization.

 

Option D. IV cefazolin: Cefazolin is a first-generation cephalosporin effective against methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) but not MRSA. It is also not suitable for treating nasal colonization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For MRSA colonization in the anterior nares, topical mupirocin is the best treatment due to its targeted action, efficacy, and minimal systemic side effects.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/809

questions.text: EEG pattern given below is suggestive of which of the following diseases? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Creutzfeldt- Jakob Disease

 

Periodic sharp wave complexes occurring every 1 second is usually seen in sporadic CJD.

 

Spongiform encephalopathy characterized by rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, akinetic mutism.

 

**Startle myoclonus is very peculiar feature observed in CJD.

 

Signs on MRI:

 

  • Sporadic CJD: 80-90% - Cortical-Ribbon sign on MRI.
  • Variant CJD: Hockey-stick appearance on MRI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic encephalopathies show triphasic wave (Negative-positive-negative waves).

 

Option B. GTCS shows high voltage, spike wave discharges in all leads.

 

Option D. HSV show periodic lateralized epileptiform discharge (PLED) arising from temporal lobes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease is associated with distinct EEG findings that are crucial for its diagnosis. Understanding the typical EEG patterns along with clinical presentation and advanced imaging can aid in the early and accurate diagnosis of this rapidly progressive and fatal disease.

 

Reference - Harrison 21e/Neurology/Dementia/chap 438/12420

questions.text: Which among the following is a subcutaneous fungal agent? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sporothrix schenckii

 

Sporothrix schenckii is a subcutaneous fungal agent. It is the causative agent of sporotrichosis, commonly known as "rose gardener's disease." This fungal infection occurs when the fungus, which lives in soil, plants, and decaying vegetation, enters the skin through small cuts or punctures. The infection usually starts as a small nodule at the site of entry and can spread along lymphatic channels, causing nodular lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryptococcus neoformans: This fungus is typically associated with systemic infections, particularly cryptococcal meningitis, in immunocompromised individuals, especially those with HIV/AIDS. It is not classified as a subcutaneous fungal agent.

 

Option B. Histoplasma capsulatum: This is a systemic mycotic agent that causes histoplasmosis, a respiratory infection that can disseminate in immunocompromised individuals. It is not a subcutaneous fungal agent.

 

Option D. Talaromyces marneffei: Formerly known as Penicillium marneffei, this fungus causes systemic mycoses, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those with HIV/AIDS. It is endemic in Southeast Asia and not classified as a subcutaneous fungal agent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

The term systemic mycoses is used here to refer to infections caused by organisms in the following genera: Blastomyces, Coccidioides, Paracoccidioides, Histoplasma, and Cryptococcus.

choices.text: It is called Argyl Robertson pupil.
﻿﻿﻿The vision is normal in right eye.
﻿﻿﻿Seen in optic neuritis, the pupil can paradoxically dilate in the both eyes.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the image given below: (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Seen in optic neuritis, the pupil can paradoxically dilate in the both eyes.

 

The image suggests Marcus Gunn pupil, which is seen in optic neuritis. The right eye is affected, while the left eye is normal.

 

  • ﻿﻿The condition is named after the scientist, Robert Marcus Gunn who belongs to Scotland.

 

Presentation:

 

  • Pupil appears to dilate when light is shone on it (this is also known as a relative afferent pupillary defect or RAPD).
  • The affected pupil constricts less than the unaffected pupil when light is shone on it.
  • The affected pupil may even dilate when light is removed from it (this is known as the Marcus Gunn pupil phenomenon).

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Diagnosed by a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) test, also called swinging flash light test, which involves comparing the pupillary response of the affected eye to that of the unaffected eye when a light is shone on them.
  • In the swinging flashlight test, a light is alternately shone into the left and right eyes. A normal response would be equal constriction of both pupils, regardless of which eye the light is directed at. This indicates an intact direct and consensual pupillary light reflex. When the test is performed in an eye with an afferent pupillary defect, light directed in the affected eye will cause only mild constriction of both pupils (due to decreased response to light from the afferent defect), while light in the unaffected eye will cause a normal constriction of both pupils (due to an intact efferent path, and an intact consensual pupillary reflex). Thus, light shone in the affected eye will produce less pupillary constriction than light shone in the unaffected eye.

 

Management:

 

  • Treatment involves addressing the underlying cause of the afferent pupillary defect, such as optic neuritis or a retinal detachment.
  • In cases where the underlying cause cannot be treated, the patient may need to wear an eye patch to alleviate symptoms caused by the unequal pupillary responses.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is called Argyl Robertson pupil: Incorrect, as Argyl Robertson pupils are associated with neurosyphilis and react to accommodation but not to light.

 

Option B. Both eyes are abnormal: Incorrect, the image specifically shows an abnormal reaction in one eye compared to a normal reaction in the other.

 

Option C. The vision is normal in the right eye: Incorrect as it is not specifically addressed in the image or scenario provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Marcus Gunn pupil, indicative of an RAPD, is a significant sign of optic nerve dysfunction often seen in conditions like optic neuritis. Detecting this early through the swinging flashlight test can guide further diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.

questions.text: A patient who receives recurrent transfusions for thalassemia develops fever and chills during this time. There is no evidence of hemolysis. Which of the following measures can decrease the rate of transfusion reactions? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leuko-reduced RBCs

 

The given scenario is suggestive of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR). Such reactions can be prevented by using leuko-reduced RBCs

 

Fever (elevation of temperature by 1º C or 2º F) , chills, or rigors resulting from cytokines released by leukocyte in transfused red cell or platelet components is called as non-hemolytic febrile transfusion reaction. It is a diagnosis of exclusion, as hemolytic and septic reactions can present similarly.

 

Prevention –

 

  1. Pre-storage leukoreduction
  2. Acetaminophen if persistent fever
  3. Routine pretreatment with acetaminophen
  4. Use of platelet additive solution
  5. Plasma reduced or washed products if severe reactions
  6. Restrictive transfusion approach in high-risk patients

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antibiotics: Antibiotics are not used to prevent transfusion reactions. They are used to treat bacterial infections and would not be effective in preventing FNHTR, which is not caused by bacterial contamination.

 

Option C. Irradiation: Irradiation of blood products is used to prevent transfusion-associated graft-versus-host disease (TA-GvHD), a different type of transfusion reaction, but it does not prevent FNHTR.

 

Option D. Washed RBCs: Washing RBCs removes plasma proteins and is used to prevent allergic reactions in patients with a history of severe allergic transfusion reactions, but it is not specifically aimed at preventing FNHTR. However, washed products can be used if the FNHTR is severe or recurrent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leuko-reduced RBCs are the preferred method to reduce the risk of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTR), especially in patients requiring frequent transfusions like those with thalassemia.

 

  • FNHTRs are commonly due to cytokines released from donor leukocytes or recipient antibodies against donor leukocytes.
  • Leukoreduction removes most white blood cells from the blood product, thereby:
    • Reducing cytokine accumulation
    • Lowering risk of FNHTRs
    • Also helps prevent HLA alloimmunization and CMV transmission

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are adverse effect of SGLT2 inhibitors? (AIIMS MAY 2019)

 

1. Ketoacidosis

2. Urosepsis

3. Fournier’s gangrene

4. Angioedema
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1, 2 and 3 are correct

 

SGLT-2 INHIBITORS

 

  • Sodium Glucose Transporter 2 (also called SGLT2)  is a transporter for reabsorption of glucose and Na+. It is present in PCT of nephrons. Drug inhibiting this transporter are Canagliflozin, Dapagliflozin, Empagliflozin, Ertugliflozin etc.
  • By inhibiting the reabsorption of glucose, these drugs result in glucosuria. This can result in urinary tract infections (including Urosepsis) and genital tract infections like Fournier’s gangrene.
  • If used in type 1 diabetes, these decrease the blood sugar by causing glucosuria. The patient usually decreases the dose of insulin or may altogether stop using insulin as blood sugar levels are within required range. However, type 1 diabetes has absolute insulin deficiency. Insulin not only controls blood sugar but is also required for metabolism of ketone bodies. If the person stops using insulin, it may result in Ketoacidosis. Hence, SGLT-2 inhibitors are contra-indicated in Type 1 diabetes mellitus.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Angioedema: Angioedema is not a recognized adverse effect of SGLT2 inhibitors. This condition is more commonly associated with other drug classes, such as ACE inhibitors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary adverse effects of SGLT2 inhibitors include ketoacidosis, urosepsis, and Fournier's gangrene, while angioedema is not associated with these medications.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/301

questions.text: A 68-year-old female is admitted to the hospital with complaints of vomiting and abdominal distention. A nasogastric (NG) tube is inserted to decompress the stomach. However, the patient remains conscious and alert during the procedure. What is the best position to place the patient in during the insertion of the NG tube? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sitting with neck flexion

 

This is the best position for a conscious patient during Ryle's tube insertion. Sitting allows for better alignment of the upper gastrointestinal tract, making it easier to guide the tube through the esophagus and into the stomach. Neck flexion helps align the crico-pharynx with the Ryle’s tube, reducing faulty tracheal insertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of Ryle's tube is sitting with neck flexion.

 

Confirmation of the correct position of RT is done by:

 

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • Aspiration of gastric contents
  • X-ray chest + upper abdomen

 

The approximate length of the Ryle’s tube is 120-125 cm. There are 4 markings on the tube which indicates the traversing of the tube through various parts of the stomach

 

  1. 40 cm - Tube has traversed cardia of the stomach
  2. 50 cm - Tube has traversed body of the stomach
  3. 60 cm - Tube has traversed pylorus
  4. 70 cm - Tube has traversed duodenum

 

The length of tube to be inserted is calculated by measuring the distance between nose-tip of ear lobule-xiphoid (N-E-X rule).

choices.text: Cell membrane blebs and loss of microvilli
Nuclear changes like pyknosis and karyolysis

questions.text: Which is the most important light microscopic feature of irreversible cell injury? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nuclear changes like pyknosis and karyolysis

 

The most important light microscopic features of irreversible cell injury are nuclear changes. These changes are indicative of cell death and include:

 

  • Pyknosis: The nucleus shrinks and becomes dense, with chromatin condensing into a solid, darkly staining mass.
  • Karyorrhexis: The pyknotic nucleus fragments into smaller pieces.
  • Karyolysis: The nuclear fragments dissolve and fade, leading to the eventual loss of the nucleus.

 

These nuclear changes are hallmark signs of irreversible cell damage and cell death, distinguishing them from reversible changes such as cellular swelling or detachment of ribosomes from the endoplasmic reticulum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amorphous densities in mitochondria: These changes are often seen in irreversible cell injury, particularly in the context of mitochondrial dysfunction, but nuclear changes are more definitive indicators of irreversible damage.

 

Option B. Cell membrane blebs and loss of microvilli: These features are associated with reversible cell injury, not irreversible injury. They indicate cellular swelling and loss of structural integrity but do not signify cell death.

 

Option C. Ribosomal detachment from endoplasmic reticulum: This is also a feature of reversible cell injury, indicating disruption in protein synthesis, but it does not define irreversible injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyknosis, karyorrhexis, and karyolysis on light microscopy are signs of irreversible cell injury.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a patient who presents with flaccid bullous lesions affecting both the oral cavity and the skin, as shown in the provided image, and exhibits acantholytic cells on Tzanck smear? (AIIMS May 2019
questions.solution:
Ans B) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

Flaccid lesions, mucosal involvement, and the presence of acantholytic cells are suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris.

 

The production of antibodies, specifically those against Desmoglein 3, is seen in Pemphigus vulgaris. Desmoglein 1 antibodies are also occasionally associated. Usually, the antibodies are IgG antibodies. The skin and mucosa's basal and suprabasal layers contain the majority of Desmoglein 3.

 

The patients, therefore, present with flaccid bullae over the skin and due to Desmoglein 3 involvement, mucosal involvement can also be seen. Oral mucosa is commonly affected. Other areas where ulceration can be seen are conjunctiva, nasopharynx, larynx, etc.

 

Cutaneous lesions are more common over the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus foliaceus: Autoantibodies are seen against only Desmoglein 1, not against DsG 3, so there is no mucosal involvement in pemphigus foliaceus.

 

Option C. Dermatitis herpetiformis presents with multiple small Papulo-vesicles, which are extremely itchy and it is a subepidermal blistering disorder, so acantholysis will not be seen.

 

Option D. Bullous Pemphigoid presents as Tense bullae, which can have an erythematous base (urticarial wheals) & it is a subepidermal blistering disorder, so acantholysis will not be seen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of flaccid bullous lesions affecting both the oral cavity and the skin, along with the observation of acantholytic cells on a Tzanck smear, is most consistent with a diagnosis of pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 50 Page no 50.1-50.8
