Harrisons principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 356

questions.text: Which of the following is not an intermediate filament? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tubulin

 

Tubulin is a part of microtubules and is not an intermediate filament.

 

The intermediate filaments comprise the major component of the cytoskeleton and consist of five major subgroups—vimentin, keratins, desmin, neurofilaments, and glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP)—and a small number of minor subgroups (e.g., nestin, peripherin).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vimentin: Vimentin is an intermediate filament protein commonly found in cells of mesenchymal origin. It helps maintain cellular integrity and provides resistance to stress.

 

Option C. Desmin: Desmin is an intermediate filament protein found predominantly in muscle cells. It is crucial for maintaining the structural integrity of muscle cells by linking the cytoskeletal network to the sarcomere.

 

Option D. Neurofilament: Neurofilaments are intermediate filaments found in neurons. They are important for maintaining the shape and strength of nerve cells and play a role in the conduction of nerve impulses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tubulin is not an intermediate filament; it is a protein that forms microtubules, which are essential for cell shape, motility, and division. Intermediate filaments, such as vimentin, desmin, and neurofilaments, provide mechanical support and structural integrity to cells.

questions.text: Which of these is not an expected complication of Heller’s operation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gas bloat syndrome

 

  • The most common surgical procedure for achalasia is laparoscopic Heller myotomy, usually performed in conjunction with an anti-reflux procedure (partial fundoplication) to prevent post-operative acid reflux (option B). 
  • During the procedure, the anterior vagus nerve can be injured (option A). Forceful myotomy may also tear the mucosa and lead to perforation (Option D).
  • Gas bloat is seen after fundoplication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Injury to the vagus nerve: It can occur during dissection around the esophagus.

 

Option B. Acid reflux: It can occur especially if the myotomy is not combined with a partial fundoplication, since the LES is weakened.

 

Option D. Esophageal perforation: It can occur due to the delicate nature of the esophageal wall during the procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gas bloat syndrome is more commonly associated with Nissen fundoplication, a procedure for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
  • It occurs when patients are unable to burp, leading to bloating and discomfort from trapped gas.
  • Thus, gas bloat syndrome is not a complication of Heller’s myotomy.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion
Assertion is independently a true/correct statement but the Reason is independently an incorrect/false statement
Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement

questions.text:
Assertion: Distal pole of scaphoid is the most common carpal bone to undergo avascular necrosis.

 

Reason: Blood supply is retrograde from its distal to proximal end.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement

 

SCAPHOID FRACTURE

 

  • Scaphoid is the most commonly fractured bone in the carpus, in adult as well as children. 
  • Scaphoid fracture is seen most commonly in males between the ages of 15 and 30. 
  • Middle third (waist) fractures are most common accounting for 70% of scaphoid fractures > proximal pole fracture (20%) > distal pole fracture (10%), in adults and adolescents.
  • Distal pole avulsion type fracture is most common fracture type in children.
  • Salient Features:
    • Most of the blood supply to the scaphoid enters distally, so blood supply of scaphoid diminishes proximally. 
    • This accounts for the fact that 1% of distal third, 20% of middle third, 40% of proximal third and 100% of proximal pole fractures result in avascular necrosis or non-union of the proximal fragment.
  • Complication: Non-union > Avascular necrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The proximal pole of scaphoid is the most common bone to undergo avascular necrosis. 
  • This is because the blood supply to the scaphoid is retrograde, from its distal end to its proximal end. 
  • At the proximal end, the blood supply diminishes. 
  • This accounts for increased chances of avascular necrosis or non-union of the proximal fragment when the proximal pole of the scaphoid is fractured.

questions.text: You are posted as a medical officer in a rural Primary Health Centre (PHC) for your rural internship. As part of your duties, you are required to oversee and understand the roles and responsibilities of ASHA working in your region. Which of the following tasks is NOT traditionally a responsibility of the ASHA worker? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malaria slide preparation

 

  • ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist) workers play a crucial role in community health, especially in rural areas of India.
  • Their responsibilities are extensive but focused primarily on preventive and promotive healthcare. But not the malaria slides preparation.
  • Preparation of malaria slides is the responsibility of health worker male.

 

Other 3 options are ASHA responsibilities

 

Educational Objective:

 

Responsibilities of ASHA:

 

  • Create awareness on health and its social determinants and mobilize the community towards local health planning and increased utilization and accountability of the existing health services
  • Promote good health practices and provide a minimum package of curative care as appropriate and feasible and make timely referrals
  • Provide information on determinants of health, on existing health services and the need for timely utilization of services
  • Counsel women on aspects of reproductive and child health
  • Mobilize the community and facilitate them in accessing health and health related services provided by the government
  • Act as a depot holder for essential provisions like ORS, IFA tablets, chloroquine, disposable delivery kits, oral pills & condoms
  • Provide primary medical care and act as DOTS provider
  • Help develop a comprehensive village health plan
  • Arrange escort/accompany pregnant women and children requiring treatment/ admission to nearest health facility
  • Be a part of JSY (Janani Suraksha Yojana) and help reduce MMR

 

Additional Information

 

Proposed population norm: 2 ASHA worker per 1000 population

 

ASHA is expected to act as,

 

  • Interface between: Community and Health care system
  • Bridge between: ANM and village
  • Accountable to: Panchayat

 

Selection criteria of ASHA:

 

  • Woman resident of local community
  • Preferably 25 – 45 years age
  • Literate with formal education up to 10th class (Relaxable for Tribal areas)

 

Indicators for Monitoring and Evaluation of ASHA’s Work

 

  • Process indicators:
    • No. of ASHAs selected
    • No. of ASHAs trained
    • % ASHAs attending review meeting after 1 year
  • Outcome indicators:
    • % newborns weighed and families counseled
    • % deliveries with skilled assistance
    • % institutional deliveries
    • % JSY claims made to ASHA
    • Completed immunized 12-23 months age group
    • % unmet need in BPL
    • % fever cases received chloroquine within 1 weeks in endemic area
  • Impact indicators:
    • Infant mortality rate (IMR)
    • Child malnutrition rates
    • No. of cases of TB/Leprosy detected as compared to last year.

questions.text: The following instrument is used for……:  (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PAP smear

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image shown is that of Ayre's spatula which is used for preparing PAP smear.
  • It is used to scrape the squamocolumnar junction of the cervix while preparing a Pap smear.
  • A cytobrush is used to take endocervical samples
  • The smear is fixed with 95% ethanol

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. VIA: This is Visual Inspection under Acetic Acid. This is done by applying acetic acid on the cervix. Any acetowhite area is suspicious for dysplasia. It is done in low resource settings.

 

Option B. VILI: Visual inspection under Lugol Iodine: This is done by applying Lugol’s iodine on the cervix. A dysplastic area will not take up iodine. It is also done in low resource settings.

 

 

Option D. Colposcopy: This is a magnified view of the cervix. It is done in patients with abnormal pap smear/ HPV +Ve/ VIA +ve or VILI +ve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ayre's spatula is used for preparing a Pap smear by scraping cells from the cervix for cytological examination.

 

Ref: Page no 325, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Providing services for unmarried mothers

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits a clinic in Mumbai for a consultation about family planning. She discusses various options and services with her healthcare provider. During the conversation, she asks about additional health screenings included in family planning services. Which of the following screenings is NOT typically included as part of family planning services in India? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Screening for HIV infection

 

  • Family planning services aim to support individuals and couples in managing their reproductive health, but not all health screenings are integrated into these services:
  • Screening for HIV infection: This screening, while crucial for overall health and particularly important in prenatal care to prevent mother-to-child transmission, is generally conducted as part of broader sexual health services rather than within the narrower scope of family planning services.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Screening for cervical cancer: This is typically included because it directly relates to reproductive health and can impact a woman’s long-term health and fertility.

 

Option B. Providing services for unmarried mothers: This includes counseling and support, reflecting a comprehensive approach to reproductive health care that supports all individuals, regardless of marital status.

 

Option D. Providing adoption services: Part of family planning services that helps individuals and couples prepare for parenthood, including the option of adoption, aligning with the broad goals of family planning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Family planning is not synonymous with birth control only. A WHO Expert Committee (1970) recommends that family planning includes in its’ purview:

 

  • Proper spacing and limitation of birth
  • Advice on sterility
  • Education for parenthood
  • Sex education
  • Screening for pathological conditions related to the reproductive system (e.g., cervical cancer)
  • Genetic counselling
  • Premarital consultation and examination
  • Pregnancy tests
  • Marriage counselling
  • Preparation of couples for the first child
  • Providing services to unmarried mothers
  • Teaching home economics and nutrition
  • Providing adoption services

questions.text: You are participating in a research discussion about the best approach to study the circadian changes in the fat content of expressed breast milk among mothers of preterm babies. The primary aim is to observe the variations over time and establish a temporal relationship. Which of the following study designs would be most suitable to achieve this objective? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prospective Cohort

 

  • The study design of choice for the given scenario is a prospective study.
  • In the given situation, the study cohort would comprise of mothers with preterm infants, whereas the control cohort would include mothers with full-term babies.
  • To investigate the diurnal fluctuations in the fat composition of expressed breast milk, samples of breast milk would be collected at designated time points each day.
  • These samples would be monitored over the course of multiple days and subjected to analysis. This research constitutes a prospective study.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ambispective Cohort: An Ambispective cohort includes both retrospective and prospective cohort study. This case scenario will not fit in retrospective study

 

Option C. Case control: Case-control study is also a retrospective study.

 

Option D. Cross sectional: Cross-sectional study is used to figure out the prevalence of a disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A prospective cohort study is the optimal design for research that needs to observe how a variable changes over time and establish a chronological sequence of events or effects. This method will allow for the systematic collection of breast milk samples at various times to analyze changes in fat content relative to the time of day in a defined sample of mothers with preterm infants.

choices.text: COV of DBP is more than Vitamin D
COV of Vitamin D is more than DBP
Both DBP and Vitamin D have equal variability
It cannot be ascertained from information provided

questions.text: During your clinical rotations, you are reviewing data from an experiment that examined the correlation between Vitamin D levels and diastolic blood pressure (DBP). The experiment aimed to ascertain the variability within two distinct sample sets. Based on the findings, the average DBP was noted to be 110, with an associated standard deviation of 11. Similarly, the mean Vitamin D level was observed to be 18, with a standard deviation of 3. With reference to the coefficient of variation (COV), which statement accurately represents the collected data? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) COV of Vitamin D is more than DBP

 

Coefficient of Variation (COV)

 

  • Is a measure used to compare relative variability
  • Is a unit-free measure to compare dispersion of one variable with another
  • Is SD expressed as percentage of mean

 

 

Calculation -

 

COV of DBP = 11/110 = 0.1

 

COV of Vitamin D = 3/18 = 0.166

 

Hence, COV of Vitamin D is more than DBP

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The coefficient of variation provides a useful comparison of variability across different datasets.
  • In this case, the higher COV for Vitamin D indicates a greater relative variation compared to DBP, highlighting important considerations for researchers analyzing the impacts or associations involving these variables.

questions.text: The wrong statement regarding the levator ani muscle is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Attached to pelvic brim

 

Explanation:

 

The levator ani is not attached to the pelvic brim. Instead, it originates from the posterior surface of the body of the pubis, the obturator fascia, and the ischial spine. It then inserts into the coccyx, anococcygeal ligament, and walls of the prostate or vagina, rectum, and anal canal. The incorrect notion about its attachment to the pelvic brim is a common misconception.

 

  • Insertion :- The coccyx and the anococcygeal raphe or ligament.
  • Nerve supply:- The branches of the anterior rami of sacral nerves S3 and S4 and the perineal branch of the pudendal nerve.
  • Supports and raises the pelvic floor.
  •  Consists of the puborectalis, pubococcygeus, and iliococcygeus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supports pelvic viscera: This statement is correct. The levator ani, along with other pelvic floor muscles, forms a supportive sling for the pelvic organs such as the bladder, uterus (in females), and rectum. This muscular support is essential for maintaining continence and facilitating functions such as micturition and defecation.

 

Option B. Converge downwards and medially: This statement is also correct. The fibers of the levator ani muscles, especially from the pubococcygeus, tend to converge towards the midline and run in a downward direction. This orientation provides the necessary support to the pelvic organs and creates a muscular barrier between the pelvic cavity and the perineum.

 

Option C. Consists of iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus: This statement is partially true. The levator ani is made up of three parts: the puborectalis, pubococcygeus, and iliococcygeus. All three parts contribute to the function and support provided by the levator ani. Thus, while the statement includes two components of the levator ani, it omits the puborectalis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pelvic brim is not connected to the levator ani muscle. It originates from the ischial spine, levator ani's arcus tendinous (a thickened section of the obturator fascia, and the pubic body.

questions.text: A case of gestational trophoblastic neoplasm is detected to have metastasis in the lungs. It is considered as stage? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) III

 

Gestational trophoblastic neoplasms (GTN) are classified into stages based on their extent of spread:

 

  • Stage I: The disease is confined to the uterus.
  • Stage II: The disease has spread outside the uterus but remains confined to the genital structures.
  • Stage III: The disease has metastasized to the lungs, which is a significant indicator of progression beyond the local genital structures.
  • Stage IV: The disease has spread to other distant sites beyond the lungs, such as the liver or brain.

 

Since the case involves metastasis specifically to the lungs, it falls into Stage III, which is characterized by such pulmonary involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metastasis to the lungs in gestational trophoblastic neoplasm is classified as Stage III.

 

Ref: Page no 364, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition.

questions.text: Identify the plant which produces a toxin of abuse potential? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Erythroxylum coca

 

The plant in the picture is Erythroxylum coca, which can be identified by red berries.

 

Cocaine, a substance with significant abuse potential, is derived from this plant.

 

Other Options

 

Option B Datura: It can be identified by:

 

  • Green color fruit with sharp spines
  • Large trumpet shaped flowers

 

Datura flower and fruit images shown below:

 

 

Option C Digitalis Purpura: It can be identified by: 

 

  • Leaves are spirally arranged and covered with gray-white hairs, imparting a woolly texture.
  • Flowers are arranged in an elongated cluster, and each flower is tubular and pendent.

 

Digitalis purpura Flower and Plant images shown below:

 

 

Option D Cannabis: It can be identified by: 

 

  • Leaves have a digitate shape, with serrated edges. Leaflets are arranged opposite each other along the stem and are usually symmetrically aligned.

 

Cannabis leaves images shown below:

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Cocaine is obtained from Erythroxylum coca, which can be identified by following features:

 

  • Leaves: Characteristic of the leaf is an areolated portion bounded by two longitudinal curved lines, one line on each side of the midrib.
  • Flowers are small, and disposed in little clusters on short stalks.
  • Red Berries: The flowers mature into red berries.

questions.text: A child presents with brown-colored urine and oliguria for the last 3 days. He has mild facial and pedal edema. His blood pressure is 126/90. He has 2+ proteinuria with >100 red cells/HPF and a few granular casts. His creatinine is 0.9, urea is 56. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PSGN

 

  • The clinical picture points to post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. (PSGN).
  • PSGN is characterised by sudden onset of gross hematuria, edema, hypertension, and renal insufficiency.
  • Most children recover entirely from hematuria and proteinuria within 3-6 weeks of the beginning of nephritis after a throat infection with nephritogenic strains of group A -hemolytic streptococci. However, between 3 and 10% of children may have persistent microscopic hematuria, non-nephrotic proteinuria, or hypertension.

 

Light microscopy reveals larger, pale glomeruli with diffuse mesangial proliferation and an increase in the mesangial matrix in PSGN. In the early stages, polymorph neutrophils (PMN) infiltrate.

 

Immunofluorescence: "Lumpy-bumpy" IgG and complement deposits on the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) and

 

Electron microscopy- humps are seen on epithelial side of glomerular basement membrane

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nephrolithiasis: Nephrolithiasis will have features of kidney stones in ultrasound. Symptoms: dysuria, hypogastric pain, hematuria & repeated urinary infections.

 

Option C. Posterior Urethral Valve: this is one of the cause of distal urinary tract obstruction in boys. Clinical features, abnormal urinary stream, dribbling, palpable bladder & recurrent UTI.

 

Option D. Minimal change disease: Blood pressure of the patient will be normal. Electron microscopy shows nonspecific obliteration of epithelial foot processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sudden onset of gross hematuria, edema, hypertension, and renal insufficiency are indicative of PSGN.

questions.text: The given instrument is used in: (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

The instrument shown is a Doyen's retractor, which is specifically used in cesarean sections. It plays a crucial role during the surgical procedure by retracting the bladder to provide proper exposure of the lower uterine segment. This retraction helps in ensuring a clear view and access to the uterus while minimizing the risk of bladder injury. The Doyen's retractor is used once the utero-vesical fold of peritoneum is opened and the bladder is dissected away from the lower uterine segment. It holds the bladder away from the site of the uterine incision, facilitating a safer and more efficient cesarean section.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vaginal hysterectomy: Involves the removal of the uterus through the vaginal canal and typically uses different types of retractors and instruments designed for vaginal access, not the Doyen's retractor.

 

Option C. Manchester operation: This is a surgical procedure used to correct uterovaginal prolapse and does not involve the use of Doyen's retractor.

 

Option D. Fothergill's surgery: This is performed for uterovaginal prolapse and uses different instruments tailored for vaginal repairs, not the Doyen's retractor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Doyen's retractor is used during cesarean sections to retract the bladder and prevent bladder injury while providing exposure of the lower uterine segment.

 

Ref: Page no 751, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

choices.text: Transfusion related circulatory overload

questions.text: A CKD patient had to undergo dialysis and his Hb was 5.2gm/dL. So two blood transfusions were to be given. The first bag was completed in 2 hours. The second was started and in the midway, he developed shortness of breath and hypertension. Vitals Were BP - 180/120 mmHg and pulse rate - 110 min. What is the cause? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transfusion related circulatory overload

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO).

 

Transfusion associated circulatory overload includes any four of the following occurring within 6 h of a blood transfusion - acute respiratory distress, tachycardia, increased blood pressure (BP), acute or worsening pulmonary edema and evidence of a positive fluid balance.

 

TACO may occur due to rapid or excess transfusion of red cell preparations or plasma products.

 

Prevented is by slow transfusion at the rate of 1 to 2 ml of blood/kg of body weight per hour. Diuretics are also used if necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic: Allergic reactions to blood transfusions usually present with urticaria (hives), pruritus (itching), and sometimes anaphylaxis, but do not typically cause the significant hypertension and tachycardia seen in this case.

 

Option C. Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI): TRALI is characterized by acute onset of non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, leading to respiratory distress and hypoxemia during or within 6 hours of transfusion. However, TRALI typically presents with hypotension or normal blood pressure, not the significant hypertension seen here.

 

Option D. Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction: This reaction typically presents with fever, chills, and rigors, but does not cause the hemodynamic instability (hypertension and tachycardia) seen in TACO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transfusion-related circulatory overload (TACO) is a potential complication of blood transfusion, particularly in patients with predisposing conditions like CKD. It presents with respiratory distress, hypertension, and tachycardia and can be prevented by careful monitoring and slow transfusion.

choices.text: Risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with the degree of thrombocytosis
It is protective against H. pylori infection
Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation
Acute myeloid leukemia is the most common cause of mortality

questions.text: Which of the following statements about polycythemia vera is true? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation

 

Polycythemia vera (PV) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by the overproduction of red blood cells. It is commonly associated with a mutation in the JAK2 gene, which can also affect other cell types, including mast cells. Activation of these cells can lead to the release of histamine, which is thought to contribute to the itching or pruritus often experienced by patients, particularly after warm baths or showers.

 

Myeloproliferative neoplasms include PCV, CML, and PMF.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with the degree of thrombocytosis: Incorrect. Although thrombocytosis is present in polycythemia vera, thrombosis risk correlates more significantly with leukocytosis and the presence of JAK2 mutation rather than solely with thrombocytosis.

 

Option B. It is protective against H. pylori infection: Incorrect. There is no evidence to suggest that polycythemia vera provides protection against H. pylori infection. Patients with PV actually may have an increased risk of gastrointestinal issues.

 

Option D. Acute myeloid leukemia is the most common cause of mortality: Incorrect. While patients with polycythemia vera do have an increased risk of transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML), the most common cause of mortality in these patients is thrombotic events such as heart attack or stroke.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Generalized pruritus in polycythemia vera, exacerbated by warmth or bathing, is a well-known symptom related to mast cell activation due to the JAK2 mutation. This mutation is a hallmark of the disease and leads to several systemic effects, including increased histamine release, which contributes to pruritus.

 

All MPN can develop AML, Myelofibrosis in the course of the disease.

questions.text: What is the most common pulmonary manifestation of SLE? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pleuritis with/without pleural effusion.

 

Pleuritis with or without pleural effusion is the most common pulmonary manifestation in patients with SLE. This condition reflects the systemic inflammatory nature of SLE, which frequently affects serous membranes including the pleura. Pleural involvement in SLE typically presents as an exudative pleural effusion, often characterized by pleuritic pain and effusion that can be detected by physical examination and imaging studies.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shrinking lung syndrome: is very rare occurring in 1% of patients. Some association with Anti-Ro/La antibodies seen. No correlation between disease activity, symptoms and antibodies.

 

Option B. Intra Alveolar hemorrhage and D. Interstitial inflammation: are not the most common presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleuritis with or without pleural effusion stands out as the most frequent pulmonary complication in SLE due to the disease’s propensity to inflame serous membranes. Accurate diagnosis and effective management of SLE and its pulmonary manifestations are crucial for improving quality of life and reducing morbidity in affected patients.

questions.text: True regarding the lesion of the structure marked by 5 the arrow is: (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Wrist drop

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked in the image is the radial nerve demonstrated in the cubital fossa. A lesion of the radial nerve leads to a wrist drop. Injury to the radial nerve leads to paralysis of the extensor muscles of the wrist and fingers. This results in an inability to extend the wrist and fingers actively, leading to the characteristic "wrist drop" appearance. The hand hangs flaccidly with the fingers flexed, and the person cannot extend them

 

 

Anterior view of the right cubital fossa:

 

The structures marked in the given image are:

 

  1. Branch of the median nerve to the brachialis muscle
  2. Biceps brachii muscle
  3. Brachialis muscle
  4. Lateral cutaneous nerve of fore arm
  5. Superficial branch of the radial nerve
  6. Brachioradialis muscle
  7. Flexor carpi ulnaris muscle
  8. Pronator teres muscle
  9. Brachial artery
  10. Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm
  11. Median nerve.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ape thumb deformity: This deformity is primarily associated with the median nerve lesion. It refers to an inability to oppose or flex the thumb due to weakness or paralysis of the thenar muscles (especially the opponens pollicis), which are innervated by the median nerve. This results in a flattened thenar eminence, giving the thumb an appearance reminiscent of an ape's thumb.

 

Option B. Claw hand: Claw hand, or "clawing" of the fingers, usually results from a combined ulnar and median nerve lesion. It is characterized by hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and flexion at the interphalangeal (IP) joints. It can also result from a high ulnar nerve lesion on its own. The claw hand deformity is not a typical consequence of radial nerve injury.

 

Option C. Claudication: Claudication refers to pain, cramping, or fatigue in muscles, typically the calves, during walking or exercise. It's a symptom of peripheral arterial disease, where there's reduced blood flow to the legs. This is not related to radial nerve injury.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Tigroid white matter on MRI imaging is seen in which of the following conditions? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease

 

Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease (PMD) is a rare, genetic, demyelinating disorder of the central nervous system characterized by a distinctive "tigroid" pattern on MRI. This pattern arises from the preservation of perivascular myelin in the brain's white matter, interspersed with areas of demyelination, creating a striped or tigroid appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pantothenate kinase deficiency: This condition is also known as PKAN (Pantothenate Kinase-Associated Neurodegeneration). It typically shows a characteristic MRI feature known as the "eye of the tiger" sign, which involves a specific pattern of iron deposition in the basal ganglia. The "eye of the tiger" sign appears due to a combination of hyperintense signal surrounded by a region of hypointensity on T2-weighted MRI images, reflecting iron accumulation and gliosis. This is distinct from the tigroid pattern seen in demyelinating diseases.

 

Option B. Neuroferritinopathy: Neuroferritinopathy is another disorder of iron metabolism that affects the brain, leading to iron accumulation, particularly in the basal ganglia. MRI findings in neuroferritinopathy typically do not include the tigroid pattern but may show abnormalities such as signal changes in the basal ganglia related to iron deposition. The imaging features here are more associated with iron accumulation rather than the patchy demyelination that produces the tigroid appearance.

 

Option D. Aceruloplasminemia: Aceruloplasminemia is a rare hereditary disorder characterized by iron accumulation in various tissues, including the brain. Similar to neuroferritinopathy, the primary MRI findings in aceruloplasminemia are related to iron deposition, particularly in the cerebellum and basal ganglia, and do not typically involve the tigroid pattern. Instead, the imaging might show evidence of iron accumulation without the specific changes associated with demyelination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease is a prototypical condition that displays a tigroid pattern on MRI. This appearance is due to the patchy preservation and destruction of myelin in the white matter, creating alternating areas of normal myelin and demyelination. This results in the characteristic striped or tigroid appearance on imaging studies, reflective of the disease’s impact on myelination.

questions.text: Clostridium difficile diarrhoea is most commonly associated with? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Aminopenicillins

 

  • Clostridium difficile diarrhea is a super-infection also called as Pseudomembranous colitis.
  • Most common cause is 3rd generation Cephalosporins
  • Other causes include Clindamycin, Aminopenicillins (Ampicillin and Amoxycillin), and Fluoroquinolones.
  • DOC for treatment of PMC is fidaxomicin now.
  • Stool transplant can also be done.
  • Monoclonal antibody against toxin of C.difficile is Bezlotoxumab.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aminoglycosides: These can also lead to C. difficile diarrhea, but they are less commonly the cause compared to aminopenicillins and third-generation cephalosporins.

 

Option C. Macrolides: Macrolides are less likely to cause C. difficile diarrhea compared to aminopenicillins, third-generation cephalosporins, clindamycin, and fluoroquinolones.

 

Option D. Carbapenems: Carbapenems are broad-spectrum antibiotics but are not commonly associated with C. difficile diarrhea. Their impact on the gut flora is less significant in this context compared to aminopenicillins and other antibiotics mentioned.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clostridium difficile diarrhea, also known as pseudomembranous colitis, is commonly associated with aminopenicillins such as ampicillin and amoxicillin. Treatment includes fidaxomicin and potentially stool transplants, with bezlotoxumab available as a monoclonal antibody against the toxin of C. difficile.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/744

questions.text:
True statements about fracture shaft of femur: (AIIMS MAY 2019)

 

  1. More commonly in elderly.
  2. Easily managed with Gallow’s traction in elderly.
  3. Associated with pulmonary complications.
  4. Intramedullary nailing is gold standard for management.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. c & d are correct

 

FRACTURE SHAFT FEMUR

 

  • Men are more likely to sustain a fracture between the ages of 15 to 35, while women begin to show a steady increase starting at age 60.
  • Men are more likely to sustain fracture from automobile accidents or other high-energy mechanisms.
  • Women are more likely to sustain an fracture from ground-level falls.
  • Automobile accidents are more prevalent in the younger population, while ground-level falls are more common in the elderly population, which is attributed to osteoporosis.
  • Treatment:

 

 

a. Management Plan of Fracture Shaft Femur in Adults: 

  1. Interlock intramedullary nailing currently is considered to be the treatment of choice for most femoral shaft fractures.
  2. External fixator is used in open fractures (open injuries).
  3. Delayed union is treated by dynamization of nail (removal of proximal or distal screws or both) and bone grafting.
  4. Non-union is treated by exchange nailing (i.e. introduction of large diameter reamed interlocking nail) and bone grafting.

 

b. Management Plan in children:

  1. Gallow’s traction: < 2 years of age and traction weight < 2 kg of weight can be used.
  2. Immediate or early spica casting is the treatment of choice in children <5 years of age for femoral fractures with < 2–3 cm of initial shortening, and stable fracture pattern.
  3. Femoral fractures with > 2-3 cm of shortening or marked instability, high probability of slipping of reduction and tight thigh swelling in 6 months to 5 years age group, who cannot be reduced with immediate spica casting, require 3-10 days of skin or skeletal traction before casting.
  4. Fixation by enders intramedullary flexible rods and plating can be used in children with multiple trauma, head injury, vascular compromise, floating knee injuries or multiple fracture, preferably in children > 6 years of age.

 

  • Complications:
    • Postoperative complications include fat emboli syndrome, pulmonary embolism, infection, osteomyelitis, malunion, nonunion, and hip and knee pain.
    • Nerve injuries are common and can be due to positioning as well as iatrogenic injury. Pudendal nerve injuries occur from positioning patients with a perineal post. The sciatic nerve can suffer injury in retrograde nailing with excessive traction of the lower extremity or surgical instruments. 
    • Vascular injury to the DFA or SFA can occur after penetration with instruments or implants.
    • Intraoperative fractures may occur, especially of the greater trochanter, the knee.
    • Malrotation is one of the most significant complications. Malrotation of greater than 14 degrees from neutral can alter gait mechanics and efficiency. Patients cope better with internal than with external malalignment.
    • Nonunion is a failure of the fracture to heal or lack of signs of healing for six months.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Femoral shaft fractures are more commonly seen in young males of age 15-35 years.
  • It is easily managed with intramedullary nailing in elderly.
  • It is most commonly associated with pulmonary complications like pulmonary embolism.
  • Intramedullary nailing is gold standard for management in adult patients.

choices.text: Suicide occurring at the time when the patient starts to recover
Suicide after taking low dose of drug

questions.text: Which of the following best describes paradoxical suicide? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Suicide occurring at the time when the patient starts to recover

 

Paradoxical suicide refers to the situation where a patient, who has been depressed and possibly suicidal, begins to show signs of improvement or recovery and then commits suicide. This paradox may occur because as the patient starts to recover, they regain some of their energy and motivation, which they might then use to act on their previously existing suicidal thoughts.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

About 2/3rd of patients with depression have suicidal ideation and 10-15% die by suicide. Patients with depressive disorders are at increased risk of suicide as they begin to improve and regain the energy needed to plan and carry out a suicide, this is known as Paradoxical suicide.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 366.

questions.text: Which of the following TCA cycle intermediate is a part of heme metabolism? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Succinyl CoA

 

TCA cycle is truly amphibolic (both catabolic and anabolic) in nature. Since various compounds enter into or leave from TCA cycle, it is sometimes called as “metabolic traffic circle”.

 

  • Succinyl CoA and Heme Synthesis:
    • Function: Succinyl CoA combines with glycine to form delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA), which is the first step in the synthesis of heme.
    • Enzyme Involved: The enzyme ALA synthase catalyzes this reaction in the mitochondria.
    • Importance: Heme is a vital component of hemoglobin, myoglobin, and various cytochromes involved in electron transport and drug metabolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha Ketoglutarate:

  • Function: Precursor for the synthesis of glutamate and subsequently other amino acids.
  • Relevance: Not directly involved in heme metabolism.

 

Option B. Fumarate:

  • Function: Intermediate in the TCA cycle, involved in the conversion of fumarate to malate.
  • Relevance: Not directly involved in heme metabolism.

 

Option D. Malate:

  • Function: Intermediate in the TCA cycle, involved in the conversion of malate to oxaloacetate.
  • Relevance: Not directly involved in heme metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Important anabolic reactions related with citric acid cycle are:

  1. Oxaloacetate is the precursor of aspartate
  2. Alpha ketoglutarate can be made into glutamate
  3. Succinyl CoA is used for synthesis of heme
  4. Mitochondrial citrate is transported to cytoplasm, where it is cleaved into acetyl CoA, which then is the starting point of fatty acid synthesis.

questions.text: Which immunoglobulin is elevated in a case of chronic allergy? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IgE

 

Immunoglobulin E (IgE) is specifically associated with allergic reactions and parasitic infections. In the context of chronic allergies, such as asthma, hay fever, and other allergic conditions, IgE levels are typically elevated. IgE binds to allergens and triggers histamine release from mast cells and basophils, leading to the symptoms of allergic reactions.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. IgA: IgA is primarily found in mucous membranes, secretions like tears, saliva, and colostrum, and plays a critical role in mucosal immunity.

 

Option B. IgM: IgM is the main antibody of primary immune responses and is effective at fixing complement. It is also found as a monomer on the surface of B cells.

 

Option D. IgG: IgG is the most abundant antibody in blood and extracellular fluid, providing the majority of antibody-based immunity against invading pathogens. It is the main antibody involved in secondary immune responses and can cross the placenta.

 

Educational objective

questions.text: What type of tinea is likely affecting the 10-year-old child who presents with patchy hair loss as shown in the image below, along with the presence of black dots in the areas of hair loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endothrix

 

The given clinical picture is suggestive of endothrix type of tinea capitis.

 

Tinea capitis is a dermatophyte infection primarily occurring in children.

 

Tinea capitis variants:

 

 

  • Ectothrix - Spores & fungus present outside the hair shaft.
  • Endothrix - Spores & fungi present inside the hair shaft.

 

 

 

Kerion:

 

  • Presents in Children with boggy swelling, easily pluckable hair, with regional lymphadenopathy.
  • It is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis.
  • The most common causative organisms of kerion are Zoophilic dermatophytes, T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes. In severe cases, there may be pus along with sinus formation.

 

 

  • Investigation: 10% KOH mount
  • Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum is Griseofulvin

 

Note: DOC for Trichophyton associated Tinea capitis - Terbinafine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of patchy hair loss with black dots in the areas of hair loss in a child is indicative of an endothrix type of tinea capitis, where the fungal spores are located inside the hair shaft, causing it to break at the scalp level.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.8, 32.38-32.40

choices.text: b, d and e only
c and e only
a and c only
Only e is correct

questions.text:
Mention the true statement/s about drug resistant malaria: (AIIMS May 2019)

 

  1. It is not present in India.
  2. Quinine with clindamycin or doxycycline is still effective treatment.
  3. Chloroquine with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine is effective.
  4. Artemether with lumefantrine is useful.
  5. Monotherapy with artemisinin derivatives is not useful due to high risk of recrudescence.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. b, d and e only

 

  • Plasmodium falciparum is now the most common cause of malaria as well as most common cause of drug resistant malaria in India (Option a is false)
  • DOC for multiple drug resistant P falciparum is artemisinin compounds, but they are short acting. The short action is responsible for recrudescence when used as monotherapy in malaria. So they are combined with long acting drugs (known as ACT; Artemisinin based Combination Therapy) like 
  • Artemether + Lumefantrine: DOC in North-Eastern states.
  • Artesunate + Sulfadoxine/Pyrimethamine: DOC all over India except NE states.
  • Artemisinin’s are contraindicated in first trimester of pregnancy; but can be given in second and third trimester.
  • So, if drug resistant malaria occurs in 1st trimester of pregnancy, DOC is Quinine. To reduce its toxicity, we commonly add clindamycin (in pregnancy and children) or doxycycline (in other patients).
  • Chloroquine is not effective in drug resistant malaria. So artesunate (not Chloroquine) is combined with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (Option c)  

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is not present in India. False. Drug-resistant malaria is present in India. Plasmodium falciparum, known for drug resistance, is a common cause of malaria in India.

 

Option C. Chloroquine with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine is effective. False. Chloroquine is not effective in drug-resistant malaria. Artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) are preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drug-resistant malaria in India is effectively treated with ACTs like Artemether with lumefantrine. Monotherapy with artemisinin derivatives is avoided due to the risk of recrudescence.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/876-877

questions.text: Most commonly implicated drug for causation of acute liver failure is? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Paracetamol

 

  • All the four drugs given Paracetamol, Valproate, Warfarin and Tetracyclines can cause hepatotoxicity. Paracetamol among these is the most common cause particularly in patients with liver disease and in alcoholics.
  • Paracetamol is the most common cause of acute liver failure in many countries, particularly in the context of overdose. It can cause severe hepatotoxicity, which can lead to acute liver failure, especially when taken in doses exceeding recommended levels or in individuals with certain risk factors (such as existing liver disease and chronic alcohol use etc.).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valproate: While valproate can cause hepatotoxicity, it is less commonly associated with acute liver failure compared to paracetamol. It is more frequently a concern in certain populations, such as young children and individuals on multiple anticonvulsants.

 

Option C. Warfarin: Warfarin is an anticoagulant and is not commonly associated with acute liver failure. Its primary risk is bleeding due to its anticoagulant effects.

 

Option D. Tetracycline: High doses of tetracycline, especially the older formulations, can cause liver toxicity, but it is not the most common drug causing acute liver failure. Tetracycline-induced liver injury is now relatively rare due to the decreased use of high-dose intravenous forms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paracetamol (acetaminophen) is the most common drug implicated in the causation of acute liver failure, especially in the context of overdose and in individuals with risk factors like existing liver disease and chronic alcohol use.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/223

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given serum electrophoresis image (pink)? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nephrotic syndrome

 

The given electrophoresis picture shows hypoalbuminemia and increased alpha-2 globulin, which is suggestive of nephrotic syndrome.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multiple myeloma: Multiple myeloma would typically present with a sharp, monoclonal spike in the gamma region (known as an M-spike or paraprotein spike) due to the overproduction of a single type of immunoglobulin by malignant plasma cells. This pattern is not seen in the provided electrophoresis image.

 

Option B. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis is generally associated with a chronic inflammatory response and can show a polyclonal increase in the gamma region due to chronic immune activation. However, it does not show the specific hypoalbuminemia and alpha-2 globulin increase seen in nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option C. Hepatic cirrhosis: In hepatic cirrhosis, the electrophoresis pattern often shows a polyclonal increase in the gamma region (polyclonal gammopathy), sometimes with a beta-gamma bridging pattern. This pattern is not consistent with the hypoalbuminemia and alpha-2 globulin increase observed in nephrotic syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The electrophoresis pattern showing hypoalbuminemia combined with an increase in alpha-2 globulin is most indicative of nephrotic syndrome, reflecting the characteristic loss of albumin and retention of larger plasma proteins in this condition.

questions.text: What does this Cardio-Tocography show?  (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Deceleration

 

Explanation:

 

The Cardio-Tocography (CTG) in question shows decelerations, which are characterized by a drop in the fetal heart rate (FHR) by at least 15 beats per minute (bpm) lasting for at least 15 seconds.

 

Types of Decelerations on CTG:

 

  1. Early Deceleration:
    • The nadir (lowest point) of the deceleration corresponds with the peak of the uterine contraction.
    • Caused by head compression during contractions.
    • Commonly observed in the second stage of labor.
  2. Late Deceleration:
    • The nadir of the deceleration occurs after the peak of the contraction.
    • Indicative of uteroplacental insufficiency, which can lead to fetal distress or hypoxia.
    • Considered an ominous sign and requires prompt evaluation and intervention.
  3. Variable Deceleration:
    • There is no fixed relationship between the deceleration and uterine contractions.
    • Caused by umbilical cord compression, often seen with oligohydramnios.
    • Significant if persistent, with FHR <70 bpm for more than 60 seconds.
  4. Prolonged Deceleration:
    • Occurs when the deceleration lasts beyond 2 minutes but less than 10 minutes.
    • May indicate acute fetal hypoxia, such as with cord prolapse or intrapartum abruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acceleration: This would show an increase in the fetal heart rate by at least 15 bpm lasting for at least 15 seconds, which is not the case here.

 

Option C. Normal: A normal CTG would not show any decelerations or would show a typical pattern of fetal heart rate variability and accelerations.

 

Option D. Deceleration followed by acceleration: This pattern would indicate a combination of deceleration and acceleration, which is not specified here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decelerations on a Cardio-Tocography indicate a decrease in fetal heart rate by at least 15 bpm lasting for at least 15 seconds, with different types signifying various conditions and levels of concern.

 

Ref: Page no 994, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Parvovirus
Toxoplasma
HIV

questions.text: Which of these is the cause of Hydrops fetalis?  (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parvovirus

 

  • Parvovirus B19 is the most common infectious cause of hydrops fetalis. (Non immune hydrops)
  • Parvovirus B19 infects fetal erythroid progenitor cells and causes anemia.
  • Severe anemia leads to high-output cardiac failure and hydrops fetalis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. CMV: Typically causes peri-ventricular calcifications in the fetus.

 

Option C. Toxoplasmosis: Causes:  hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, cerebral calcification, microcephaly, seizures and mental retardation in the newborn.

 

Option D. HIV: Vertical transmission of HIV from mother to infant can occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 is the most common infectious cause of hydrops fetalis due to its effect on fetal erythroid progenitor cells, leading to severe anemia and subsequent high-output cardiac failure.

 

Ref: Page no 347, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: Anti-D vaccine is not given in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intrauterine transfusion at 28 weeks

 

The Anti-D vaccine (anti-D immunoglobulin) is typically administered to prevent Rh sensitization in Rh-negative women who might be exposed to Rh-positive fetal blood. It is given to protect against the formation of anti-Rh antibodies that could affect future pregnancies. The vaccine is not given after an intrauterine transfusion because this procedure is performed to treat severe fetal anemia in cases where the mother is Rh-positive or the indirect Coombs test (ICT) is positive, indicating that the mother has already been sensitized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amniocentesis at 16 weeks: Anti-D vaccine is given after amniocentesis to prevent Rh sensitization, as the procedure can cause fetal blood to mix with maternal blood.

 

Option B. Manual removal of placenta: Anti-D vaccine is administered after manual removal of the placenta to prevent sensitization, as this procedure can result in significant feto-maternal hemorrhage.

 

Option D. MTP at 63 days: Anti-D vaccine is given after medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) to prevent Rh sensitization if the mother is Rh-negative and the fetus is Rh-positive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-D vaccine is not given after intrauterine transfusion, as this procedure is used to treat severe fetal anemia and does not require further prophylaxis against Rh sensitization.

 

Ref: Page no 919, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: The test given below in the image is used for: (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stereopsis test

 

The test shown in the above image is Titmus stereotest, which is done to test for stereopsis (perception of depth).

 

  • Patients are shown a picture of a housefly for children and circular patterns for adults.
  • The picture is held about 16 inches in front of the patient's eyes.
  • Patients are asked to wear polarized glasses during the test.
  • Normal perception of depth will cause the housefly to appear as a 3D image above the plane.
  • Patients will attempt to pinch the wings of the housefly in the air, above the plane of the image, if perception of depth is normal.
  • Defective perception of depth will cause the image to appear as a normal 2D image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ocular deviation: This refers to misalignment of the eyes, typically tested with cover tests or Hirschberg test, not the Titmus stereotest.

 

Option C. Refractive errors: These are assessed with vision tests using an eye chart, not stereopsis tests.

 

Option D. Colour Blindness: This is assessed using color vision tests like the Ishihara test, not related to depth perception tests like the Titmus stereotest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Titmus stereotest evaluates stereopsis or depth perception, an essential aspect of binocular vision, allowing for the three-dimensional interpretation of the world necessary for various activities and indicating healthy, cooperative eye function.

questions.text: Which test evaluates the extrinsic pathway? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PT

 

Prothrombin time (PT) evaluates the extrinsic pathway of coagulation.

 

PT measures the clotting time of plasma in the presence of an optimal concentration of tissue extract (thromboplastin). This indicates the overall efficiency of the extrinsic clotting system.

 

 

Causes of prolonged PT:

 

  • Administration of oral anticoagulant drugs - vitamin K antagonists
  • Liver disease - obstructive jaundice
  • Vitamin K deficiency
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Previously undiagnosed factor VII, X, V or prothrombin deficiency or defect (rare)

 

Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) measures the clotting time of plasma after the activation of contact factors and the addition of phospholipid and CaCl2, but without added tissue thromboplastin. It indicates the overall efficiency of the intrinsic pathway.

 

Causes of prolonged APTT:

 

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Liver disease
  • Massive transfusion with plasma-depleted red blood cells
  • Administration of or contamination with heparin or other anticoagulants
  • A circulating anticoagulant (inhibitor)
  • Deficiency of a coagulation factor other than factor VII
  • Intake of oral anticoagulant drugs
  • Vitamin K deficiency

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. APTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time): APTT evaluates the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade. It measures the time taken for plasma to clot after the activation of contact factors and the addition of phospholipid and calcium, but without tissue thromboplastin. APTT is used to assess the intrinsic pathway involving factors XII, XI, IX, and VIII, as well as the common pathway.

 

Option C. TT (Thrombin Time): TT measures the final step of the coagulation process—conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin after the addition of thrombin. It does not evaluate either the intrinsic or extrinsic pathways specifically but rather the conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin.

 

Option D. Bleeding time: Bleeding time is a test that assesses platelet function and the initial phase of hemostasis but does not evaluate the coagulation pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prothrombin time (PT) evaluates the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade by measuring the time it takes for plasma to clot after the addition of tissue thromboplastin and calcium. It is commonly prolonged in conditions such as vitamin K deficiency, liver disease, and the use of vitamin K antagonists.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic Basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 232

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency and his ocular examination reveals the following. Which of the following is not done initially? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Removal of the foreign body

 

The image shows an eye with a metallic foreign body causing a penetrating injury. In such cases, immediate removal of the foreign body is not recommended as an initial step because doing so may exacerbate the injury or lead to complications such as infection or further mechanical damage to the eye structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Proper Initial Steps Include:
 

Option B. Check for visual acuity: This helps assess the extent of damage to the eye's visual function and provides a baseline for future comparisons.

 

Option C. Give antibiotics: Prophylactic treatment to prevent infection, especially considering the risk introduced by the foreign object.

 

Option D. Do primary survey: Ensures that the patient's overall health and other potential life-threatening conditions are addressed (part of the ABCDE approach - Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure).

 

Further Management:

 

CT scan: To precisely locate the foreign body and any possible penetration into the orbital or cranial cavities, helping plan for surgical intervention.

 

Avoid MRI: Due to the risk of movement of the metallic object, which can cause more damage.

 

Surgical exploration and repair in the operating theatre: To safely remove the foreign body under controlled conditions, minimizing risk of further damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of ocular injuries involving foreign bodies, immediate removal is not advised due to the potential for further damage. Initial steps should focus on assessment, stabilization, and prevention of infection, followed by careful planning and execution of the foreign body removal under appropriate surgical conditions.

questions.text: Which of these structures are retained during radical neck dissection? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sublingual gland

 

In a radical neck dissection, the aim is to remove extensive lymphatic tissue potentially involved with malignancies, but the procedure generally spares certain non-lymphatic structures unless directly involved by the tumor. The sublingual gland, which is located under the floor of the mouth, is not typically removed during a radical neck dissection because it is not within the field of the lymph node groups that are typically excised. This gland remains intact unless the specific tumor pathology dictates otherwise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tail of parotid: The tail of the parotid may be removed if it is involved with the tumor or if the dissection needs to be extended to ensure comprehensive removal of cancerous tissues.

 

Option C. Submandibular gland: This gland is typically removed during radical neck dissections because it lies within the Level I lymph nodes, which are included in the dissection.

 

Option D. Level 2b lymph nodes: These are generally removed in a radical neck dissection, which traditionally includes the removal of lymph nodes from Levels I to V.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition Page No. 442; Stell and Maran 5th edition Page No. 710

questions.text: You are the on-call surgeon who is called for an emergency laparotomy for a patient with suspected bowel obstruction. During the surgery, which organ will you first visualize to determine if the obstruction is in the small or large bowel? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Caecum

 

  • The caecum is a pouch-like structure at the beginning of the colon. Visualizing the caecum first would indicate that the obstruction likely involves the large bowel if it is distended, helping to differentiate it from a small bowel obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The cecum is the first organ to be visualized to differentiate between small and large bowel obstruction in cases of intestinal obstruction.
  • Distension of the cecum will confirm large bowel involvement, while collapsed cecum implies small bowel obstruction.
  • Identifying a collapsed distal segment of the large bowel and its sequential proximal assessment leads to the identification of the cause.

questions.text: Paradoxical undressing is seen in? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hypothermia

 

  • Paradoxical undressing is seen in hypothermia victims.
  • The victims, despite low environmental temperatures, paradoxically remove their clothes due to a sudden feeling of warmth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heat stress: Heat stress leads to symptoms such as heat cramps, heat exhaustion, and heat stroke, characterized by elevated body temperature, dehydration, and sometimes loss of consciousness. It does not cause paradoxical undressing.

 

Option B. Voyeurism: Voyeurism is a psychiatric condition where an individual derives sexual pleasure from observing unsuspecting people who are naked, undressing, or engaging in sexual activities. It is unrelated to hypothermia or paradoxical undressing.

 

Option D. LSD overdose: LSD overdose can cause hallucinations, altered mental status, and sensory distortions. While individuals may engage in bizarre behaviors, paradoxical undressing is not a recognized symptom of LSD overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paradoxical undressing occurs in hypothermia victims who, despite experiencing extremely low temperatures, remove their clothing due to a sudden and misleading sensation of warmth.

questions.text:
Match the following ocular drugs with respect to their side effects: 

 

Column A:

1. Amiodarone 

2. Digoxin

3. Systemic steroids 

4. Hydroxychloroquine

 

Column B:

A. Cataract

B. Retinopathy

C. Yellow vision

D. Corneal microdeposits
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-d, 2-c, 3-a, 4-b

 

The correct matches of the drugs with their side effects are:

 

  1. Amiodarone: d. Corneal microdeposits
    Amiodarone leads to the formation of whorl-like corneal microdeposits, also known as cornea verticillata or vortex keratopathy. These appear as gray or brown opacities in a whorled pattern on the corneal surface. The mechanism is related to the drug’s accumulation within the corneal epithelium due to its lipid affinity. Typically, these deposits are asymptomatic, but in some cases, patients may experience visual disturbances. Other medications, such as chloroquine, phenothiazines, and indomethacin, can also cause similar deposits.
  2. Digoxin: c. Yellow vision (Xanthopsia)
    Digoxin is known to cause xanthopsia, where the vision takes on a yellowish hue. This side effect is due to the drug’s action on the retina and visual pathways, altering color perception. Yellow vision is a common sign of digoxin toxicity, and other associated symptoms can include blurred vision and visual disturbances.
  3. Systemic steroids: a. Cataract
    Prolonged use of systemic steroids can lead to the development of cataracts, particularly posterior subcapsular cataracts. These cataracts form at the back of the lens and are more likely to impair vision compared to other types. The mechanism involves changes in lens protein structure and oxidative damage. In contrast, topical steroids are more often associated with increased intraocular pressure and glaucoma.
  4. Hydroxychloroquine: b. Retinopathy
    Hydroxychloroquine can result in toxic retinopathy, which damages the retinal layers, especially the macula. In the initial stages, retinal damage may not be visible on examination. As the condition progresses, a characteristic bull’s eye maculopathy can be seen, which features central pigmentation surrounded by a ring of depigmentation. This is due to the drug’s accumulation in the retina, where it binds to melanin and disrupts the function of photoreceptors.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The key drug-specific ocular side effects: Amiodarone causes corneal microdeposits, Digoxin leads to yellow vision, systemic steroids can cause cataracts, and Hydroxychloroquine is linked with toxic retinopathy.

questions.text: Which modification will lead to Various short and long-acting analogs of the hormone given in the picture ?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Change in 29-30 in B chain 

 

Explanation:

 

The hormone depicted in the image is insulin.  

 

Insulin's primary structure consists of two polypeptide chains: the A chain (21 amino acids) and the B chain (30 amino acids).  

 

There are two interchain disulfide bonds: 

  • Between the 7th amino acid of the A chain and the 7th amino acid of the B chain. 
  • Between the 20th amino acid of the A chain and the 19th amino acid of the B chain. One intrachain disulfide bond exists between the 6th and 11th amino acids of the A chain. 

Modifications in amino acids 29-30 of the B chain result in the production of short- and long-acting insulin types, depending on the changes made 

 

Other Options Explanation: 

 

Option A. Hydrolysis of disulphide bonds: Disrupts the structural integrity of insulin, leading to loss of biological activity. 

 

Option B. Change in 5-6 in A chain: Changing the sequence in the critical A chain can affect the folding and activity of insulin. 

 

Option D. Change in 14-16 in A chain: Changing the sequence in the A chain can disrupt the structure and function of insulin. 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: If DNA is damaged in the cell cycle, which gene causes cell cycle arrest? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) p53

 

  • Tumor suppressor gene causes cell cycle arrest (to provide time for DNA repair) and apoptosis (if DNA cannot be repaired). Acts mainly through p21 to cause cell cycle arrest. Causes apoptosis by inducing the transcription of pro-apoptotic genes such as BAX. Levels of p53 are negatively regulated by MDM2 through a feedback loop.
  • p53 is required for the G1/S checkpoint and is a main component of the G2/M checkpoint.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rb: The Rb (retinoblastoma) protein is another tumor suppressor that plays a role in regulating the cell cycle. Rb controls the progression from the G1 to S phase by binding to and inhibiting E2F transcription factors. While Rb is critical for cell cycle regulation, it does not directly mediate the response to DNA damage like p53.

 

Option B. MYC: The MYC gene is a proto-oncogene that promotes cell proliferation by driving the expression of genes necessary for cell growth and division. It does not cause cell cycle arrest in response to DNA damage; instead, its dysregulation is often associated with uncontrolled cell proliferation.

 

Option D. K-RAS: K-RAS is a proto-oncogene involved in cell signaling pathways that regulate cell growth and survival. Mutations in K-RAS can lead to uncontrolled cell division and are implicated in many cancers. However, K-RAS does not have a direct role in DNA damage response or cell cycle arrest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The p53 gene is a critical tumor suppressor that causes cell cycle arrest in response to DNA damage, providing time for DNA repair or triggering apoptosis if the damage is irreparable.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, pg 527

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Hepatitis B infection. Which of the following markers will always be present in his serum, even during recurrences, or if he develops chronic hepatitis? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti Hbc Ab

 

The Anti-HBc antibody (C) is the marker that will always be present in a patient's serum if they have been exposed to Hepatitis B virus (HBV). This marker is indicative of both past and ongoing infection and remains detectable for life. It indicates a previous or ongoing infection with HBV and is present in both acute and chronic stages of the infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HBc Ag: Hepatitis B core antigen is typically not detectable in the serum. It is found within the hepatocyte and not usually present in the bloodstream.

 

Option B. Anti HBs Ab: The antibody against the Hepatitis B surface antigen indicates immunity to HBV, either from past infection or vaccination. It is not present during chronic infection without recovery.

 

Option D. HBe Ag: Hepatitis B e antigen is a marker of active viral replication and high infectivity. It is not present in all stages of infection, especially in chronic carriers where the virus may not be actively replicating.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Bone mineral density screening is recommended after the age of:(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 65 years

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Bone mineral density is measured by DEXA scan (65 years onwards).
  • Normal Ca2+, PO‑4, ALP
  • Hemiplegic – Humerus maximum loss of bone mineral density

 

 

  • Radiological Investigation: Quantitative CT is a newer imaging technique that can be used to detect osteoporosis
  • Treatment:
    • Estrogen
    • Bisphosphonates – Increases hip fracture
    • Calcitonin
    • Low dose PTH – Stimulates osteoblasts

 

 

Codfish Vertebrae

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bone mineral density screening by DEXA scan is recommended at the age more than 65 years.

questions.text: A patient was treated with steroids for psoriasis. On stopping the treatment, he develops fever, malaise, and lesions as seen in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pustular psoriasis

 

The given clinical scenario points towards the diagnosis of Pustular psoriasis.

 

Clinical clues for diagnosis of Pustular psoriasis:

 

  • Pustular Lesions seen after withdrawal of corticosteroids in a psoriasis patient
  • History of fever & malaise
  • Presence of pustules on a circumscribed, fiery red & edematous or scaling plaque

 

Acitretin

 

  • Approved for use in the cutaneous manifestations of psoriasis.
  • It is the DOC for Pustular psoriasis.
  • Female patients should avoid conception for 3 years after receiving acitretin treatment to prevent retinoid induced embryopathy.

 

Acitretin:

 

  • Is associated with photosensitivity.
  • It has half-life of 50-70 hours

 

Absolute contraindications:

 

  • Pregnant women
  • Women who are planning to get pregnant
  • Breast-feeding

 

Relative contraindications:

 

  • Leukopenia
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Hypercholesterolemia
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Significant hepatic or renal disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Staphylococcal infection: While staphylococcal infections can cause skin lesions, there's no direct link provided between steroid withdrawal and the onset of such infections. In fact steroid usage would initiate such staphylococcal infections, not withdrawal.

 

Option C. Acute generalized Exanthematous pustulosis (AGEP): AGEP is typically a reaction to medications not due to steroid withdrawal, and its presentation can be similar to pustular psoriasis.

 

Option D. Sub corneal pustulosis dermatosis: Sub corneal pustular dermatosis is also known as Sneddon-Wilkinson disease. It is a rare condition, characterized by pustules that appear in crops over months or years. However there is no direct link between steroid withdrawal and SCPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When a patient with a history of psoriasis presents with fever, malaise, and widespread pustules following the abrupt withdrawal of systemic corticosteroids, consider pustular psoriasis as the probable diagnosis.
  • This condition can be a severe, life-threatening variant of psoriasis that requires prompt medical attention and management.

 

Ref - Goodman Gillman’s he pharmacological basis of therapeutics – 13th edition page no 1276

Online resources - https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19998529/

Rook’s textbook of dermatology - 9th Edition page no 18.18, 26.22, 35.28, 35.33

questions.text: Identify the structure marked a in the image given below? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ulnar artery

 

 

The structure marked in the image is the ulnar artery, seen contributing to the superficial palmar arch.

 

It is a major blood vessel of the forearm that passes alongside the ulna bone. It is essential for supplying blood to the deep and superficial structures of the forearm and hand. In the wrist, the ulnar artery passes through Guyon's canal before contributing to both the superficial and deep palmar arches.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulnar nerve: Incorrect because the ulnar nerve, while it travels a similar path as the ulnar artery in the forearm, is not a blood vessel but a nerve. It primarily provides sensory and motor innervation to the hand, not blood supply.

 

Option C. Superficial radial artery: Incorrect as this artery travels along the radial side of the forearm and would not be located where the marked structure is. The superficial radial artery is much smaller and does not contribute significantly to the palmar arches.

 

Option D. Median nerve: Incorrect because, like the ulnar nerve, the median nerve is a neural structure responsible for sensory and motor functions in the forearm and hand, not a vascular structure. It travels down the middle of the forearm and does not supply blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ulnar artery is an essential vascular structure for the blood supply to the forearm and hand, particularly contributing to the formation of the palmar arches, which are critical for hand perfusion. Its course alongside the ulna bone and through Guyon's canal makes it a significant artery in the vascular anatomy of the forearm and hand. It passes deep to the Guyon's canal in the wrist and contributes to the superficial and deep palmar arch.

choices.text: Crystal violet, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin
Methanol, Kinyoun's carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue
Methanol, dilute carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, crystal violet
Methylene blue, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin

questions.text: A HIV patient with fever, chronic diarrhea presented to OPD. His stool was examined which showed the following oocysts. Identify the components used for staining the stool? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Methanol, Kinyoun's carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue

 

Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidian parasitic infestation. The image shows a blue background and red-stained oocysts, suggestive of modified acid-fast stain positive Cryptosporidium parvum.

 

The Modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain (mZN stain) is a type of differential bacteriological stain used to identify acid-fast organisms, mainly Mycobacteria. Acid fast organisms are those which are capable of retaining the primary stain when treated with an acid fast (holding capacity).

 

Members of the Actinomycetes, genus Nocardia (N. brasiliensis and N. asteroides are opportunistic pathogens) are partially acid-fast. Oocysts of coccidian parasites, such as Cryptosporidium and Isospora, are also acid-fast. Hence, they can also be detected and identified through mZN staining procedure.

 

The reagents used for modified Ziehl–Neelsen staining are absolute methanol (for fixation), kinyoun’s carbol fuchsin (primary stain), acid alcohol (for decolorization), and methylene blue (counter stain).

 

Unlike the ZN-stain, the modified ZN stain does not require heating of the reagents. Kinyoun’s carbol fuschin has greater concentration of phenol and basic fuschin and does not require heating to stain properly. Heat is used as mordant (A mordant is a substance that increases the affinity of the cell wall for a stain by binding to the primary stain, thus forming an insoluble complex, which gets trapped in the cell wall). Acid-fast bacilli are bright red after staining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crystal violet, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin: This combination is not used for modified acid-fast staining but is related to Gram staining.

 

Option C. Methanol, dilute carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, crystal violet: This is incorrect as the proper primary stain for the modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain is Kinyoun’s carbol fuchsin.

 

Option D. Methylene blue, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin: This combination is incorrect for modified Ziehl-Neelsen staining.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain uses methanol for fixation, Kinyoun’s carbol fuchsin as the primary stain, acid alcohol for decolorization, and methylene blue as the counterstain to detect acid-fast organisms like Cryptosporidium parvum.

questions.text: A 16-year-old unmarried female has come to the gynae OPD for cervical cancer vaccination. Which is preferred? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gardasil

 

Explanation:

 

Gardasil is the preferred vaccine for cervical cancer prevention. It is a quadrivalent HPV vaccine that provides protection against four serotypes of the Human Papillomavirus (HPV): 6, 11, 16, and 18.

 

  • HPV Serotypes Covered by Gardasil:
    • 6 and 11: These types are associated with anogenital warts.
    • 16 and 18: These types are linked to cervical cancer and other HPV-related cancers.

 

Gardasil is administered as an intramuscular injection with a recommended schedule of three doses (0, 2, and 6 months).

 

Available HPV Vaccines:

 

  1. Cervarix (Bivalent): Covers HPV serotypes 16 and 18.
  2. Gardasil (Quadrivalent): Covers HPV serotypes 6, 11, 16, and 18.
  3. Gardasil 9 (Nonavalent or HPV9): Covers HPV serotypes 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.
