  4. Cervavac (India’s indigenous HPV vaccine): Quadrivalent, covers serotypes 6, 11, 16, and 18.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Biovac: This is a vaccine for Hepatitis A, not related to HPV or cervical cancer.

 

Option C. Rabivac: This is a rabies vaccine for animals, not related to HPV or cervical cancer.

 

Option D. Tvac: This is a tetanus vaccine, not related to HPV or cervical cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gardasil is the preferred vaccine for preventing cervical cancer and related HPV diseases, covering serotypes 6, 11, 16, and 18.

 

Ref: https://www.who.int/teams/immunization-vaccines-and-biologicals/diseases/human-papillomavirus-vaccines-(HPV)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of liver failure? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paracetamol

 

The most common cause of liver failure is paracetamol poisoning.

 

Acetaminophen is the leading cause of drug-induced acute liver failure. The most common prescription drugs causing idiosyncratic injury (that is, drug toxicity unrelated to drug dosage) include antibiotics and, in particular, isoniazid, nonsteroidal analgesics, and anti-seizure.

 

  • Paracetamol poisoning is a medical emergency that requires prompt management to prevent serious liver damage and other complications. The general steps involved in the management of acute paracetamol poisoning:

 

1. Decontamination: If the ingestion of paracetamol occurred within the last 1-2 hours, activated charcoal can be given orally to reduce the absorption of paracetamol.

 

2. Treatment with antidote: N-acetylcysteine (NAC. is the specific antidote for paracetamol poisoning. It is most effective if given within 8 hours of ingestion of the overdose. NAC replenishes the depleted glutathione stores in the liver, which helps to prevent liver damage.

 

3. Monitoring and supportive care: Patients with paracetamol poisoning require close monitoring, particularly for liver and kidney function, electrolytes, blood glucose, and acid-base balance. Treatment with intravenous fluids, glucose and electrolytes may be necessary to maintain fluid and electrolyte balance.

 

RUMACK MATTHEW NOMOGRAM is used for monitoring:

 

 

4. Referral for specialist care: In severe cases of paracetamol poisoning, the patient may require specialist care in a hospital setting, including referral to a liver transplant center.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alcohol: Chronic alcohol consumption is a significant cause of liver disease, including cirrhosis, but paracetamol is the leading cause of acute liver failure.

 

Option C. CCl4 (Carbon Tetrachloride): CCl4 is a chemical that can cause liver damage, but it is not a common cause of liver failure compared to paracetamol.

 

Option D. Pesticides: Certain pesticides can cause liver toxicity, but they are not as common a cause of liver failure as paracetamol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paracetamol poisoning is the most common cause of acute liver failure, the mechanism involves free radical injury and so and it is a medical emergency that requires prompt treatment with N-acetylcysteine (NAC) and close monitoring to prevent serious complications, including liver failure.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease, 11th edition, Pg 1635

questions.text: Duration of action of Proparacaine? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 20 mins

 

Proparacaine:

 

  • Duration of Action: The duration of action of proparacaine is approximately 15-20 minutes.
  • Uses: Proparacaine hydrochloride is used as a topical anesthetic agent, especially for ophthalmic surgeries such as:
    • Tonometry
    • Gonioscopy
    • Removal of corneal foreign bodies
    • Short corneal and conjunctival procedures

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The duration of action of proparacaine is approximately 15-20 minutes, making it suitable for short ophthalmic procedures.

questions.text: Match the Eponym with their fractures.(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-e

 

  • The correct description of the given fractures are:

 

 

COMMON FRACTURE EPONYMS

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

1. Pilon’s fracture: It is the intra-articular comminuted fracture of the distal tibia. It is also known as Plafond fracture, Tibia Plafond fracture, Distal Tibial Explosion fracture. The high energy axial compression force if the tibia acts as a pestle, driving vertically into the talus.

 

 

2. Runner’s fracture: It is the fracture of lower end of the fibula. They are usually the stress fracture, commonly seen in runners.

 

 

3. Cotton’s fracture: It is the trimalleolar fracture in the ankle i.e., there is involvement of medial and lateral malleoli, and posterior aspect of the tibial plafond (also called as posterior malleolus). This is a more unstable fracture and may be associated with ligamentous injury.

 

 

4. Chauffer’s fracture: It is an intra-articular oblique fracture of the styloid process of the radius. It is sustained from a direct trauma like a blow to the back of the wrist or from forced dorsiflexion and abduction of the wrist.

choices.text: Decrease in Systolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 6 mins of standing
Decrease in Diastolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 6 mins of standing
Decrease in Systolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 3 min of standing
Decrease in diastolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 3 mins of standing

questions.text: True about the definition of Postural Hypotension: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decrease in systolic blood pressure 20 mm Hg after 3 mins of standing

 

“3-20-10” mnemonic can aid in remembering the definition of orthostatic hypotension.

 

Sustained fall of SBP > 20mmHg /DBP > 10mmHg after 3 mins of standing. Usually, it is accompanied by a rise in HR. Absence of increase in heart rate suggest neurogenic/autonomic dysfunction.

 

Cause of Orthostatic Hypotension:

 

  • Cardiac pump failure
  • Hypovolemia
  • Endocrinopathies: AI, Pheochromocytoma.
  • Venous pooling
  • Medications

 

Other Options:

 

Option A and B: These options extend the timing to 6 minutes, which is not standard for the initial assessment of orthostatic hypotension.

 

Option D: Specifies a diastolic drop which should be 10 mmHg, not 20 mmHg, thus making it incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postural hypotension, also known as orthostatic hypotension, is defined as a significant drop in blood pressure when a person stands up from a sitting or lying position. The correct definition, as per the consensus, includes a decrease in systolic blood pressure of 20 mmHg or a decrease in diastolic blood pressure of 10 mmHg within 3 minutes of standing. The answer C correctly reflects the component of this definition regarding the systolic blood pressure drop.

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology, chap 21/695

choices.text: Both assertion and reasoning are independently true/correct and reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reasoning are independently true/correct and reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is independently a true/correct statement but the Reason is independently an incorrect/false statement
Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement but the reason is independently a true/correct statement

questions.text:
Assertion: Decompression surgery is needed with progressive neurological difficulty in Pott’s spine. (AIIMS May 2019)

 

Reason: Even after completion of ATT, there can be neurological abnormalities.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Both assertion and reasoning are independently true/correct and reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion

 

  • When there is stage 4 of pott’s spine with bladder/bowel involvement and more than 50% of sensory loss, the treatment of choice is decompression surgery with bone graft, along with continuation of ATT.
  • Even after the completion of ATT, there can be presence of neurological abnormalities.

 

POTT’S SPINE

 

  • Like tuberculosis of the bones and joints elsewhere in the body, TB of the spine is always secondary.
  • The bacteria reach the spine via the hematogenous route, from the lungs or lymph nodes.
  • The spine is the most common site of skeletal tuberculosis, accounting for 50% of cases followed by hip (15%) and knee (10%).
  • Any level of the spine may be involved, the lower thoracic region being the most common followed by lumbar > upper dorsal > cervical > sacral region.
  • Types:

 

 

  • Clinical features: Pain, stiffness, cold abscess formation, paraplegia, deformity, fever, weight loss.
  • Imaging:
    1. Plain radiograph:
      • Reduction of disc space
      • Vertebral body destruction
      • Paravertebral abscess
      • Widening of mediastinum
    2. CT scan: 
      • It may detect a small paravertebral abscess, not otherwise seen on plain X-ray; may indicate precisely the extent of destruction of the vertebral body and posterior elements; and may show a sequestrum or a bony ridge pressing on the cord.
    3. MRI: 
      • It is the investigation of choice to evaluate the type and extent of compression of the cord.
      • It also shows condition of the underlying neural tissues, and thus helps in predicting the prognosis in a particular case.
    4. Biopsy: 
      • CT guided needle biopsy, or an open biopsy may be required in a case with doubtful diagnosis.
  • Stages of TB Spine with Neural Deficit:
    • Stage 1: Patient has no neural complaint clinician elicits increased reflexes.
    • Stage 2: Patient has weakness but can walk with support.
    • Stage 3: Patient is non-ambulatory or has sensory loss <50%.
    • Stage 4: Patient has bowel/bladder involvement or sensory loss >50%.
  • Treatment:
    • Middle path regimen is used in India.
    • Patient is treated by antitubercular therapy (ATT), spinal brace and rest.
    • Patient is followed on with complete neural examination and if progress is good then continued on nonoperative management but if indications of surgery exist  then he needs to be operated.
  • Stage-wise Treatment:

 

 

  • ATT: 
    • Rifampicin is always a part of all regimens.
    • Minimum duration is 9-12 months in spinal TB and may be given up to 18-24 months depending upon clinical, radiological (MRI) and hematological (ESR) healing (in non-spinal TB, the duration of ATT is 6 months-1 year).
  • Indications of surgery in any disease of spine:
    1. Bowel bladder involvement.
    2. Deterioration in neural or clinical status on treatment
    3. No improvement in neural or clinical status after conservative trial of 3-4 weeks or
    4. Surgical options for most of the cases are: anterior decompression + bone grafting or anterolateral decompression + bone grafting and both have similar success rates.
    5. Hong Kong operation is also carried out for Pott’s spine.
    6. Structures removed in anterolateral decompression are part of rib, one side transverse process, one pedicle and small part of vertebral body (intercostal nerves are exposed).

 

 

Structures removed in anterolateral decompression

 

Note:

 

  • Posterior structures like lamina are never removed in tuberculosis because disease destroys anteriorly and if surgeon destroys posteriorly then there will be instability.
  • These surgeries are carried out in right lateral position (right side down and left side up) approaching the spine from left side as the vessel handled is aorta on left side which is thick muscular vessel with more resilience to handling pressure as compared to vena cava on right side which is friable to handle.

 

Prognostic Factors:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When there is stage 4 of pott’s spine with bladder/bowel involvement and more than 50% of sensory loss, the treatment of choice is decompression surgery with bone graft, along with continuation of ATT.
  • Even after the completion of ATT, there can be presence of neurological abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a hemostatic agent? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Boric acid

 

Boric acid is not a hemostatic agent. Boric acid is commonly used as an antiseptic, insecticide, and in various industrial applications, but it does not possess properties that would promote blood coagulation or control bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zeolite and Option D. Kaolin are microporous aluminosilicate minerals with large surface areas, having high hygroscopicity and excellent hemostatic performance. Zeolite absorbs blood and the releases Ca2+ into the blood and to activate the intrinsic path of coagulation cascade.

 

Option B. Chitosan: Chitosan is a biopolymer derived from chitin, which is found in the shells of crustaceans. Chitosan and its derivatives are known to accelerate the hemostasis process by promoting platelet adhesion and activation. This helps in forming a stable clot more quickly, which is particularly useful in controlling external bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Boric acid is not a hemostatic agent. Hemostatic agents like Zeolite, Chitosan, and Kaolin work by activating the coagulation pathways to control bleeding.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use presents to the emergency department with a pulsatile mass in the inguinal region. Imaging studies reveal a pseudoaneurysm involving an artery. What is the most commonly involved artery in pseudoaneurysm formation? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Femoral artery

 

The femoral artery is a common site for pseudoaneurysm formation, especially in individuals with a history of intravenous drug use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aorta: While pseudoaneurysms can occur in the aorta, they are less common than in peripheral arteries like the femoral artery.

 

Option C. Popliteal artery: Pseudoaneurysms can occur in the popliteal artery, but they are less common than in the femoral artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A pseudoaneurysm is a pulsatile hematoma that forms when there is a breach in the arterial wall, resulting in the extravasation of blood into the surrounding tissues.
  • The most commonly involved artery in pseudoaneurysm formation is the femoral artery, due to its superficial location and frequent use for arterial access.
  • Pseudoaneurysms can also occur in other arteries, such as the brachial, radial, ulnar, and carotid arteries.
  • Common causes of pseudoaneurysm formation include trauma, iatrogenic injury during medical procedures (e.g., arterial catheterization), and underlying arterial disease (e.g., atherosclerosis).
  • The clinical presentation of a pseudoaneurysm may include a pulsatile mass, pain, tenderness, and signs of bleeding or hematoma formation.
  • The diagnosis of a pseudoaneurysm is confirmed by imaging studies such as ultrasound, CT scan, or angiography.
  • Treatment options for a pseudoaneurysm may include observation, compression, percutaneous thrombin injection, or surgical repair depending on the size, location, and underlying cause of the lesion.
  • MC site of true peripheral aneurysm is however, the popliteal artery.

questions.text: On the 5th day after coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG), a patient develops rapid breathing and low blood pressure. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute respiratory failure

 

The symptoms of rapid breathing (tachypnea) and hypotension in a patient on the 5th day post-CABG suggest acute respiratory failure, commonly caused by lung collapse (atelectasis). This complication occurs frequently in the postoperative period and is classified as type 3 respiratory failure.

 

  • Risk Factors: The likelihood of developing atelectasis is higher after general anesthesia, upper abdominal, or thoracic surgery. Reduced lung expansion due to pain and restricted mobility are contributing factors.
  • Signs and Symptoms: Patients often present with decreased oxygen saturation, tachypnea, and diminished breath sounds with a bronchial character on auscultation.
  • Management Strategies: Early intervention, including mobilization, deep breathing exercises, the use of an incentive spirometer, and chest physiotherapy, can resolve atelectasis within 24-48 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sepsis: Sepsis would need to be confirmed with clinical evidence of infection and an increased SOFA (Sequential Organ Failure Assessment) score by at least 2 points. In the absence of a clear infection or systemic symptoms, sepsis is less likely in this context.

 

Option B. Acute kidney failure: Defined by reduced urine output (<0.5 mL/kg/h over 6-12 hours) and increased serum creatinine (>1.5 times the baseline or >0.3 mg/dL), acute kidney injury typically occurs later or as a secondary issue and is not the most immediate concern in this case.

 

Option D. Acute cardiac failure: This condition would present with signs such as hypotension, rapid heart rate, and reduced perfusion, evidenced by cold, clammy extremities. Without specific indications of heart dysfunction, acute respiratory failure is a more probable cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atelectasis is a frequent postoperative respiratory issue following thoracic or upper abdominal surgeries, presenting with symptoms like tachypnea and low oxygen levels. Early mobilization and breathing exercises are crucial for management and recovery.

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord

questions.text: A patient has recurrent optic neuritis of both eyes with extensive transverse myelitis. Visual acuity in the right eye is 6/60 and visual acuity in the left eye 6/18. The patient showed a partial response to steroids. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neuromyelitis optica

 

Bilateral optic neuritis with extensive transverse myelitis and partial steroid response is suggestive of NMO-Spectrum disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MS usually causes U/L optic neuritis. LETM (Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis) not common in MS.

 

Option C. SACD usually affects the posterior column. LETM, optic neuritis not a feature of B12 deficiency.

 

Option D. Neurosyphilis is usually associated with RAPD (U/L Optic neuritis). LETM not common.

 

Educational Objective:

 

WINGERCHUK Criteria for NMO-SD

questions.text: An intraocular lens was placed uneventfully in a young patient during cataract surgery. What should be done thereafter? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Never replaced

 

In the case of a successful and uneventful intraocular lens (IOL) implantation during cataract surgery, there is typically no need to replace the IOL. These lenses are designed to be permanent solutions that do not require routine replacement. Modern IOLs are made from durable materials that are meant to last a lifetime without degrading or causing adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IOL replaced every 10 years: There is no routine schedule for replacing IOLs as they are designed to last a lifetime.

 

Option C. Replaced when secondary cataract develops: Secondary cataract (or posterior capsule opacification) can often be treated with a simple laser procedure called a posterior capsulotomy, not by replacing the IOL.

 

Option D. Replaced when presbyopia develops: Presbyopia is related to the lens of the eye and loss of its elasticity, affecting near vision; IOLs implanted during cataract surgery do not correct presbyopia inherent to aging, but specific types of IOLs can be chosen to address presbyopia at the time of surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An IOL replacement (IOL exchange) may be done under the following conditions:

 

  • Incorrect IOL placed-Incorrect power or Incorrect Type
  • Posterior or anterior dislocation of IOL
  • Hyphema
  • Asymmetrical Haptic Placement
  • Sunset Syndrome
  • Lens-Bag Decentration

questions.text: The structure that divides the liver in Couinaud's classification system is? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Portal vein

 

The structure that divides the liver in Couinaud's classification system is the portal vein.

 

The portal vein is a significant vessel that delivers blood from the gastrointestinal tract, spleen, pancreas, and gallbladder to the liver.

 

In the context of Couinaud's classification, the liver is divided into right and left lobes by the main portal vein. Further segmentation divides each lobe into individual segments based on the branches of the portal vein. As such, the portal vein is the primary structure used in Couinaud's system to determine liver segmentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hepatic artery: The hepatic artery provides oxygen-rich blood to the liver. While it is part of the portal triad and serves individual liver segments, it is not the primary structure used to define the segments in Couinaud's classification. The segmentation is based on the portal vein's distribution, although the hepatic artery's branches supply the respective segments concurrently.

 

Option C. Bile duct: The bile ducts are responsible for transporting bile produced in the liver to the gallbladder for storage or directly to the small intestine for digestion. Similar to the hepatic artery, while bile ducts are part of the portal triad and serve individual liver segments, they aren't the primary structure used for segmentation in the Couinaud's system.

 

Option D. Cystic duct: The cystic duct connects the gallbladder to the common bile duct. It does not have a direct role in dividing the liver into its segments and is unrelated to Couinaud's classification system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Illustration of the segmental anatomy of the liver based on the third-order portal vein branching (Couinaud's classification system) and the portal vein and hepatic vein branches.

 

IVC: inferior vena cava and PV: portal vein.

questions.text: What is the first step in the management of an 18-month-old child with both eyes deviated medially? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Refractive error testing

 

In children, who present with a convergent squint, the first step is to check the visual acuity and estimate the error of refraction.

 

  • When the child presents, the distant vision is recorded and atropine 1% eye ointment, 3 times a day, is prescribed for three days.
  • After 3 days, the error of refraction is estimated by retinoscopy.
  • Fundoscopy is done to rule out retinoblastoma, and any other pathology
  • The angle of squint is measured and full spectacle correction is ordered for constant use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Forced ductions test: Used to check if the eye muscles move normally or are restricted, more relevant in cases where physical obstruction or muscle entrapment is suspected.

 

Option B. Examination under anesthesia: May be necessary for a comprehensive examination in uncooperative children, but it is not the first step.

 

Option D. Examination of fundus: Important for ruling out intraocular causes of squint such as retinoblastoma, but it follows the refractive assessment in priority.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first management step for a child presenting with a convergent squint is to test for refractive errors. This helps to identify any need for optical correction which might resolve or reduce the squint, thereby improving the visual development and alignment of the eyes.

choices.text: Dead space volume

questions.text: Single breath nitrogen method is used for measuring? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dead space volume

 

Air in the respiratory passages where gas exchange does not occur, such as the nose, pharynx, and trachea are called dead space.

 

Anatomical dead space can be measured by the single-breath N2 curve (Fowler's method).

 

  • In making this measurement, the subject suddenly takes a deep breath of oxygen.
  • This fills the entire dead space with pure oxygen. Some oxygen also mixes with the alveolar air but does not completely replace this air.
  • Then the person expires through a rapidly recording nitrogen meter, which makes the record
  • Record of the changes in nitrogen concentration in the expired air after a single previous inspiration of pure oxygen. This record can be used to calculate dead space.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. FRC (Functional Residual Capacity): Incorrect. FRC is usually measured using techniques such as body plethysmography or helium dilution, not the single breath nitrogen method.

 

Option C. Tidal volume: Incorrect. Tidal volume is the amount of air inhaled or exhaled during a normal breath and is measured directly using spirometry.

 

Option D. Diffusion capacity: Incorrect. Diffusion capacity, often measured by the DLCO (Diffusing Capacity of the Lungs for Carbon Monoxide) test, assesses the ability of gases to diffuse across the alveolar-capillary membrane, not by the single breath nitrogen method.

 

Educational Objective

 

The single breath nitrogen method (Fowler's method) is used to measure the anatomical dead space volume, which is the volume of air in the respiratory passages where no gas exchange occurs. This method provides a precise measurement of dead space by analyzing the nitrogen concentration in expired air following a single breath of pure oxygen.

choices.text: The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B
﻿﻿﻿The points A and B represent the range of maximum ionization of the amine and carboxyl group
﻿﻿﻿The compound has three ionisable side chains
﻿﻿﻿The compound has one ionisable group

questions.text: The graph shown below is the titration curve of a biochemical compound. Which of the following statement is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B

 

The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B, which corresponds to the pk1, and pk2 of the compound.

 

The above graph resembles the titration curve of the amino acid glycine.

 

Titration curve of Glycine:

 

 

The titration is completed at a pH of 12, where the glycine predominantly exists in the form of H2N - CH2 - COO.

 

pK1, and pK2, correspond to the point where the buffering capacity is maximum.

 

Characteristics of the titration curve:

  • ﻿﻿Buffering capacity is referred to as the ability of the amino acid to resist the change in pH due to the addition of acid (H+) or base (OH- equivalents), by accepting or losing the protons respectively.
  • ﻿﻿An ionizable group refers to the group which can either lose or accept a proton and becomes negatively charged or positively charged ion respectively.
  • ﻿﻿During the titration, the buffering capacity of the compound reaches its maximum, at points where the pKa of the ionizable groups is reached.
  • ﻿﻿Each of these pKa are labeled as pK1, pK2, pK3, etc.
  • ﻿﻿The presence of two pKs indicates that the compound has two ionizable groups. Ex. Glycine.
  • ﻿﻿The presence of three or more pKs indicates the presence of side chains on the amino acid, with additional ionizable groups.
  • ﻿﻿Ex. histidine has three ionizable groups, an amino group, an imidazole group (on the side chain), and a carboxyl group. The pKas of these groups respectively correspond to the pK1, pK2, pK3 of the titration curve of histidine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The points A and B represent the range of maximum ionization of the amine and carboxyl group: Points A and B represent the pKa values, not the range of maximum ionization. The range of maximum ionization would be broader than just the pKa points.

 

Option C. The compound has three ionisable side chains: The graph shows two pKa values, indicating two ionizable groups. A compound with three ionizable groups would have three pKa values.

 

Option D. The compound has one ionisable group: The graph shows two pKa values, indicating two ionizable groups (an amino group and a carboxyl group).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The points A and B on the titration curve represent the maximum buffering capacity of the compound, corresponding to the pKa values of the ionizable groups. The graph shown likely represents an amino acid like glycine, which has two ionizable groups.

questions.text: Which of the following does not happen in 5' to 3' direction?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) RNA editing

 

RNA editing is not a synthesis process; it involves modification of the pre-existing RNA sequence after transcription.
 

It may include: Base substitution (e.g., A-to-I, C-to-U)
 

Directionality (5′ to 3′) does not apply to these post-transcriptional modifications in the same way it applies to polymerization.
 

An example of RNA editing is apoB gene and mRNA
 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transcription: Occurs in the 5' to 3' direction, where RNA polymerase synthesizes RNA from a DNA template.

 

Option B. DNA Replication: Occurs in the 5' to 3' direction, with DNA polymerase adding nucleotides to the growing DNA strand.

 

Option C. DNA Repair: DNA repair processes, including nucleotide excision repair and base excision repair, involve synthesis in the 5' to 3' direction during the filling in of repaired regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RNA editing, such as the editing of the apolipoprotein B mRNA, can involve modifications that do not occur in the 5' to 3' direction, unlike transcription, DNA replication, and DNA repair.

choices.text: Profound feelings of guilt over trivial events

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of melancholia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sleep-onset insomnia

 

Melancholia, also known as melancholic depression, is a severe form of major depressive disorder characterized by specific symptoms. Key features of melancholia include:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Severe anhedonia (a loss of pleasure in virtually all or almost all activities)

 

Option B. Weight loss

 

Option D. Profound feelings of guilt, often over minor or even imagined misdeeds.

 

The characteristic sleep disturbance in melancholia is early morning awakening, not sleep-onset insomnia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Melancholic depression refers to a depression characterized by severe anhedonia, early morning awakening, weight loss, and profound feelings of guilt. It is also associated with changes in ANS and endocrine functions, hence it is also known as ‘endogenous depression’.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 380-382

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is NOT transmitted by sandflies? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trench fever

 

Trench fever is transmitted by lice and caused by Bartonella quintana.

 

Points to remember about Sandfly - 

 

  • Sandfly cannot fly; it hops
  • Sandfly rests in cracks and crevices of walls
  • Insecticide of choice: 

 

DDT - 2 rounds of spray per year; Spray up to 6 feet height on walls; 

 

If DDT–resistant, use BHC 

 

  • Sandfly is the vector of:
  • Visceral Leishmaniasis (Kala azar) (by Female Phlebotamus argentipes)
  • Cutaneous Leishmaniasis (Oriental Sore) & Mucocutaneous Leishmaniasis (by Phlebotamus papatasi & Phlebotamus sergenti)
  • Sandfly Fever
  • Oroya Fever
  • Sandflies inject the infective stage, metacyclic promastigotes, during blood meals.

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vectors and Diseases Transmitted

questions.text:
Mention the true statement/s about digoxin toxicity:(AIIMS MAY 2019)

 

  1. Earliest manifestation of digoxin toxicity is gastrointestinal symptoms
  2. Nonspecific vision changes may be noted in digoxin toxicity
  3. Early toxicity may not correlate with serum levels
  4. Neurological symptoms may occur without corresponding cardiovascular changes
  5. Hypokalemia is associated with increased risk of toxicity
questions.solution:
Ans. A. All are true

 

  • Most common and earliest adverse effect of digoxin is nausea and vomiting (option a).
  • Most common arrhythmia seen in digoxin overdose is ventricular bigeminy.
  • Other adverse effects of digoxin include Gynecomastia and Vision defects (initially non-specific and later yellow vision): Option b
  • Early toxicity may not correlate with serum levels because Digoxin has very high volume of distribution (~450L); So when digoxin reaches heart the plasma concentration may not be high.: Option c
  • Hypokalemia increases the risk of toxicity as the binding site of digoxin and K+ are same on the Na+ K+ pump. So, normally K inhibits the binding of digoxin to Na K pump. When K is less (hypokalemia), binding of digoxin increases and toxicity can result.
  • However, Note that Digoxin toxicity causes hyperkalemia (due to inhibition of Na K pump, K+ cannot enter inside cells and remain in blood, hence hyperkalemia occurs).

 

Educational Objective:

 

All statements about digoxin toxicity, including the earliest manifestations, vision changes, correlation with serum levels, neurological symptoms, and the association with hypokalemia, are true.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/560

questions.text: A patient presents with a 5 cm renal calculus causing severe flank pain. It is detected as a staghorn calculus. What is the best management? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy

 

PCNL is the preferred treatment for large and complex kidney stones, especially Staghorn calculi. It involves making a small incision in the patient's back to access the kidney directly. A nephroscope is then used to remove or break up the stone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ESWL (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy): ESWL is a non-invasive procedure that uses shock waves to break up kidney stones into smaller pieces, making them easier to pass. While ESWL is effective for smaller kidney stones, it may not be as successful for very large (> 2 cm) and complex Staghorn calculi.

 

Option C. Ureteroscopic removal: Ureteroscopy is a procedure that involves inserting a thin, flexible tube (ureteroscope) through the urethra and bladder to reach the stone in the ureter or renal pelvis. While it can be effective for ureteric stones, it may not be the best choice for Staghorn calculi, especially those larger than 4 cm.

 

Option D. Hydrotherapy: This can be tried for stones up to 5 mm in size. Larger stones would get obstructed in ureter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is a minimally invasive surgical procedure used to remove large kidney stones. The following are some of the indications for PCNL:

 

  1. Large or complex kidney stones (> 2 cm) or hard stones (Cysteine) that cannot be treated with other minimally invasive procedures such as shock wave lithotripsy (SWL) or ureteroscopy.
  2. Staghorn calculi (large branching stones) that occupy a significant portion of the kidney.
  3. Stones that are associated with renal obstruction or infection.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male admitted to the ICU for acute exacerbation of COPD develops a sudden onset of palpitations. The following ECG changes are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Multifocal atrial tachycardia             

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. VT is usually regular and wide QRS tachycardia (QRS > 120ms).

 

Option B. P waves usually absent in AF.

 

Option D. Atrial tachycardia is regular narrow QRS tachycardia with fixed morphology of P wave.

 

Note:

 

  • MAT is usually associated with lung disease and occurs secondary to underlying hypoxemia.
  • Treatment is with CCB > BB to slow the atrial, ventricular rate.
  • Cardioversion is ineffective and contraindicated in this rhythm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia is characterized by multiple ectopic atrial activities leading to variable P wave morphologies and an irregular rhythm, often associated with underlying chronic pulmonary conditions. Management focuses on treating the underlying condition and stabilizing the rate with appropriate medications.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/chap 250/7033

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is not supplied by the structure marked by red arrow? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Superior oblique

 

The superior oblique muscle is not supplied by the oculomotor nerve, which is the structure highlighted in the figure. Superior oblique muscle is supplied by the trochlear nerve.

 

All the extraocular muscles are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except:

 

  • ﻿﻿Lateral rectus which is supplied by abducens (VI) nerve
  • ﻿﻿Superior oblique which is supplied by trochlear (IV) nerve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior rectus: This muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve, which is the structure indicated by the red arrow in the image. This muscle helps in elevating the eye.

 

Option C. Medial rectus: Also supplied by the oculomotor nerve, this muscle is responsible for adducting the eye towards the nose.

 

Option D. Levator palpebrae superioris (LPS): Innervated by the oculomotor nerve, the LPS is essential for elevating the upper eyelid, enabling the opening of the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Rough handling of thyroid during surgery

questions.text: A 46-year-old female is undergoing thyroidectomy for a large goiter. During the procedure, the patient develops tachycardia, hypertension, and hyperthermia. She becomes agitated and confused. Laboratory tests reveal elevated thyroid hormone levels, and a diagnosis of thyroid storm is made. The surgical team immediately stops the procedure, and the patient is transferred to the intensive care unit for treatment. What is the most common cause of thyroid storm during thyroidectomy? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inadequate patient preparation

 

Inadequate preparation of a patient with hyperthyroidism before thyroidectomy, such as not optimizing thyroid function and medication management, can increase the risk of thyroid storm. Proper preoperative management and stabilization of thyroid function are crucial to prevent this complication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rough handling of thyroid during surgery: While rough handling during thyroid surgery can potentially lead to complications, it is not the usual cause of thyroid storm.

 

Option B. Due to parathyroid gland injury: The parathyroid glands are separate from the thyroid gland and regulate calcium levels in the body. Complications involving the parathyroid glands can occur during thyroid surgery leading to postoperative hypocalcemia.

 

Option D. Infections: Infections can occur as complications after thyroid surgery, but they are not the usual cause of thyroid storm. Thyroid storm is primarily related to the excessive release of thyroid hormones into the bloodstream.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A thyroid storm, also known as thyrotoxic crisis, is a rare but life-threatening medical emergency that occurs in individuals with severe hyperthyroidism. Hyperthyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland produces an excessive amount of thyroid hormones, primarily thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3). In a thyroid storm, these hormone levels become dangerously elevated, leading to a wide range of symptoms and complications.

 

Symptoms of a thyroid storm may include:

 

  1. High fever
  2. Rapid and irregular heartbeat (tachycardia)
  3. Elevated blood pressure
  4. Extreme agitation and restlessness
  5. Profuse sweating
  6. Tremors and shaking
  7. Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea
  8. Delirium or confusion
  9. Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
  10. Coma (in severe cases)

 

Thyroid storms can be triggered by various factors, such as surgery, infection, trauma, or medication changes in individuals with underlying hyperthyroidism. The condition is more common in people with Graves' disease, a common cause of hyperthyroidism.

 

Treatment of a thyroid storm is a medical emergency and typically involves a combination of interventions to rapidly lower thyroid hormone levels, control symptoms, and support vital organ function.

 

The usual cause of thyroid storm in thyroidectomy is inadequate patient preparation before surgery. Thus, patient preparation pre-operatively involves ensuring a euthyroid state.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion.
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not a correct explanation of the assertion.
Assertion is true, but the reason is false.
Assertion is false, but the reason is true.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the given statements?

 

Assertion: About 10% of patients with sarcoidosis present with hypercalcemia or hypercalciuria along with suppressed PTH levels.


Reason: Granulomas convert 25-OH Vitamin D to 1,25-OH Vitamin D due to the increased presence of 1α hydroxylase enzyme.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion.

 

Hypercalcemia or hypercalciuria is seen in approximately 10% of patients with sarcoidosis. This is because the elevated calcium level in the bloodstream leads to a suppression of parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. The underlying mechanism involves granulomas found in sarcoidosis, which exhibit increased 1α hydroxylase enzyme activity. This enzyme facilitates the conversion of inactive 25-OH Vitamin D to its active form, 1,25-OH Vitamin D, which subsequently raises the calcium levels.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Granulomas in sarcoidosis can activate 1α hydroxylase, leading to the conversion of 25-OH Vitamin D to 1,25-OH Vitamin D and causing hypercalcemia with suppressed PTH levels.

choices.text: Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain

questions.text: A young boy from high altitude came with fever and weakness and had the following reports Hemoglobin 17 gm%, TLC is 21,000 with neutrophils 25, lymphocytes 30, eosinophils 5, myelocytes and metamyelocytes 40 in peripheral smear. Next step in the investigation should be: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Erythropoietin levels

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia (Hb>16 g/dL). Erythropoietin levels should be determined to differentiate primary from secondary forms.

 

Polycythemia vera (PCV) is characterized by increased marrow production of red cells, granulocytes, and platelets (panmyelosis), but it is the increase in red cells (polycythemia), that is responsible for most of the clinical symptoms. PCV must be differentiated from relative polycythemia resulting from hemoconcentration and other causes of absolute polycythemia. PCV is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase JAK2.

 

In PCV the progenitor cells have markedly decreased requirements for erythropoietin and other hematopoietic growth factors due to constitutive JAK2 signaling. Accordingly, serum erythropoietin levels in PCV are very low, whereas secondary forms of absolute polycythemia have high erythropoietin levels.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Philadelphia chromosome: This test is relevant in diagnosing chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), not polycythemia. While the presence of immature myeloid cells (myelocytes and metamyelocytes) could suggest a myeloproliferative disorder, the patient's clinical presentation and high hemoglobin level are more consistent with polycythemia, making erythropoietin testing a more appropriate next step.

 

Option B. JAK mutation: Testing for the JAK2 mutation is crucial in confirming a diagnosis of PCV. However, before proceeding to this test, it is important to measure erythropoietin levels to differentiate between primary and secondary polycythemia. If erythropoietin levels are low, JAK2 mutation analysis would then be the next step.

 

Option D. Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain: This investigation is used to evaluate bone marrow fibrosis, which can occur in myeloproliferative disorders like PCV. However, it is not the first-line investigation in this scenario. The erythropoietin level is a less invasive test that provides critical information to guide further diagnostic steps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythropoietin levels should be measured to differentiate between primary and secondary polycythemia. In cases of polycythemia vera, erythropoietin levels are typically low due to constitutive JAK2 signaling, while secondary polycythemia is associated with high erythropoietin levels.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cortans pathologic basis of disease, Pg 1161, 1242

choices.text: 1-F, 2- E, 3-D, 4- B
1-F, 2-E, 3-B, 4-A

questions.text: Match the following drugs poisoning with the antidotes:(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1-F, 2-E, 3-B, 4-A

 

1. HCN (Hydrogen Cyanide):

 

  • Antidote: F. Amyl nitrite
    HCN poisoning, also known as cyanide poisoning, is treated with amyl nitrite, which induces methemoglobinemia, allowing cyanide to bind to methemoglobin instead of cytochrome oxidase, reducing its toxicity. The DOC for cyanide poisoning is Hydroxocobalamine.

 

2. Paracetamol (Acetaminophen):

 

  • Antidote: E. N-acetylcysteine
    N-acetylcysteine replenishes glutathione stores, helping detoxify the reactive metabolite of paracetamol, thereby preventing liver damage.

 

3. Morphine:

 

  • Antidote: B. Nalorphine
    Nalorphine is an opioid antagonist used to counteract the effects of opioid overdose, including morphine.

 

4. Nicotine:

 

  • Antidote: A. Trimethadione
    Trimethadione is used in cases of nicotine poisoning due to its ganglionic blocking properties, similar to the Nn receptor blockers (ganglionic blockers) like Trimethaphan and Hexamethonium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HCN poisoning: DOC is Hydroxocobalamin. Amyl Nitrite(inhalational) with sodium thiosulphate (iv) can also be used.
  • Paracetamol poisoning (causes hepatoxicity): N-acetylcysteine is used.
  • Morphine poisoning: DOC is Naloxone. Nalorphine can also be used.
  • Nicotine poisoning: Trimethaphan and Hexamethonium – Nn receptor blockers

(ganglionic blockers) are used.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/590, 223, 509, 134

choices.text: Metronidazole
Fluconazole
Clindamycin

questions.text: Drug of choice for treatment of pregnant woman with bacterial vaginosis? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metronidazole

 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating bacterial vaginosis (BV) in pregnant women. This choice is based on its efficacy in addressing the anaerobic bacterial overgrowth that characterizes BV. It is generally prescribed as 200 mg three times daily for 7 days during pregnancy. While Clindamycin is also used for BV and can be an alternative, Metronidazole remains the preferred treatment due to its effectiveness and established safety profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fluconazole: This drug is used for the treatment of fungal infections like candidiasis, not bacterial vaginosis.

 

Option C. Clindamycin: Clindamycin is an alternative treatment for BV, especially if Metronidazole is contraindicated or not tolerated. However, Metronidazole is typically preferred.

 

Option D. Erythromycin: This antibiotic is generally used for various bacterial infections but is not the first choice for BV. It is not typically used for treating bacterial vaginosis in pregnant women.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating bacterial vaginosis in pregnant women.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

questions.text:
For the detection of Diabetes Mellitus in a population over 40 but less than 60, two screening tests are performed simultaneously, without considering the result of one before conducting the other. This method leads to:


1. Decreased Specificity for detecting DM
2. Increased Sensitivity for detecting DM
3. Increased Negative Predictive Value
4. Increased Specificity for detecting DM
5. Reduced sensitivity for detecting diabetes
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2 and 3

 

When two screening tests are used in parallel, both tests are performed independently, and the results of one test do not influence whether the second test is done. The primary purpose of using tests in parallel is to increase the likelihood of detecting a condition if it is present, which affects sensitivity and predictive values as follows:

 

1. Increased Sensitivity for detecting DM (B): Performing tests in parallel increases the overall sensitivity, meaning that more cases of diabetes mellitus are likely to be detected. This is because if either test returns positive, the condition is considered present, reducing the chance of a false negative.

 

2. Decreased Specificity for detecting DM (A): While sensitivity increases, specificity decreases. This occurs because a higher likelihood of obtaining a positive result also means there is an increased chance of false positives, thereby reducing specificity.

 

3. Increased Negative Predictive Value (C): Negative Predictive Value (NPV) improves because if both tests come back negative, there is a very high probability that the person does not have diabetes mellitus. Thus, the reliability of a negative result is strengthened.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Increased Specificity for detecting DM: Incorrect, Using tests in parallel reduces specificity because the probability of a false positive increases when either test is sufficient for a positive result.

 

5. Decreased Sensitivity for detecting DM: Incorrect, The sensitivity actually increases when tests are used in parallel, as the likelihood of detecting true positive cases is higher.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Performing two screening tests in parallel increases sensitivity and negative predictive value while decreasing specificity.

questions.text: Gene involved in Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GABRA-1

 

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME), also known as Janz syndrome, is a common type of generalized epilepsy that typically manifests in adolescents and young adults. It is characterized by myoclonic jerks, generalized tonic-clonic seizures, and absence seizures. A mutation in the GABRA-1 gene, which encodes for the alpha-1 subunit of the GABA(A) receptor, has been linked to juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. The GABA(A) receptor is crucial in mediating inhibitory neurotransmission in the brain, and mutations in this gene can disrupt normal neuronal function, leading to the seizures characteristic of JME.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CHYNN-1: This gene is not associated with juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. The correct genes associated with JME include GABRA-1 and others like CLNC2, EFHC1, and CACNB4.

 

Option C. FMR-1: The FMR-1 gene is associated with Fragile X syndrome, which is a leading cause of inherited intellectual disability, not juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

 

Option D. All of the above: This option is incorrect because not all the genes listed are involved in juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. Only GABRA-1 from the options given is directly linked to JME.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The GABRA-1 gene is a key genetic factor in juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

choices.text: TIBC increased, Ferritin decreased, Transferrin saturation increased
TIBC increased, Soluble transferrin receptor decreased, Ferritin increased
TIBC increased, Transferrin saturation decreased, Ferritin decreased
TIBC increased, Transferrin saturation decreased, Ferritin increased

questions.text: Which of the following are features of iron deficiency anemia? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) TIBC increased, Transferrin saturation decreased, Ferritin decreased

 

In iron deficiency anemia, TIBC is increased, transferrin saturation is decreased, and ferritin is decreased.

 

Progressive depletion of iron reserves first lowers serum iron and transferrin saturation levels without producing anemia. In this early stage there is increased erythroid activity in the bone marrow.

 

Anemia appears only when iron stores are completely depleted and is accompanied by low serum iron, ferritin, and transferrin saturation levels.

 

The serum iron and ferritin are low, and the total plasma iron-binding capacity (reflecting elevated transferrin levels) is high. Low serum iron with increased iron-binding capacity results in a reduction of transferrin saturation to below 15%. Reduced iron stores inhibit hepcidin synthesis, and its serum levels fall and this in turn facilitates iron absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differential Diagnosis:

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 1231-1234

questions.text: In a clinical study exploring the relationship between variables X and Y, a scatter plot with a linear regression line has been generated. Based on the graphical representation provided, which of the following equations corresponds to the linear regression model of the plotted graph? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) y=11+2x

 

  • Y = 11 + 2x is a simple linear regression equation where a = 11 and b = 2 are constants and x and y are variables.
  • Regression is change in measurements of a variable. It provides structure of relationship between 2 quantitative variables.

 

Types of regressions:

 

  • Simple linear regression: Only one dependent variable and one independent variable
  • Multiple linear regression: Only one dependent variable and more than one independent variable
  • Simple curvilinear regression: Only one dependent variable and one independent variable, with some power of independent variable
  • Multiple curvilinear regression: Only one dependent variable and more than one independent variables, with some power of independent variables).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of regression equations:

questions.text:
In the given section of the heart, match the marked (4, 9, 12, 1) structures:

 

  1. Outflow to pulmonary trunk (blue)
  2. Mitral valve
  3. Tricuspid valve
  4. Papillary muscles
questions.solution:
Ans. C. a-1, b-4, c-9, D-12

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a cut and reflected section of the heart.

 

The ventricles can be identified based upon the wall thickness - Left ventricle has thicker walls.

 

  1. Outflow to pulmonary trunk (marked as 1): This structure represents the exit point for blood traveling to the lungs for oxygenation.
  2. Mitral valve (marked as 4): Located between the left atrium and the left ventricle, the mitral valve regulates blood flow within the heart.
  3. Tricuspid valve (marked as 9): This valve, situated between the right atrium and right ventricle, prevents backflow of blood from the ventricles to the atria.
  4. Papillary muscles (marked as 12): These muscles are attached to the ventricular walls and play a critical role in the function of the mitral and tricuspid valves via tendon-like chords.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct match is:

 

1. Outflow to pulmonary trunk (blue)

2. Left atrium

3. Pulmonary veins (light red)

4. Mitral valve

5. Aorta (red).

6. Superior vena cava (blue)

7. Aortic semi lunar valve

8. Right atrium

9. Tricuspid valve

10. Right ventricle

11. Inferior vena cave (blue)

12. Papillary muscles

13. Left ventricle

questions.text: Transmission assessment survey is carried out for: (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Filariasis

 

Transmission assessment survey is carried out for filariasis.

 

Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is targeted for global elimination through treatment of entire at-risk populations with repeated annual mass drug administration (MDA). Essential for program success is defining and confirming the appropriate endpoint for MDA when transmission is presumed to have reached a level low enough that it cannot be sustained even in the absence of drug intervention. Guidelines advanced by WHO call for a transmission assessment survey (TAS) to determine if MDA can be stopped within an LF evaluation unit (EU) after at least five effective rounds of annual treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. P. vivax: Transmission assessment surveys are not typically used for evaluating the transmission of Plasmodium vivax, which causes malaria.

 

Option B. P. falciparum: Transmission assessment surveys are not typically used for evaluating the transmission of Plasmodium falciparum, another cause of malaria.

 

Option D. Leishmania: Transmission assessment surveys are not used for Leishmania species, which cause leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transmission Assessment Surveys (TAS) are essential tools used to evaluate the success of mass drug administration programs for lymphatic filariasis and determine if the transmission levels are low enough to discontinue these programs.

choices.text: More common after life threatening trauma
Seen in seizure and migraine patients
Mean age at onset is 25 years

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding depersonalization disorder? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Seen in seizure and migraine patients

 

Depersonalization disorder (DPD) is characterized by persistent or recurrent feelings of detachment or estrangement from one's own thoughts, emotions, body, or surroundings.

 

DPD can be associated with other medical conditions, including seizure disorders and migraines, as stated in option B.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. While it can occur as a reaction to life-threatening trauma, it is not specifically more common after such events .

 

Option C. The disorder has a slight male predominance.

 

Option D. The mean age of onset for depersonalization disorder is typically in the mid to late teens, not 25 years.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Depersonalisation disorder is characterized by feelings of unreality or detachment from oneself or one’s body. The patients feel ‘as if’ they have changed. They can be associated with medical conditions such as migraine, seizure disorder, cerebral tumors and encephalitis.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 110

questions.text: Identify the device shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Automated External Defibrillator

 

Explanation:

 

Automated External Defibrillator (AED):

 

  • Definition: An automated external defibrillator (AED) is a portable electronic device that automatically diagnoses the life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias of ventricular fibrillation (VF) and pulseless ventricular tachycardia, and is able to treat them through defibrillation, the application of electricity which stops the arrhythmia, allowing the heart to re-establish an effective rhythm.

 

  • Rapid Defibrillation: Rapid defibrillation is paramount in improving survival rates from sudden cardiac arrest due to ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia.

 

  • User-Friendly and Accessible: AEDs are made for laypersons and first responders, not just for medical professionals. They come with voice prompts and sometimes visual displays to guide the user through each step of the defibrillation process. This design makes it possible for people without extensive medical training to assist in a cardiac emergency.

 

  • Self-Analyzing: An AED automatically evaluates the heart rhythm of a person in cardiac arrest. If the device detects a shockable rhythm, it will instruct the user to deliver a shock; if not, it will guide the user to continue with CPR or other appropriate interventions. This ensures that shocks are only given when necessary.

 

  • Public Availability: Many public places such as airports, gyms, schools, and shopping centers have publicly accessible AEDs. Increasing the availability and visibility of AEDs in public spaces can reduce the time to defibrillation and increase survival rates from out-of-hospital cardiac arrest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Automated External Desynchronizer: This term is incorrect and not associated with any known medical device.

 

Option C. Automated Electronic Defibrillator: This term is incorrect and not associated with any known medical device.

 

Option D. Automated External Decompressor: This term is incorrect and not associated with any known medical device.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • An Automated External Defibrillator (AED) is a crucial device for rapidly diagnosing and treating life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias through defibrillation, especially designed for use by laypersons and first responders to increase survival rates in cases of sudden cardiac arrest.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2537

questions.text: A drug trial was initiated under Medicine department to test the efficacy of a new medication in comparison to a placebo. The participants were divided into two cohorts. Cohort A received a placebo, while cohort B was treated with the novel drug. Out of the 120 participants in cohort A, 36 faced fatal outcomes. In cohort B, with 130 participants, there were 26 fatal outcomes. Given this data, if a clinician were to incorporate this novel medication into practice, how many patients would they need to treat with this new medication to prevent one additional fatality when compared to the placebo group? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 10

 

10 patients need to be treated with the new drug to avert 1 death.

 

We can group divide the case scenario into two groups:

 

Experimental (New treatment) group – 26 Treatment failures out of 130

 

Control (Old treatment) group – 36 Treatment failures out of 120

 

 

Now, we have to calculate failure rate in both groups:

 

Experimental (New treatment) group – 26/130 = 0.2

 

Control (Old treatment) group – 36/120 = 0.3

 

 Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is the difference of failure in both groups = 0.3 – 0.2 = 0.1

 

Number needed to treat (NNT) = 1/ARR = 1/0.1 = 10

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Number Needed to Treat (NNT) is a practical measure used in decision-making for clinical interventions.
  • It represents the number of patients that need to be treated with a particular therapy over a specific period to prevent one additional bad outcome, such as death in this scenario.
  • An NNT of 10 indicates that the new medication has a significant impact in reducing fatalities compared to the placebo.

questions.text: Which among the following occupation is a risk factor for this presenting illness? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kennel worker

 

The above image shows cutaneous larva migrans. Parasite eggs are passed in the feces of infected animals (cats, dogs) into the soil, where the larvae hatch out. Hence kennel workers are at high risk.

 

This condition also known as creeping eruption (ground itch) is caused by nematode larvae that infect by skin penetration.

 

On coming in contact with human skin, the larvae penetrate the skin to cause infection.

 

In normal animal host, the larvae are able to penetrate the deeper layers of the skin by reaching there via circulation.

 

Once they enter intestine, they mature sexually and lay more eggs that are then excreted to repeat the cycle.

 

However, in a human host, which is an accidental host for the parasite, the larvae are unable to penetrate the basement membrane to invade the dermis, so that the disease remains confined to the outer layers of the skin.

 

The larvae produce itching papules, which develop into serpiginous tunnels in the epidermis. With the movements of the larva in the skin, the lesion also shifts, hence the name "creeping eruption''. Scratching may lead to secondary bacterial infection.

 

Transient creeping eruptions may be produced sometimes by the human hookworm, Necator americanus. Gnathostomiasis and sparganosis may produce larva migrans, where the lesions are deeper, subcutaneous or in the muscles. Loeffler's syndrome may occur in one-fourth to one-half of the cases.

 

A rapidly moving lesion is produced by Strongyloides stercoralis particularly in immune persons. This is known as larva currens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lifeguard in a swimming pool: This occupation does not typically involve exposure to soil contaminated with animal feces.

 

Option C. Veterinarian: While veterinarians do work with animals, they are less likely to be exposed to soil contaminated with the specific nematodes causing cutaneous larva migrans.

 

Option D. Poultry Worker: This occupation involves working with birds, which are not typically hosts for the nematodes causing this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cutaneous larva migrans, caused by nematode larvae from Ancylostoma species, is commonly associated with occupations that involve close contact with contaminated soil and animal feces, such as kennel workers.

 

Additional Information

choices.text: Cephalic phase of gastric secretion
Cerebellar action in motor coordination
Exercise resulting in heart rate increase

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of feed forward control mechanism? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Exercise resulting in heart rate increase

 

Feedforward mechanism is the control system of our body that anticipates and makes corrective changes without any stimulus. Also called as Anticipatory or Adaptive Control.

 

For instance, some movements of the body occur so rapidly that there is not enough time for nerve signals to travel from the peripheral parts of the body all the way to the brain and then back to the periphery again to control the movement. Therefore, the brain uses a principle called feed-forward control to cause required muscle contractions wherein sensory nerve signals from the moving parts inform the brain whether the movement is performed correctly. If not, the brain corrects the feed-forward signals that it sends to the muscles the next time the movement is required. Then, if still further correction is needed, this will be done again for subsequent movements. This is called adaptive control.

 

Examples include

 

  • Thermoregulation by hypothalamus BEFORE the changes in environmental temperature changes the body's core body temperature
  • Cephalic phase of gastric secretion- Increase in gastric acid secretion on thinking about food
  • THINKING about exercise leading to increase heart rate & respiratory rate
  • Motor coordination by cerebellum

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Temperature Regulation: Incorrect. This is a feedforward mechanism where the hypothalamus anticipates and adjusts for temperature changes.

 

Option B. Cephalic phase of gastric secretion: Incorrect. This is a feedforward mechanism where thinking about food triggers gastric secretions in anticipation of eating.

 

Option C. Cerebellar action in motor coordination: Incorrect. This is a feedforward mechanism where the cerebellum coordinates movements by predicting the required muscle contractions.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: How is wound infection severity graded? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Southampton grading

 

Southampton wound grading system is a scoring system for the severity of wound infection.

 

  • The Southampton Wound Grading System is a widely recognized method for grading wound infection severity.
  • It categorizes surgical site infections (SSI) into different grades based on clinical signs, such as erythema (redness), purulent discharge, and wound breakdown.
  • The grading system allows healthcare providers to classify SSIs as minor, moderate, or severe based on specific criteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ASA classification: The ASA (American Society of Anesthesiologists) classification system is primarily used to assess a patient's overall health and fitness for surgery.

 

  • It does not directly grade wound infection severity.

 

Option B. SIRS criteria (Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome): SIRS criteria are used to identify systemic inflammation and are not specific to grading wound infection severity.

 

  • These criteria include parameters like temperature, heart rate, respiratory rate, and white blood cell count.

 

Option D. APACHE II score (Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation II): The APACHE II score is a severity of illness scoring system used to assess critically ill patients in intensive care units.

 

  • It does not directly relate to grading wound infection severity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Southampton grading:

 

 

In summary, the Southampton grading system is the appropriate option for grading wound infection severity as it provides a structured approach to categorizing surgical site infections based on clinical criteria. This system helps healthcare providers assess the seriousness of wound infections and make appropriate treatment decisions.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with chest pain and shortness of breath. Further investigation reveals a mediastinal mass on imaging studies. The patient is referred to a specialist for further evaluation. What is the most common type of tumor found in the anterior mediastinum? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thymoma

 

The most common anterior mediastinal tumor is thymoma, while posterior mediastinal tumor is neurogenic tumor.

 

The most common mediastinal tumor in children is neurogenic tumor.

 

  • Thymomas are tumors that originate from the thymus gland located in the mediastinum.
  • They account for a significant portion of mediastinal tumors and are the most common type.
  • Thymomas can vary in terms of malignancy, with some being benign (noncancerous) and others being malignant (cancerous).
  • These tumors can cause chest pain, shortness of breath, and other symptoms when they grow and press on nearby structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neurogenic: Neurogenic tumors, which originate from nerve tissue, are another type of mediastinal tumor found in posterior mediastinum

 

  • Examples of neurogenic tumors include neuroblastoma and ganglioneuroma.

 

Option C. Lymphoma: Lymphomas can occur in the mediastinum but are less frequent than thymomas.

 

  • Lymphomas originate from lymphatic tissue and can be Hodgkin lymphoma or non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

 

Option D. Bronchial cyst: Bronchial cysts are fluid-filled sacs that can develop in the mediastinum but are relatively rare compared to thymomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, thymoma is the most common type of tumor found in the mediastinum, and it originates from the thymus gland. When a patient presents with chest pain and shortness of breath and is found to have a mediastinal mass on imaging studies, thymoma is a likely consideration among other possible mediastinal tumors

questions.text: Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to the plasma by binding to? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ferroportin

 

Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to plasma by binding to ferroportin.

 

Iron absorption is regulated by hepcidin, a small circulating peptide that is synthesized and released from the liver in response to increases in intrahepatic iron levels.

 

Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to plasma by binding to ferriportin and causing it to be endocytosed and degraded. As a result, as hepcidin levels rise, iron becomes trapped within duodenal cells in the form of mucosal ferritin and is lost as these cells are sloughed. Thus, when the body is replete with iron, high hepcidin levels inhibit its absorption into the blood.

 

Conversely, with low body stores of iron, hepcidin synthesis falls and this in turn facilitates iron absorption. By inhibiting ferriportin, hepcidin not only reduces iron uptake from enterocytes but also suppresses iron release from macrophages, which are an important source of the iron that is used by erythroid precursors to make hemoglobin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transferrin: Transferrin is a plasma protein that binds iron in the blood and transports it to various tissues, particularly the bone marrow for erythropoiesis. Hepcidin does not bind to transferrin; instead, it regulates iron export through ferroportin.

 

Option C. Divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1): DMT1 is involved in the uptake of iron (in its ferrous form) from the lumen of the intestine into enterocytes. Hepcidin does not interact with DMT1; its regulatory effect occurs after iron has been absorbed into enterocytes, at the point of iron export into the bloodstream via ferroportin.

 

Option D. Ferritin: Ferritin is the intracellular protein that stores iron in a soluble and non-toxic form. Hepcidin does not bind to ferritin directly. However, by reducing the expression of ferroportin, hepcidin indirectly increases the storage of iron within cells in the form of ferritin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepcidin regulates iron homeostasis by binding to ferroportin, leading to its degradation, which prevents iron export from enterocytes into the plasma and from macrophages.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 1231

questions.text: Acute inflammatory response is not seen in: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Apoptosis

 

An inflammatory response is not seen in apoptosis. In this process, the cell membrane remains intact. Hence, there is no leakage of cell contents and no surrounding inflammation.

 

On the other hand, other forms of cell death including necrosis, necroptosis, and pyroptosis involve the disintegration of the cell membrane. This causes the cell contents to leak out of the cell leading to an acute inflammatory response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyroptosis: Pyroptosis is a form of cell death associated with inflammation. It involves the activation of caspase-1, leading to the formation of pores in the cell membrane and the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines, ultimately resulting in cell lysis and an inflammatory response.

 

Option B. Necroptosis: Necroptosis is a form of programmed cell death that is morphologically similar to necrosis. It results in cell swelling, membrane rupture, and the release of inflammatory mediators.

 

Option D. Necrosis: Necrosis is an uncontrolled form of cell death that leads to the release of cell contents into the extracellular space, which triggers an inflammatory response.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apoptosis is a non-inflammatory form of programmed cell death, characterized by the maintenance of membrane integrity and the absence of an acute inflammatory response. In contrast, necrosis, necroptosis, and pyroptosis involve membrane rupture and the release of intracellular contents, leading to inflammation.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 33-34

questions.text: An affected male does not have affected children but an affected female always has affected children. Type of inheritance? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mitochondrial

 

A person mitochondrial genome is completely derived from the mother as sperm contain relatively few mitochondria which are degraded after fertilization. Thus, the mitochondrial inheritance is essentially maternal inheritance.

 

Mitochondrial genetic disorder can affect either sex, but males cannot transmit the disease to offspring.

 

 

Here are some examples of mitochondrial inheritance:

 

  1. Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON): This is a rare genetic disorder that affects the optic nerve and can cause vision loss due small fibres papulomacular bundles dropouts.
  2. Mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes (MELAS): MELAS can be inherited from the mother, but it can also occur sporadically due to new mutations in the mtDNA.
  3. Myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fibers (MERRF): This is a rare condition that causes seizures, muscle weakness, and other symptoms.
  4. Kearns-Sayre syndrome (KSS): This is a rare condition that affects multiple systems in the body, including the eyes (CPEO), heart (Heart blocks), and muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial inheritance is characterized by the transmission of genetic traits solely through the maternal line, where affected females pass the condition to all of their offspring, while affected males do not pass it on to their children

choices.text: 1-A, 2-C, 3-C, 4-D
1-B, 2-C, 3-D, 4-E
1-D, 2-A, 3-B, 4-F
1-D, 2-B, 3-A, 4-F

questions.text: Match the following drugs with the organism they are used for? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, 4-F

 

The correct matches based on the given drugs and organisms:

 

  1. Praziquantal: This drug is primarily used for the treatment of flukes (except liver fluke) and tapeworms (except dog tapeworm). Therefore, the correct match for Praziquantal is D (Tapeworms).
  2. Di Ethyl Carbamezine: This drug is the drug of choice for the treatment of filariasis, making A (Filaria) the correct match.
  3. Nitazoxanide: This drug is used for Cryptosporidium and also for Giardia. However, the drug of choice for Giardia is metronidazole or tinidazole, but Nitazoxanide is also effective against Giardia. Therefore, the correct match for Nitazoxanide is B (Giardia).
  4. Mebendazole: This drug is used for treating various nematodes, including Ascaris lumbricoides. Therefore, the correct match for Mebendazole is F (Ascaris lumbricoides).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Drug of choice for treatment of flukes (except liver fluke) and tapeworms (except dog tapeworm) is Praziquantal.
    • Drug of choice for treatment of liver fluke is triclabendazole.
    • Drug of choice for dog tapeworm (Echinococcus) is albendazole
  • Drug of choice for all nematodes (see exceptions below) is albendazole (or Mebendazole)
    • Drug of choice for treatment of filariasis is Diethylcarbamazine.
    • Drug of choice for treatment of Onchocerca and Strongyloides is ivermectin.
  • Nitazoxanide: DOC for Cryptosporidium and also used for Giardia (DOC is metronidazole and tinidazole)

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/907

questions.text:
Regarding prostate cancer, which of the following statements is/are true?

 

  1. Prostate cancer commonly arises from the central zone.
  2. Histological grading is done by Gleason's score.
  3. The most common type of prostate cancer is squamous cell carcinoma.
  4. It is hormone-dependent.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 4

 

Statement 2: Histological grading is done by Gleason's score.

 

This statement is true. The Gleason scoring system is the standard method for grading prostate cancer based on its histological appearance. It assesses the architectural patterns of prostate cancer cells, assigning a score that helps predict the aggressiveness of the cancer. 

 

 

Statement 4: It is hormone-dependent.

This statement is true. Prostate cancer growth is typically driven by androgens, such as testosterone. Androgen deprivation therapy, which reduces androgen levels or blocks their effects, is a common treatment approach for prostate cancer. 

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 1. Prostate cancer commonly arises from the central zone: This statement is false. Approximately 70% of prostate cancers originate in the peripheral zone, 10-15% in the transitional zone, and only 15-20% in the central zone. 

 

Statement 3. The most common type of prostate cancer is squamous cell carcinoma. This statement is false. Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of prostate cancer, accounting for over 95% of cases. Squamous cell carcinoma of the prostate is extremely rare, comprising less than 1% of prostate cancers. 

 

Educational Objective:
